DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance entitled Vocational Registration of General Practitioners.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate Select Committee has canvassed the issues in clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Amendment Legislation 1989 under its terms of reference and recommends to the Senate that clause 10 be proclaimed, but only after regulations to provide mechanisms for alternative pathways to vocational registration and appeals mechanisms have been presented to the Parliament.

Before I speak to the content of the report I have two points. Firstly, I apologise to the Senate that no copies of the report are currently available. I believe that chapter 5, containing a brief summary and list of the recommendations, is about to be or has been circulated in this chamber. Essentially because of the time constraints which the Committee has had to deal with, I have to seek the tolerance of the Senate in this regard. I thank honourable senators.

Secondly, I would like to place on record my thanks to and appreciation of the secretariat who have so ably assisted the Committee in its work: Derek Abbott, the Secretary, assisted by Barry Jenkins, Laurie Swift and Christine McDonald. Whilst those of us on the Committee worked flat out, I think we would all acknowledge that the secretariat ran twice as fast behind the scenes. The success of this report is in large part, or at least in no small measure, due to their considerable work. So we are able to bring into the Senate but one day late the report as required and requested by the Senate.

I think it is also very important to appreciate how constructively and cooperatively the senators on this Committee worked. I would like to place on record my appreciation for that behaviour by the senators involved in this inquiry. It has been a very interesting and constructive exercise. I think it is a measure of the good working of this Committee that I can now table in the Senate a unanimous report signed by all members of the Committee.

The Committee received 225 submissions and conducted four days of public hearings in Canberra and Sydney, where we heard evidence from 27 witnesses. In selecting those witnesses to appear before the Committee, we sought as much as possible-and, I think, achieved-a very wide representation of the views that were brought to the Committee's attention in the submissions. I think those witnesses also reflected the range of views that had been raised in the debate in this place. For the record I note that Dr Shepherd from the New South Wales Australian Medical Association (AMA) has written-I do not know to who else, but certainly I have received a letter-complaining that the Committee did not hear evidence from an American doctor, Frank Rogers, who was in the country. I note for the record that the Committee, as honourable senators would appreciate, was under considerable time constraints. It selected 27 witnesses out of 225 who presented submissions. Many people-for example, deans of medical schools, professors of medicine and general practitioners from across this country who sought the opportunity to put evidence to the Committee-had to be denied the opportunity to appear before the Committee at its public hearings. Further, I make no apology about saying that it was Australian views we were canvassing about Australian medical practice, to consider Australian legislation. We received our terms of reference from the Senate and responded to them and not to an American-led agenda proposed by Dr Shepherd.

The Committee had the benefit of a number of witnesses who gave to the Committee documentary evidence, citing reports about the situation overseas, particularly in comparison to Western countries, and not limited to the United States. We received a range of evidence, not just views reflecting our own perspective, or the Australian perspective. Given the time constraints we judged that the more than sufficient number of witnesses from Australia would best assist us in our task, rather than the views of one doctor from America.

We noted too that one doctor may present one side of an argument and that, if we were minded to take evidence from overseas witnesses, we would also have liked the opportunity to have a range of views presented. That is the accounting of why the Committee made that decision. We also note, for the record, that Dr Bruce Shepherd was invited to appear as a witness but declined.

The Committee, as I think most would appreciate, had the contribution of senators in the debate in this place on the legislation to assist it, and indeed many of the issues raised in the hearings covered the points from the Senate debate. We conclude that the inquiry has been very useful and constructive, and as I said before, it was conducted in a very cooperative and useful atmosphere. It has addressed the substantive points of concern raised in the debate in the Senate and raised in the public domain and within the profession, as well as in the submissions and hearings.

I think the Committee was very much assisted by the comprehensive submissions from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and from the Department. Those submissions addressed the concerns of substance in the legislation and also took into account many of the points that had been raised in debate, both in the public arena and in the Senate, prior to the hearings and I think assisted the Committee considerable in its deliberations.

I would have to say that the submission from the AMA was a little less helpful. It contained within its own pages a number of contradictions and conclusions in opposition to what seemed to be its earlier positions of support for the ideas and intentions of vocation training and content-based descriptors, for example. The Committee appreciated very early on-and certainly from the submissions in evidence-that there was widespread misunderstanding of the proposal. That was not assisted by evidence of mischievous misrepresentation of the facts. Add to that insufficient consultation and we get a potent brew for confusion and anxiety. The legislation that we had to contend with properly understood this, I think, and anyone reading this report should take considerable comfort from how the concerns are largely laid to rest. For the record, the legislation establishes a vocational register for doctors who seek to be registered. It is not mandatory, and doctors who chose not to register will be able to continue to practise their medicine as they do now.

I think we can say that the Royal Australian College criteria for eligibility for vocational registration are clearly defined and need to be understood as addressing two things: one, the interim arrangements up to 1995, and then the arrangements from then on. I think that, when they are properly understood and properly read and appreciated, much of the confusion about criteria for eligibility will be laid to rest too. I also think it is important to note for the record that interim arrangements are interim: and I think some people had not appreciated that fact either.

I believe that the proposals under clause 10-if I did not say this in my Senate contribution, I will say it now-contain prospects for innovation in health care delivery and for opportunities for better, more interesting and exciting medical practice for the practitioners themselves. Indeed, I think the college and the Government need to be congratulated for their efforts to actually achieve that. The opening paragraph of chapter 5 reads:

For many years, general practice and its practitioners have had to struggle for fair recognition within the medical world. Despite the fact that general practice is the first port of call for the majority of people seeking medical care and assistance, it has long been the view that general practice is the Cinderella of medicine-not quite up to the level of its specialist sisters.

The proposal ensures that that view will no longer prevail. It gives recognition to general practice as a significant and separate area of medicine and acknowledges the efforts of general practitioners to improve their practice through vocational training at the postgraduate level. I think that, if the proposal is properly understood by those practitioners in the field, there will be a lot of allaying of the anxiety and concern that have been evidenced over the last few months in addressing this legislation.

The Committee, as I said earlier, in recommending that clause 10 be proclaimed, has asked for a rider, and that rider goes to regulations being presented in Parliament to establish what we have called the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee-known in our discussions as VREC and VRAC. It got a little strained at times understanding who was saying what about whom, but I think both of those committees, established by regulation under paragraph 3f6 (6), will allay very many of the substantive concerns that people had about this legislation.

The Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee will be established to provide registration as an alternative to a fairly automatic registration of general practitioners who have fellowship of the Royal Australian College. If general practitioners have fellowship of the college, their listing on the vocational register will be near enough to automatic, but the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee is to be established to deal with those doctors who have concerns about whether they fit the eligibility criteria, who do not have fellowship of the college or who have sundry other concerns. We have made it clear that the Eligibility Committee will be able not only to do all of those things but also to deal with complaints from doctors, for example, if they have been rejected by the college for automatic acceptance onto the register and/or if they are advised by the college to seek registration through the Committee.

I believe it will be important to canvass the details of these committees in the substantive debate on this matter so I shall not devote too much time to them now, but I believe that they deal with one of the areas of concern for general practitioners who may not fall exactly within the definition of general practice or meet the eligibility criteria as defined by the college at the moment. I could cite as an example the case brought most often into discussion, submissions or evidence-sports medicine. I believe that the establishment of the Eligibility Committee will deal with the concerns raised with us by many people perhaps just outside the clear definitions of eligibility criteria.

The other area of concern raised in this place and extensively in discussion and debate on the issue was the need for an appeals mechanism. If doctors can be put on the register and taken off the register, it seemed to the Committee, and to many of the people bringing evidence before the Committee, that an appeals mechanism was necessary. It seemed reasonable that people say, `But we want to know what it is like; we want to know how it will be constituted; we want to know exactly what its terms are and how it will be established'. The report makes that clear and I think will deal with all of the concerns raised by people about the establishment of an appeals mechanism. Both committees, as I said, are to be established by regulation under paragraph 3f (6) (b), and once those regulations are presented in parliament any remaining concerns in this area should be laid to rest.

The Committee was also very concerned-I do not think that is an overstatement-at the difficulty facing the college, the Government and the medical profession if the AMA remained outside of negotiations. We have strongly urged the AMA to return on behalf of the profession to negotiation with the Government, particularly in the area of schedule fees and rebates. I am sure the Department of Community Services and Health would welcome it, and it made that clear. The college would welcome it, and we have made that clear. The Committee would welcome it, and we have made that clear. We have in the AMA a considerable body of expertise and talent, and that is wasted for the profession and government if the AMA is not back at the negotiating table. So I hope that that recommendation of the Committee is also taken very seriously.

The report also addresses a lot of issues raised about vocational training, about continuing medical education and quality assurance and about the family medicine program. It also says that the Independent Peer Review Organisation should not proceed because many objections are raised in that area, largely, the Committee concludes, based on misunderstanding of what IPRO was about, how it was to be constituted and what it was to do. Nevertheless, in the light of the very effective campaign, either intentional or unintentional, the doubts and anxieties about IPRO are such that the Committee has recommended that it not proceed, but the Committee is very clear that a proper process for evaluation and monitoring of the new content-based descriptors, that is, the new item numbers that will be available to vocationally registered general practitioners, has to be put in place. One cannot introduce something of that importance, associating with it the prospects for improved medical practice and delivery of health care, and then not seriously discuss the question of how to evaluate and monitor that.

The Committee makes clear what we understood IPRO was to do, but we now make it beyond doubt that that evaluation and monitoring has to be done by the profession on the profession. It is not to be done by the Health Insurance Commission. Hopefully, the Department, the college and the AMA, as we recommend, will form a tripartite committee to get that process established. The principle is there. The principle is largely agreed to, but we need a discussion paper, a draft outline, and extensive consultation and discussion with the profession so that no doubt remains about, firstly, the importance of monitoring, secondly, the need and right for that to happen-which we recommend-and, thirdly, the process of how it can be properly done so the profession's concerns are satisfied. We have decided that that should be called the Descriptor Utilisation Review Committee, to put beyond doubt what it will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —DURC!

—We did have better names, Senator Puplick. Maybe we will see the honourable senator in the corridor to explain those. We can get very amusing with letters in these committees. One of the other difficulties we had in this whole peer review area was to cope with the fact that, while various sections in the community, for example, the departmental people or the professional people, use terms such as peer review quite properly, in the course of our discussions and the debate we discovered that there were slightly different meanings perhaps in the different uses of the word. We appreciate that a lot of the difficulty actually arose from an honest and genuine misunderstanding of what terms meant and how they were being used. We hope that our recommendations will lay to rest the difficulties in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that was of considerable importance, and clearly the case, was that consultation in this whole issue had been, if not insufficient, at least disparate. I think it is fair to say that it was probably not sufficient. While the college had contacted all doctors and the Minister had written to all doctors, we were given advice that not all doctors read the letters they get-amongst other reasons for why the consultation was not sufficient. This Committee had the benefit of four doctors on it. We all had a considerable sympathy-and we discovered that Senator Faulkner, from being in the Senate, had the same sort of sympathy, and, for the record, I am sure that Senator McMullan had the same sympathy-for people who are very busy professional people and who have to make a kind of selection of the sort of material they read. Letters of this sort did not seem to preoccupy them when they first got them, so perhaps that contributed to the failure to understand and follow the consultation and advice given from the earlier stages.

The Department, in its second or supplementary submission, outlined a program for consultation, and the Committee recommends that, once the section is proclaimed, that consultation process be put in place. It is quite clear that a more optimal and satisfactory outcome will occur if more people, or all the people involved, are fully informed of what it is all about. That will also prevent the opportunities for misunderstanding and the consequent anxiety that can happen.

I was interested in a particular way to notice many submissions from women doctors. I would have to say, for the record, `Thank God for the New South Wales medical women'. While my women colleagues from other sections of Australia seemed to present the argument against the clause 10 and provided a litany of reasons for that, the submission from the Medical Women's Society of New South Wales was, I suppose, more thoughtful and more reasoned and seemed to find very little objection in the proposal, except for its concerns about the aforementioned IPRO. Unlike some of the other women, its members were very strong in suggesting that women graduating as doctors should not get a lesser degree, or be treated in a lesser way so that being kind to women could actually allow for a second grade of medical practitioners or for women being assisted in postgraduate training in a way that men are not. The Committee was very encouraged by the New South Wales Medical Women's Society's submission.

In the report the Committee also addresses the objections raised by women doctors. Once they have read the report, their objections and fears should be properly allayed. We did not feel there was much serious substance to their claim, for example, that women doctors are now sought after in the community-we appreciate that that is true-but that these changes will mean that women doctors will be less employable and that, just when women have got into the medical profession in significant numbers, and just when the community is indicating they are clearly very much sought after, we have actually created a scheme under which women doctors will not be employable. I think some of that reflected a misunderstanding on the part of the people putting those views of what exactly will be the consequences of the vocational registration and the use of the new descriptors. We found no substantial evidence to support the claims that there will be two tiers of doctors creating what I think the report refers to as an unemployable under-class. I believe anxieties of the women will be allayed when they read the report.

We had considerable objections from the resident medical officers and from medical students all the way through the inquiry. I suggest that Senator Sheil would be the best person to talk about medical students, as I am sure my colleagues will agree. I see Senator Sheil appreciates the point. Again, I am sure that once the resident medical officers and medical students see the report and more fully understand what it is about they will not have the same opposition to or level of anxiety about it, although I believe we can expect that it will take some time for the amount of anxiety and misinformation to be laid to rest. Hopefully, those people who have had a concern or indicated any anxiety in this area will get a copy of the report, read it and seek any further information from the college, the Department or wherever, so as to be properly informed about the concerns they raised with the Committee.

The Committee also raised the question of proper evaluation. There is no doubt, as I have said before, that the monitoring under the Descriptor Utilisation Review Committee and in general and the evaluation of this change by measurements of the health status of the Australian community as well as any changes in the way medicine is practised by the profession are the sorts of things that need to be seriously addressed. The Committee has made recommendations about them.

We have asked the Government to respond as soon as possible because of the concerns raised by a number of people. We want regulations brought into this Parliament as soon as possible to deal with the establishment of an eligibility committee and an appeals committee so that that can be finalised and people can see that the difficulties they have raised in the past are now properly addressed.

The only other point I would like to make before closing is that there are some recommendations for funding, in particular funding for sufficient places under the family medicine program, for all doctors wanting to take up family medicine program vocational training prior to their registration. The Department in its submission indicated that it fully understood that that would be necessary and it indicated its commitment to the proposal and a commitment to provide adequate funding for that to happen. As I have said, we also appreciate the Department's promise to provide an extensive information education campaign. I believe that we have had from the college its commitment of preparedness to contribute by informing and educating doctors as to the details of the proposal and assisting in any other way. I note that the AMA also indicated in its hearings a willingness to contribute. I really look forward to that.

Issues of concern are raised under the heading of rural doctors and there are concerns about the Health Insurance Commission. I have not canvassed those today. I note that I have run over the time that I was supposed to have allotted myself and apologise to my colleagues for that. When one considers the issues before the Committee and its terms of reference, I think that, notwithstanding the time constraints, we have before us a good report. It is a unanimous report. I think that that demonstrates not only the cooperation and collaboration of the senators involved, but also the comprehensive and satisfactory way in which the issues have been canvassed and resolved. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to support the motion moved by Senator Crowley. Senate committees, it must be said, are of variable quality in terms of their functioning, the capacity and dedication of the senators themselves, the skills of the secretariat and so on. The subjects which the committees undertake to study also vary in importance. Some of us in this place have reached the stage where we can see those variations. We can remember good committees and bad committees, good reports and bad reports. We can see some of the unevenness. Some of us simply will not waste our time and effort if the committee is not worth it. In short, some of us try to concentrate our effort on what is important. We try to avoid committees which offer nothing more than occupational therapy for underutilised parliamentarians. We try to concentrate on what committees can address with advantage and we try to concentrate on committees which are well served in their membership and administrative support. I would say that the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance has passed all the tests which a critical senator might wish to make of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Select Committee is addressing a subject of importance. One measure of that is the number of submissions it received, as Senator Crowley mentioned. Honourable senators will recall that the Committee was formed in a hurry following the completion of a debate in June and was given 15 August, yesterday, as the date on which it had to present its report. It was able to offer only a brief period to the public in which the public could make submissions. Nevertheless, it received more than 200 submissions, while each member of the Committee received many inputs either personally, through the mail or by telephone, the subject for the first part of the reference-that is, vocational registration of general practitioners and the Government's proposal contained in clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill-was, in fact, a reference which attracted lively interest.

Secondly the six senators who served on the Committee brought to the task some useful backgrounds and skills. I remind honourable senators that the six consisted of four medically qualified persons-the gang of four, according to the medical press-and the two others who were highly qualified in political administration. That was not unhelpful to the Committee in its work. Thirdly, the secretariat support was excellent. I congratulate Derek Abbott, Barry Jenkins, Laurie Swift and Christine McDonald on their contributions. I thank them for the way they made this committee exercise, conducted in such a short time frame, proceed so well. The exercise reflects great credit upon them personally and the Senate Committee secretariat in which they work.

But what of the reference itself? What of the problem we addressed, the process we undertook and the solutions we have proposed? The reference was to examine the particular proposal of the Government for vocational registration of general practitioners. It was to do that job within eight weeks and to recommend to the Senate how it might care to proceed from there. Honourable senators will recall that the Committee has a second reference, a wider examination of health insurance, to which it will turn next and on which it will report some time early in 1990. The Committee members determined that for this first part of the reference the goal was to try to solve the problems and try to resolve the conflicts. The goal was to try to find a solution, which could be fair to all, to overcome deficiencies in the substance and in the appearance of the Government proposal. It determined to recommend action to the Senate which could then allow the Senate to endorse the proposal after it received certain Government assurances and saw some further details of Government proposed regulations.

The Committee faced several problems. First, there was great angst that one medical body had apparently usurped the role of another. The story there is long and unsavoury and little value will accrue if the whole saga is laid out for the Senate. But it has been possible to recommend-and Senator Crowley has referred to this already-that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) should return as soon as possible to its traditional role as negotiator for the medical profession with government on the matter of rebate levels and on other industrial matters. That is its traditional role and it should get back to that role quickly. It is my hope as a longstanding AMA member that it will so return. We were told in evidence that the processes necessary for this to happen were already under way.

There was concern that the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) in pursuing the commendable goal of improving the quality, of raising standards, of recognising and certifying training, had moved to areas which were not properly its to administer or to undertake. I think I speak for the Committee when I say that the College should remain a certifying body like the other royal medical college; that is, it should award its diploma to those who meet certain academic and practical criteria. If the government of the day wishes to accredit people with that diploma to receive higher rebates, that is a prerogative of government.

What the Committee determined and what I hope the Senate will confirm is that the College should not exercise certain other roles which were given to it in the original proposal. That is the key, the central part, of our recommendations. The College should not negotiate with governments rebates for fees. We believe that that is a job which the AMA could do and should do. The College will not need to undertake this role if the AMA returns to its traditional role as we have asked. The College should not undertake the registration of vocationally qualified practitioners. That is why we have proposed a separate vocational registration eligibility committee (VREC) to do the job of registration. We believe that this committee should accept the College fellowship as adequate for registration but we also expect that the committee will consider and accept other qualifications and other evidence of vocational expertise as well. With the vocational registration eligibility committee operating and separate from the College-visibly separate from the College with its membership separate-the anomalies which exist, including the position of sports medicine, the position of certain family planning practitioners, the special position of medical women and so on, can be assessed and addressed.

Further, on the question of continuing medical education, the VREC and the appeal committee that goes with it can assist practitioners whose continuing medical education activities might not satisfy the College. I think Senator Crowley has already said that if someone were to be removed from the register for failure to maintain enough continuing medical education that person should have a right of appeal to the committee, which we have proposed. Again, this would be a committee separate from the College which can provide an independent view and which is seen to be independent. We see these committees-the vocational registration eligibility committee and the vocational registration appeal committee-as being constituted in much the same way as are the equivalent committees for consultants and specialists which now exist. We think these committees are constituted in a way which is appropriate.

Next, in considering the role of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, we think that when it comes to appeals against decisions relating to failure to grant or maintain vocational registration that should not be a function of the RACGP. That is why we recommended the appeals committee-the VRAC-whose constitution we have also laid out, one which would make it independent of the college itself and one which would operate independently of the college. Of course, in line with the situation that exists with the other specialist recognition committees, the ones that exist already, the College of General Practitioners would have a representative on the two committees which we have proposed.

The other major cause of angst was a proposal for an IPRO, an Independent Peer Review Organisation-that is what the Government called it-to carry out what was called by the Government peer review. It has become clear that this problem was one largely of the choice of language by the Government. Peer review has a specific meaning to doctors and it had a specific meaning to me as a doctor. It means review of the professional activities of doctors by their peers. It has a specific meaning and the doctors who are trying to assess the Government's proposals understood that traditional meaning. They thought this was what the Government intended to do. Of course it is not so. The Department has assured us that this is not so.

What the Government has in mind is a quite different matter. It is the review of the utilisation of the new descriptor items on which rebates will be based. In other words, it wants to be sure that people are not cheating; that in fact doctors are not claiming improperly under the new descriptors for rebates for their patients.

So the intention of the Government in fact is to monitor the way in which practitioners generate Bills on which rebates can be paid. If that is what they mean, the term peer review is not appropriate if we are talking to a population of doctors. This put a completely different light on the whole exercise and the Senate Select Committee has been able to make recommendations for the form of utilisation review which is desired by the Government. We have been able to make recommendations which now, without any difficulty, accept the proper role of the Health Insurance Commission in such a process. After all it does have a role if we are looking at the utilisation of items on which rebates can be paid. It is impossible for this Committee to ask that the IPRO, as proposed by the Government, not proceed. It is our hope that the Government will accept that and that it will establish the alternative mechanism which we have proposed which is a Descriptor Utilisation Review Committee. If that is what the Government intends to establish let it say so.

Another vexed question was the capacity that existed under proposed clause 3 (h) for the Minister to replace the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners by any other body he chose. We are assured that that provision was there in case the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners changed its name or some other event occurred. That is not unreasonable. But it gave rise to the possible interpretation by those reading the Bill that it might allow the Minister one day to come in and say, `I have finished with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. I am now going to give the job to the Clerk of the Senate', or someone else; anyone he may wish to name to take the place. This caused some heartburning-not that Mr Evans would not be a perfectly proper person to do the job. But in order that there should be no misunderstanding on this matter the Committee has recommended that any such determination which the Minister may care to make under clause 3 (h) should itself be subject to parliamentary scrutiny as if it were subordinate legislation. It should have the same status as a regulation. For that to happen it will be necessary for the Government to amend, or certainly in the short term to promise to amend, that section of the Act.

Finally, I remind honourable senators of what should be apparent to us all. The Government package will be finalised only when we see and when we can assess and evaluate the draft regulations to be made under the various proposed sections. These regulations will have to provide, for instance, for the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee, the Vocational Registration Appeal Committee and probably for the Descriptor Utilisation Review Committee. The Select Committee recommends unanimously to the Senate that we defer any final Senate action, that is, the positive Senate motion required by the Senate resolution of 15 June, until after the Government has tabled draft regulations and until after the Government has given, publicly, certain assurance about its intention to enact a necessary amendment to clause 3H at an early date.

I remind honourable senators that the recommendation as it appears might not give honourable senators that impression, because it recommends that the section be proclaimed after the Government has given certain assurances. What the Committee really means is that only after the Government has done certain things-produced regulations and promised to amend clause 3H-should the Senate proceed to pass the positive resolution which is required in this matter.

Mr Acting Deputy President, this has been an example of a Senate committee working towards the solution of a problem. Senator Chaney used to tell me that there were two kinds of people: warriors and healers. I think there were some warriors on the Committee, but on this occasion they actually tried to function as healers. They tried to work towards a solution, and find some common ground on this matter that was raised in relation to the Government's legislation, to develop a formula and to satisfy the needs of most of the protagonists. Our formula will work; it will meet the essential needs of all parties; it will allow for the recognition of those with special skills; it will protect the rights of any medical practitioner who wishes to become recognised and who wishes to remain recognised and who fears that the College may not give him or her a fair go. It recognises the proper role of the Health Insurance Commission in monitoring utilisation. The Committee's report seeks protections in substantive and subordinate legislation against certain inequitable consequences that frightened some of our witnesses and some of the associations which they represent. It is our hope that the Government will adopt the proposal and that the Senate will then see fit in due course to complete its part of the process so that the scheme can begin to operate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reflecting on the words of the previous two speakers, I also would like to point out that this reference to the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance regarding the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill arose out of an extremely divisive action by the Government which was poorly explained both to general practitioners and to medical students intending to enter medical practice. I cannot recall in my brief time in the Senate, just over two years now, any matter which has occasioned such an intensity of correspondence. If I add the number of signatures on petitions which I received, some 4,000 or more people communicated with me in regard to this Bill in the space of several weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point with which I think one needs to preface remarks dealing specifically with the Committee's report is that the matter is important, as it deals with the quality of the delivery of health services to the Australian community by general practitioners. That is very important. I think that every member of the Committee, and indeed most of those who appeared before the Committee, accepted that the Government's intention in this respect was completely honourable in that it was seeking to guarantee a higher standard in the delivery of general practice services to the community and that those services be maintained through continuing medical education and quality assurance.

One had an interesting situation in that the intention was honourable and could be seen to be objectively desirable, but the manner in which the Government had chosen to present it to the community was inadequate and certainly inadequately explained. That occasioned an enormous division right through the middle of the medical profession. As the two previous speakers have pointed out, the Committee has nonetheless, in a very intense period of discussion and debate, come to a consensus on our report. We believe that we have been able to deliver a set of proposals which satisfies both sides in this debate and will-picking up Senator Peter Baume's words a few moments ago-heal this rift within the medical profession.

The Committee sat for a very brief time and its work was very intense. I also would like to thank those who served the Committee in the secretariat. They performed extremely well. A large number of submissions-well over 200-came in in a very short time. There were a number of intense sitting days. The report, which has been distilled, is excellent. It is clear, brief, to the point and I believe that it will satisfy most of those who have considered the question on both sides.

Some eight matters were contentious and required clarification. I will run through them briefly. I have already alluded to the first; that is, the lack of clarity in the proposal as presented originally. Clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill was extremely brief. Much of what was being proposed was really in the form of draft documents which had passed between the Department and the college. Firstly, they were not widely available and, secondly, they were a moving feast as it were.

We had evidence from the college on basic and fundamental matters such as the definition of general practice. Its position seemed to move as we probed and questioned the college in relation to what it understood to be general practice. I am not in these remarks reflecting in any way on the integrity of the college or suggesting that the college was being deceitful. On the contrary, the college was attempting to be helpful in terms of those who saw difficulties in the way of being registered under what appeared originally to be a fairly restrictive definition of general practice. Nonetheless, looked at objectively, the proposals were not really helpful until they were set down in a form of words to which both the Department and the college had agreed and made available to those affected, namely, those in general practice, who will be seeking registration, and those medical students intending to go on and enter general practice.

Accordingly, dealing with that specific and very serious problem which was perceived by a large number of doctors and medical students, the Committee has recommended that the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill be proclaimed only after the draft regulations proposed under sections 3f and 3g to establish the proposed VREC and VRAC that is, the Vocational Registration Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee-have been presented to Parliament. In other words, we are saying that the whole of the proposal must be on the table before the matter is then passed by the Senate. That, I believe, will substantially allay the fears which have been raised in relation to seeing only a small portion of the package.

The next matter was raised by a number of witnesses and in a number of letters. There were clearly a number of areas which ran the risk of falling outside the definition of general practice. In other words, people would not be judged as general practitioners, would therefore not be able to get registration, would not be able to charge higher fees and would not be able to have their patients get rebates at the higher rate. A number of the women doctor witnesses who came before us expressed the concern that many women doctors particularly deal with the areas of family medicine, family planning and sexually transmitted diseases.

The other major area of concern was sports medicine. These people may have been in general practice and delivering a quality service as general practitioners. In every other respect they would be eligible for registration, but because they moved to an area where their practice was not substantially any longer general practice they would not remain eligible. Nonetheless, they were still satisfying the criterion which seems to be uppermost in the mind of the Government, that is, the quality of the delivery of service. These people had engaged in vocational training in their subspeciality, had very often participated in continuing medical education and, of course, the other qualities required could be assured.

In addressing that problem, the Committee has suggested two separate proposals. They have already been outlined by Senators Crowley and Baume. The establishment of VREC will enable the qualifications of those people who do not easily fit within the college parameters to be looked at. In looking at those people the Committee will be able to say, `Yes, they fit within general practice, and they can get registration as general practitioners under that criterion'. Although the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners will have one member on that recommended VREC, it would not be a dominant force on the Committee.

We have also recommended that the Department investigate the ability to recognise those doctors who clearly fall outside general practice, however that is defined, but still fall within the characteristics of being vocationally trained, delivering quality service and participating in continuing medical education. Such a mechanism would then pick up those few practitioners who may well fall outside the area of general practice completely but who still could obtain registration and the use of, perhaps, some additional item numbers under the Medicare schedule. That recommendation picks up those people.

Concern was expressed about the adequacy of fees in general practice and the use of the descriptors. The Committee has picked up that point and reflects on the evidence given by one witness that one of the highest indicators of the quality of general practice was the length of the consultation. The length of the consultation under the existing rebate system is largely determined by the fee structure. So we are recommending that that matter also be addressed.

The next item related to the lack of appeal provisions within the original proposal. Again the Committee has recommended that, in addition to the establishment of the VREC, there be established a vocational registration appeals committee drawn from the same bodies but composed of different people. So it will be an independent committee which can review the recommendations of the college in relation to the acceptance of somebody seeking registration for the first time or in relation to an appeal against the VREC for somebody who does not fall easily within the college qualifications and who is seeking registration for the first time or for somebody who has been registered and who is threatened with the removal of his or her name from the register. Such persons can also use that appeal provision. Again, I believe that the Committee has adequately dealt with that matter of appeal.

Concern was also expressed as to the length of training required, bearing in mind that doctors are already involved in a six-year university training scheme plus one compulsory hospital year afterwards. It is seven years before they can go into general practice. If the length of training required for entry into general practice were excessive, particularly for those in part time training, then the time before they could go into unsupervised medical practice may be so long that it may discourage people from going into medicine altogether. The Committee has recommended that the length of training be investigated and that for those who wish to engage in more intensive training consideration be given to having that training period shortened, particularly in the light of the suggestion that a second hospital year may be involved as part of that training.

Concern was also expressed by a number of witnesses that the family medicine program as presently constituted is, in some cases, delivering unsatisfactory educational opportunities for some doctors entering the program, that some of the supervision is inadequate and that, if this proposal were adopted by the Government, there would be a need to expand the family medicine program. The Committee has accepted that there would be a need to expand the family medicine program to make it as flexible as possible to meet the special needs of those going into these subspecialities, to meet the needs of country doctors who need somewhat different training from those who go into an urban practice, where there may be little or no obstetrics and little or no anaesthetics given, quite contrary to the experience in the country. The Committee has recommended that more funding be provided for the family medicine program and that it be adequate to meet the needs of the expanded program.

The matter of evaluation emerged very strongly in my mind because, in questioning a number of the witnesses as to the adequacy of general practice in Australia, either objectively as assessed within Australia or comparatively as assessed between Australia and other countries, extremely slim research evidence was available as to whether we had a good or a poor service and, indeed, what changes needed to be made to improve that service. Considering that the health budget is one of the largest components of the total Budget, it is to be decried in the extreme that so little evaluation of our health care system has been carried out. The Committee has accordingly recommended that, within the family medicine program and within general practice as a whole, funding be set aside so that proper evaluation protocols can be set up now, that we can get comparative data now, so that we can see five or six years down the track whether this proposal is working, which parts of it are working well and which parts need to be changed. It is only in that way that we will be able progressively to modify general practice and really deliver to the Australian public the hope which the Government has expressed, namely, a better quality of general practice. That matter is a very important one which perhaps did not receive a great deal of attention from the Committee. I lay great emphasis on that and express the strong hope that the Government will take it up and make proper funding available for evaluation.

Finally-this is a matter which has already been mentioned-there was the vexatious question of peer review. Senator Peter Baume mentioned that at some length and pointed out that the word `peer' and the words `peer review' were used in a different context by Government and by the profession. I believe the Committee has adequately sorted that out. The Government is clearly keen to see reviewed the appropriate and consistent use of descriptors across the widest range of general practice. Appropriately, the Committee has recommended that the Independent Peer Review Organisation, as originally proposed, not be proceeded with but that, alternatively, a descriptor utilisation review committee be established. It would take on that much narrower a role. The review would be carried out by professional people-it would not involve non-professionals looking over the shoulder of doctors-and would be oriented towards uniformity in the use of those descriptors.

So those eight areas which evinced enormous concern from the medical profession-as I indicated earlier, their letters represented the largest number of letters in the shortest possible time I have ever received, covering substantially eight areas of concern-have all been addressed by this Committee. There is a uniformity of support for the Committee's report. If the Government proceeds on the basis of that report, and particularly if the draft regulations come forward on these clauses of the Bill so that everybody can see what is proposed and be satisfied that it deals with their concerns, not only will the concerns of the medical profession be allayed but the substance of their concerns will be adequately addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give my appreciation of the operation of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance. It was handed a monumental task to evaluate just what clause 10 of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill meant. The task entailed an awful lot of work, given the myriad of submissions that came in, many of them aggressive and hostile-and rightly so, given the time that they occurred. I also give my congratulations to the secretariat of the Committee. It did a tremendous job of sorting everything out and bringing all the threads together to present to the Committee so that we could make a proper appraisal. Derek Abbott and Barry Jenkins, Laurie Swift and Christine McDonald must have been doing callisthenics for tired eyeballs after reading all the submissions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak for a little on the origins of clause 10 in the legislation. Honourable senators will probably remember that at that time general practitioners' incomes were low and their morale had been sapped, probably because of the delays in negotiations with the Government on increasing the rebates. The Government had taken some unilateral actions, for example, cutting out an item number for out-of-hours services, which had a detrimental effect on the income of general practitioners. Because of actions by the Government the AMA withdrew from negotiations. The Association has been treated as if it broke off the negotiations unilaterally and without cause, but there was cause for it to lose confidence in negotiating with the Government not only because of the delays but also because of the actions of the Government.

Honourable senators will remember that at the same time as this happened the Government was taking action with regard to pharmaceutical benefits. These had been slashed in one area and have since been reinstated. The pharmacists' remuneration had been reduced and they had to take the Government to court. They won their court battle. The pathology services were under attack. In fact, pathology service rebates had been virtually cut in half. This also resulted in court action and there has been a reinstatement of those pathology rebates. In other words, it was an era of turmoil for the health industry.

The Government, as it turned out, was loath to raise the general practitioner (GP) rebates unless it got a return through better and more cost effective medical services. Because it did not have anyone to negotiate with and the executive of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) was willing to go on negotiating, negotiations took place there for some months unbeknown to the rest of the medical profession, and then it became an overt operation. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners was anxious to be the body that was responsible for the accreditation of doctors in order that they could be placed on the vocational register. Because the Government used this instrument-the executive of the RACGP-this resulted in a split in the medical profession. That split exists to this day because a lot of the doctors feel that a minority of the RACGP has carried out these negotiations, initially in secret and subsequently more openly. When they became more open there was a confused interpretation of just what was meant by the agreement.

The Government, in wanting its more cost effective application of general practitioners, was interested in about four main areas. It wanted to be sure that GPs did not prescribe more medications than they needed to; it wanted to be sure that doctors were aware of the cost of the medications they prescribed and that if they could reduce their prescriptions of high cost medicines that would help the Budget; it wanted to be sure that GPs did sufficient of their medical consultations that they did not have to refer patients to specialists as often as they had been perhaps in the past. That is understandable from the quality of the medical education lately and I will deal with that a little later. The Government wanted to prevent doctors referring cases to specialists in more cases than were absolutely necessary.

In order to improve the quality in those main areas the Government felt that it could use the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners through the vocational register, through continuing medical education, through peer review, practice audits and the other mechanisms mentioned in clause 10. The RACGP, I might add, is perhaps one of the less democratic organisations in Australia. It was instituted as an academic body. In fact, it specifically wrote into its constitution that it would never take political action. There is probably a movement within the RACGP at the moment to challenge its executive about coming to an agreement with the Government over the vocational register of general practitioners. That is an issue that I suppose will have to be supported out amongst the members of the college itself. I do not know what effect it will have on the legislation but it could mean that a lot of doctors will just refuse to go on the register, which, of course, is their right.

There are in Australia approximately 16,000 general practitioners and fewer than half of that number are members of the RACGP. It is fair to say that the vocational registration proposal was half-baked when it was presented in legislation to the Senate. I am sure that it was the half-baked nature of the proposal that led to this outcry from the medical profession. Because that proposal was ill explained and misunderstood, I think the misunderstandings and the reaction were quite understandable. A lot of those misunderstandings still exist. One of the recommendations of the Committee is that the Government have a massive publicity campaign to explain just what is meant by clause 10 before and after its implementation.

From its inception, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners has been interested in the status and prestige of its members. To that end, it instituted the family medicine program which, since its inception, has been largely funded by the Federal Government. The program consumes approximately $9m a year and that money is now built into the economic structure of the College. The RACGP is happy to use that program in its move towards becoming the accrediting body for vocational registration of general practitioners.

During the course of the Committee's deliberations it became obvious that the RACGP was willing to bend over backwards in order to help general practitioners achieve vocational registration. For example, I do not think sufficient thought had been given initially by the college to all those areas of general practice that do not come under the banner of ordinary general practice-for example, industrial medicine, womens medicine, sport medicine, sex counselling clinics and medico-legal practices. General practitioners were practising in a whole series of areas in specialised fields that could not be classified as general practice. So the Committee and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners had to turn their minds to finding some sort of common ground to enable all those different areas to be accommodated and I think we have done that.

I was quite horrified to hear the disclosures that were made to the Committee in respect of medical education. Apparently some 20 years ago the deans of the medical colleges got together and, instead of producing mainly general practitioners, which had been their aim since time immemorial, they decided to produce a thing called the non-differentiated doctor. They got to work on that. The undifferentiated doctor was able to gain only provisional registration if he worked in a public hospital for a couple of years. Having done that he could undergo further education for four, five or six years and enter whatever field of medicine he liked. It turned out that all the procedures were being removed from medical education up to and including a student's intern years in a hospital. We found that there were young students and doctors who had not stitched a wound, set a minor fracture, delivered a baby or done all of the ordinary everyday procedures that one would expect that they should be able to do.

However, 10 years ago a number of the deans of the faculties decided to change back to producing general practitioners, so now in Australia we have a hodgepodge picture of just what types of graduates we are producing. The Committee has made recommendations to the medical education bodies in the hope of resolving that issue. I hope that we can go back to producing some proper general practioners and also reinstate general practitioners' privileges in hospitals which have been denied them lately. In fact, general practitioners have hardly 10 patients in hospital. Medicine has an enormous specialist orientation now, which increases the cost and it is not warranted.

In effect, the Committee has separated all the functions of all the bodies that will administer clause 10. The RACGP has been given its job to do. We have requested that the AMA come back to the fold and start negotiating again, despite its experiences. Everybody has to be careful negotiating with government. The Health Insurance Commission has been given its job, which is to keep the register, and the Department has been given its job. The two proposed new committees, VREC and VRAC-the Vocational Registration and Eligibility Committee and the Vocational Registration Appeals Committee-are bodies which we have seen to be capable of oversighting the accreditation of doctors in order to get on to the vocational register.

If the Government is prepared to accept the Committee's recommendations, I think that many of the problems will be resolved. One that was mentioned in this morning's debate was the difficulty with the interpretation of the Independent Peer Review Organisation as compared with the doctors' interpretation of what peer review meant. That has been sorted out. Obviously the Government intended to monitor the costs of the use of its new descriptor items and the doctors referred to the quality of the care. Those two issues have been resolved and the roles of the Government and the profession have been separated. If the Government is prepared to accept that type of recommendation, I am sure the Senate would be happy with it. It now remains for the Government to act fairly quickly and say whether it does, or does not, accept the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee and get to work and put forward its regulations so that if the legislation is to come into operation, it can have the blessing of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been stated-I am not being critical of the fact-the body of the Senate does not have a copy of the report because of time delays in the printing of the report. The Committee has had a very short time in which to get the report together. All we have are the conclusions and recommendations. As I have not had an opportunity to read the report, my comments will be on just the recommendations and conclusions that I have before me. I do not have any in depth information from the Committee on which I can base my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: All members of the Committee have stated that there was great concern in the community. Senator Sheil said that there was not only great concern but also anger among the medical profession. I can understand that because over the period the Government has been in power we have had a whole heap of doctor bashing. We only have to remember back to when the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, came out saying that the medical profession was ripping off the public in cases of fraud and overservicing to the tune of $120m. At that time the Minister was preparing the community for the Government's cutting down of the medical profession.

That situation occurs in many instances. Indeed, Hitler used to use the same method. Whenever he was going to get stuck into a certain group of people he would prepare the constituency he had at that time in exactly the same way. He would do a lot of bashing of a particular group. Those of us who remember his tactics with the Jewish community know that he spent a considerable amount of time telling people what dreadful people the Jews were before he actually took action against them. This Minister, Neal Blewett, does exactly the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. We could let that run but I think it is against the good order of this chamber to suggest that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) is acting in the way Hitler did against the Jews. I suggest that the honourable senator be asked to withdraw that inference.

—It is the case that it would be unparliamentary to impute directly to a member of the other place such gross motives, as has been well acknowledged, as those of Hitler. I do not think Senator Walters directly made that imputation, and with that assurance from her I ask her to continue.

—I was saying that the same action has been taken. Indeed, we had the situation in which Neal Blewett was preparing the community for the amount of doctor bashing he was about to do and he really got stuck into the doctors and said that-I remember the figure very clearly-$120m was the estimate of the amount of fraud committed by the doctors. I quote from a letter that the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission sent to the Australian Medical Association (AMA). It said:

SPEECH.PARA: As you have said, the estimate prepared by the Department was $120m and this figure was later discredited.

So that claim was certainly laid to rest. We had a situation a little later when the pathologists were to be cut down. It was the same old thing. I will read from one of the press reports, which states:
There was no real evidence that the increasing cost of medical benefits for pathology services was due to fraud and overservicing . . .

And of course that again was discredited. The Government did exactly the same thing this month, on 11 August. The chemists were attacked. The chemists are now being prepared for attack in exactly the same way, and the Government is coming out and saying very publicly how the chemists are ripping us off on prescriptions. We have exactly the same wording:

While we have no hard evidence on the extent of the problem, we estimate that there are between 20 and 25 million general prescriptions per year priced under $11, so potentially we are talking about $25 to $50m [overcharging] if all of them are charging an extra dollar or two.

That of course was said by a principal adviser in the pharmaceutical benefits section of the Department. We have all become used to this Government, when ready to attack a certain section of the professions, first preparing the ground very well and coming out with all these extravagant suggestions and estimates that eventually are discredited. In the meantime, it does a tremendous amount of professional bashing. Is it any wonder that there was a lot of concern and a lot of anger in the community?

The Committee's report, as I see it, has at least vindicated the concerns that the Opposition had during the debate. I spoke about five main points where the legislation was defective, and they have been dealt with in the Committee's report. First of all, with the lack of provision for appeal, the Committee has recommended that a system of appeal, both for general practitioners going onto the vocational register and for those who are removed from the vocational register, be set up. I am pleased to see that this is so. The Committee has recommended that an independent committee be set up and that that committee have among its membership a member of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, a member of the Australian Medical Association, a member of the Australian Medical Council, and a member of the National Specialist Qualification Advisory Committee, and that the Minister nominate a member who is suitably medically qualified and experienced. A five-member committee of appeal, I believe, is very good.

The Committee also recommended that there be an eligibility committee set up under the regulations. We have to remember that there were two methods of doctors being put on the vocational register: either through their appeal to the college and the college giving them the okay or through regulations. We will also remember that, at the time of the debate, there were no regulations that we were able to view and, therefore, there was no method of us knowing what eligibility was available under the regulations. The Committee has suggested that there be an eligibility committee set up with the same people on it-not the same individuals, but the same representation. Indeed, the Committee stipulated that they not be the same people, but that there be a member of the college, a member of the AMA, a member of the Australian Medical Council and a member of the National Specialist Qualification Advisory Committee, and, again, I gather, a fifth member who is suitably medically qualified to be nominated by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that's the specialist recognition model we have used.

—Yes. It seems to me that the Committee has certainly dealt with two of the concerns that I had-that there was no provision for appeal for those going on and no appeal for those going off. It has also recommended that the draft regulations, which we had not seen during the previous debate, be brought forward by the Government before the Bill is proclaimed. That, I believe, is essential. If we are going to have eligibility criteria through the college, the Senate must know the eligibility criteria under the regulations. So the need for the regulations to be presented to the Senate before the proclamation of this clause of the Bill is most important.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern relates to clause 3h. Clause 3h in the Bill enabled the Minister at some future time to say that he would not use the college for eligibility, that he would use another body-any body he chose-and it would, indeed, become the arbitrator of whether or not the general practitioner would go on the vocational register; that he would not have to refer back to the Parliament; and that all he would do would be, by notice published in the Gazette, to determine who should be on such a committee.

It must be understood that that is very clearly the first step in a preferred provider scheme. The Government would be able to bring in the preferred provider scheme with no reference to the Parliament at all, just by placing a notice in the Gazette. Of course we could not possibly have passed legislation in that way. I am sure that the Government knew that when it put forward the legislation. I am sure that the Government realised that the shoddy legislation it put before us was not able to be passed by the Senate. I am at a complete loss to understand why it put forward such shoddy legislation unless it just wanted to defer payment of the extra increase in the schedules.

The Committee has handled the matter in this way. It has said that clause 3H is not correct, that it must be set out very clearly. If the Minister decides to alter the college as a reference, then he has to come back to the Parliament and it should be done by regulation rather than just by placing a notice in the Gazette. I agree entirely. I am not happy that the Committee has said that that should be done as soon as possible. The Committee has said that it would be happy to have the legislation proclaimed once the Government has done two things: firstly, after the draft regulations providing for the committee for appeals and the committee for eligibility are put forward, and, secondly, after the Government has indicated publicly that at the earliest possible opportunity clause 3H will be amended to require the Minister to exercise his powers under that section by regulation, not by determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, we have to pass a motion here at that stage.

—That is right; that will give the Parliament the right either to reject it or to accept it. But that is not the normal way to go about things. If the Government is prepared, at the earliest possible opportunity, to make that amendment, I do not see why we do not move in this place an amendment to the whole clause. We can bring in the appeals mechanism by amendment; we can amend clause 3H, which will require the Minister to exercise his powers by regulation rather than by determination in the Gazette. It is not a great problem to redraft amendments. It can be done in one day. The Committee has said that this would delay the legislation, that it would take time. It depends on the determination of the Government whether it takes one day or six months. I am not particularly happy with the fact that the Committee is prepared to accept all these alterations by way of regulation rather than by amendment of the legislation-by doing it in the proper fashion. But I guess we can talk about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also not very happy with the fact that no guidelines had been suggested in the legislation. The Committee has now dealt with that matter in a recommendation. It has said that the college, after negotiating with other professional organisations, should produce clear guidelines regarding credit towards vocational registration that will be offered for study and experience gained outside the family medical program. That has covered my main areas of concern. The Committee also recommended that the proposed Independent Peer Review Organisation not be proceeded with but that the new descriptors be properly monitored and evaluated.

We come then to the adequate funding for all that to be carried out, but perhaps more important is the evaluation that the Committee recommended. With Senator Peter Baume on that Committee, I know that that would have been of some priority. I congratulate him for making sure that the evaluation of the whole vocational register should be undertaken and that the Commonwealth provide adequate funding to enable this evaluation to be carried out. We can set up a register such as that suggested in this legislation and it could do nothing or it could do a lot. Unless we monitor it and unless we have an evaluation, and a proper evaluation, of how it is working, a lot of time, energy and money could be wasted. As usual, Senator Baume has demanded that a proper evaluation be undertaken to make sure that the legislation is carried out in a proper fashion and that its aims are indeed reached.

Another suggestion by the Committee is that the college should revert to its proper role of arbitrator of professional standards and that it should withdraw from other political negotiations. The Committee underlines that, if this is done, it is necessary for the AMA to re-enter the arena as principal negotiator for the profession, and recommends that the Government invite the AMA to be involved in consultations about the implementation of the recommendations of this report. I sincerely hope that the AMA does take that up again. I know that at one stage, because the AMA was unable to negotiate further with the Government, it chose to say, `Well, that's it. We cannot go ahead. It is an impossible situation. The Government will not give an inch', and it walked out. I sincerely hope that the AMA will take that up again. It is very necessary, because I think the legislation proved that the college, with the best intentions in the world, is not up to negotiating with the Government, and I think it is essential that the AMA come forward and again react in this way.

I congratulate the Committee on its report. I hope that the Government will respond to it very quickly, because at the moment Dr Blewett has said that there will be no increases in the schedule fee because the legislation has not gone through. That, of course, was totally unnecessary. The increases could have taken place and should have taken place. I hope that the Government does now respond to the Committee's report very rapidly because it must be recognised that during the recess the Committee and the secretariat worked extremely hard and have come forward with the report on the day that they said they would.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate)-by leave-proposed:
(1) That the Senate take note of the recommendations of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, and the 3rd and 4th Reports of the Procedure Committee for the 63rd Session.
(2) That further consideration of the recommendations and the reports be an order of the day for the first sitting day in December 1989.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the subject of the Select Committee on Legislative Procedures of which I was a member, and not on the Standing Orders report, which is a separate issue. The first thing I want to deal with is what the Committee was trying to do and what our terms of reference were. It is worth reading them. The first term of reference was to report to the Senate on the referral of Bills introduced in the Senate to committees for examination of the provisions of the Bill. The second term of reference was the allocation of one day each sitting week for meetings of committees to consider Bills. The third term of reference was the avoidance of an excessive concentration of Bills to be dealt with towards the end of the session and, finally, the Committee was to deal with any proposed changes to procedures to facilitate the referral of Bills to committees and to expedite the Senate consideration of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important subject. Responsible government has changed enormously over the last century, primarily because of the power and discipline of party organisations. The result has been that the House of Representatives is no longer a legislature and cannot be a legislature. The Government can and does get any legislation it chooses through the House of Representatives without any serious debate and certainly without any alteration. The House of Representatives fulfils a useful role; it is an electoral college that decides who the government is going to be. It is a public forum for discussing the shortcomings of the government and campaigning for the next election. But a legislature it is not. It cannot be.

If government legislation is going to be examined by an elected body it must be done by the Senate. No-one else can do it. The crucial feature in that role is that the Senate is not and will not be in the future controlled by the government. Only a body not controlled by the government, party discipline being what it is, can act as an effective legislature, critically examining legislation. That change to the whole nature of responsible government, which has happened over the last hundred years or so, is very important. Even so, we have to consider why, if that is our role, we cannot do it ourselves in the chamber, why we have to suggest that some Bills would benefit by being referred to committees.

Committees have many advantages. The first is that they can summon expert witnesses, hear them, discuss with them and argue with them. Any amendments that are going to be proposed can be carefully drafted, discussed with experts and debated by the committee before they are finalised. I think some honourable senators will remember complex issues like copyright and patents Acts which were amended-I think usefully amended-on the run. That sort of amendment would be much better done in a committee and proposed to the Senate as a whole, than done on the run in the Committee of the Whole without immediate access to expert witnesses. Committees have a very valuable role there.

A possible area of criticism of committees may be that they will be split on party lines. In my experience, that has not been the case. When a committee, which normally comprises three government senators and three non-government senators, meets to consider a particular problem, I have always found that there is a very general desire to get the right answers to the questions and the committee reports are normally unanimous. Even when there are dissenting reports, the issues are brought out and can be seriously discussed, with great benefit, by the Senate as a whole. They will benefit from committee consideration.

Perhaps a good example of the value of a committee is what we have been doing this morning-discussing one of the clauses of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill concerning the future of general practitioners.
