I cannot imagine that a useful debate could have been held in this chamber without the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Insurance Legislation having looked at the matter first. Its recommendations are valuable and if and when we do debate them in the chamber the debate will be much better as a result of those Committee considerations.

We have had suitable committees since 1970-the legislative and general purpose committees-but they have, historically, been far more concerned with their general purpose activities, their inquiries, than they have been with legislation. The increased use of them for legislation is, I think, the next logical step in their development. The Committee has accordingly recommended as its first recommendation that more Bills should be referred to committees. The question is how you select these `more Bills'.

The second recommendation of the Committee is that there should be a selection of Bills committee to examine all Bills introduced into the Senate and recommend which of them would benefit from being referred to a particular committee. Because of the procedural necessity for the Government to be able to get its legislation through, the committee must also recommend by when it should report back. That is an integral part of saying which committee they should go to. It is recommended further that that selection of Bills committee should comprise the various Whips. They do represent the balance of power in the Senate and they can say, with some certainty, what would be the will of the Senate on these particular matters. Generally speaking, they would recommend the referral of Bills. Of course, it is for the Senate to decide whether the Bills are actually referred. They would recommend the designated time each day, which Bills should be referred and to which committee and by when they would report. If that were adopted by the Senate, that would happen. Generally, I suppose they would look at controversial Bills.

I have one area of doubt about one of the arguments-not exactly recommendations-in the Committee report, where it is suggested that non-controversial Bills would not benefit from committee consideration. My view is that the non-controversial ones are sometimes the most dangerous ones. Ones with which everyone agrees go through with choruses of praise from all sides of the chamber but frequently the small print, the actual wording of the Bill, is scarcely looked at. I would like to see a system where non-controversial Bills are referred to a committee and publicly displayed by that committee asking for any comments. If after a week or two no comments have been received, the committee reports back saying that there are no difficulties with the Bill.

Perhaps the most interesting case of what can occur happened in Britain last century at a time when there was no divorce law in England. In order to be divorced, an individual had to have a special Act of Parliament. One parliamentary draftsman wished to be divorced from his wife and, when drafting a Bill-something about sewerage in the West Country or something like that-he slipped in the expression, `Mr So-and-so is hereby divorced from his wife Margaret'. Nobody noticed, and he had his divorce; he had his own Act of Parliament. I am not saying that that is at all likely to happen in this Parliament, with our Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills and the Committee of the Whole. Nevertheless, it is an example-perhaps a crude one-of what I mean by saying that with popular Bills, those with which everyone agrees, someone needs to look at the fine print. Referring them to a committee just for a check would be beneficial. That is one small area where I disagree with the thrust of the Committee's recommendation. Basically, I am very much in favour of more Bills, many more Bills, being referred to committees. We have been referring only a handful each year. Out of about 200 Bills that go through this Parliament, probably four or five go to committees. Everyone agrees, as far as I know, that all the Bills that have been referred to committees have been substantially improved as a result of committee recommendations. Now is the time, I believe, to extend that process much more.

The next recommendation of the Committee dealt with how this will come about. If we refer Bills to committees it will take more time. Admittedly, a number of committees can sit simultaneously to reduce the time. But if we add together the time taken by legislative and general purpose committees plus the time for procedures in the chamber we will find that there will be an extension of the time. We could sit longer. This Parliament does not, by international standards, sit for very long. Typically, we sit about 80 to 90 days a year. Other parliaments sit on many more days.
I will give an example. In 1987 this Senate sat on 84 days. The Canadian Parliament sits on average 175 days. In the British Parliament, the House of Lords sits for 156 days. We could sit longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they sit full days?

—I am not saying they are full days, but they sit on 156 days. We sit very long hours when we sit; much longer than other parliaments. Nevertheless, we could sit more days if that were necessary. But my soundings among my colleagues have persuaded me that the pressures on Australian members of parliament in their electorates are such that it would be very difficult to get the Senate to agree to a substantial increase in the number of sitting days. Incidentally, it would not be the voters who would be offended; it would be our own party members who would be offended by the non-appearance of the sitting member. Nevertheless, that is a reality with which we have to live.

SPEECH.PARA: If we cannot sit for many more days we must look at ways of extending the time available to us. The committee recommendation is that Wednesdays of each week should be set aside for committee hearings on Bills. Of course a number of committees could sit simultaneously; all eight could sit simultaneously if necessary. That would expedite proceedings and we would have to make some arrangements for our broadcast days, which are more typically Wednesday, if we wished to have committee hearings. That could be done; that would have to be put in train if we wanted to go for that change. But we recommend, as we were asked to do by our terms of reference, one particular day, and we thought Wednesday was the best day which should be available for committee hearings on Bills. If there were no hearings on Bills the committees could no doubt consider other references, but basically the time would be for committee hearings on Bills.

We were then concerned that if we were not prepared to sit substantially more days in this Parliament, and we were going to take more time to consider Bills in more detail-after all, that is our responsibility, because if we do not do it no-one else will-we must look at ways of saving time in other respects. Here comes one of our controversial recommendations which may or may not be accepted by the Senate. I think it is one the Senate should seriously consider. Estimates committees have not worked in the way in which they were originally envisaged. The idea of Estimates committees when they were set up was that they should be a substitute for debate in the Committee of the Whole. As things have developed we now have both. Senators hear Ministers and public servants in their Estimates committees; then the reports come into the Senate and to a substantial extent the whole thing is rehashed.

The Committee recommendation is that that should not happen. The debate in the chamber-in the Committee of the Whole-should be on the report of the Estimates committee and the only new areas that could be opened up would be ones which had been asked in the Estimates committees but had not been answered. The committees would be required to list any unanswered questions that could be raised and asked. Otherwise debate would be on the reports from the committees to the Committee of the Whole on their examination of the Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in Estimates committees some questions are judged to be questions of policy and senators are invited to raise them in the Committee of the Whole.

—In that case they would not be able to do so under this proposal. They may be; it would depend on what went in the committee report. The committee report, quite frankly, in the past has been not taken very seriously by some committees. It has just been produced as a matter of routine. If an honourable senator wished to raise policy issues as a result of Estimates committee hearings it would be put in the Estimates committee report and then it would be eligible for debate in the chamber when the report came up for debate. Also, the committee would list any unanswered questions which could be asked again and answers insisted on.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make this point, because I know some honourable senators feel they are being deprived of something by this elimination of the Estimates committee debates in the Committee of the Whole: if they wish to have a question asked there is no difficulty about giving that to another honourable senator to ask on their behalf. Alternatively, any senator, if he or she is available, can attend a committee hearing.

Finally, if the answer is not obtained in that way there are many other processes by which a senator can get information. A question without notice, a question on notice, a speech on the adjournment, a letter to the Minister, a request under the Freedom of Information Act are all methods by which we can gain information. We do not have to take up considerable time of the Senate-and we do take up a lot of time on these Estimates committee debates-if we can get a better procedure. I accept that this will be a controversial matter when it comes to debate in the chamber in due course. The Committee was looking for a way in which we could allocate the time of the Senate-there are only so many hours in a sitting day and we accept that we are not going to increase the number of sitting days by any very great margin-and use our available time more productively. We think a duplication of the Estimates committee debates in the Committee of the Whole is not a wise use of our time.

There are two other matters which the Committee did not, in fact, discuss very much, but which were put in because they have been the subject of procedural debate in this chamber and recommendations from the Procedure Committee, and we thought for completeness they should be covered in our report. The first is the matter of a time limit on debates on the suspension of Standing Orders. I think we want to be quite clear what sorts of debates take place on a motion to suspend Standing Orders. If it is generally agreed-in other words, if it is to happen, if Standing Orders are to be suspended-there will be no debate at all; it will be accepted on the nod; people will do a deal and say, `Right, we'll suspend Standing Orders and get on with that matter'. The only occasion on which there is a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders is if the motion is going to be rejected. The sole purpose of moving the suspension of Standing Orders, knowing that it will fail, is to make a political point or points.

It is very easy, as I who often sit in the chair know, to make one's remarks relevant, even though one is supposed to be saying why Standing Orders should be suspended. In fact, with a little skill, one can link in with remarks such as `It is only by suspending Standing Orders that we can debate so-and-so', and make one's whole speech on a subject on a motion to suspend Standing Orders. It is a very common procedure in this chamber. The question is for how long it is prudent or fair to allow people to make such a political statement. At the moment there is no time limit. Each speaker can speak for 30 minutes. Any number of speakers may speak. Again, that does not seem a prudent use of our time and the suggestion in this report, echoing a report by the Procedure Committee, is that a time limit of 30 minutes should be set on a motion for suspension of Standing Orders, bearing in mind-as I said at the outset-that the sole purpose of such a motion, knowing it is going to fail, is to make a political point. I think that is probably a fair recommendation, but I am aware again that it is one on which there are very divided opinions in this Senate.

The final recommendation to which I wish to refer is the question of the quorum. At present the quorum is one-third. The House of Representatives has suggested, or has moved, to a quorum of one-fifth of its members. The suggestion in the Committee report is that we should shift to a quorum of one-quarter. That, again, is a matter on which the Senate is, I know, deeply divided. Calling quorums is one of the weapons of an Opposition because it is the Government's responsibility, traditionally, to keep the quorum and Oppositions yield very reluctantly the few weapons they have at their disposal. I would say to my colleagues that this is probably all right because, in view of the fact that the proposition will reduce a weapon of the Opposition, that will be more of a problem for the Australian Labor Party than for us in the not too distant future. Nevertheless, we cannot expect to be in government forever, so one has to look at what is fair and I am open minded about this. I do not feel strongly very much one way or the other about whether a quorum should be one-third or one-quarter. But I do know there are deep feelings on this matter and when this motion comes on at the end of the year it will have to be fully debated.

I come back to my original point, Mr Acting Deputy President. This, in my view, touches a vital issue in the working of our system of democracy. The House of Representatives, for reasons I have already given, cannot be a legislature and will never be a legislature again. The only legislature we have in the Federal Parliament is this chamber. What we have to look at is how we can best perform that role. I think the use of committees, hearing expert witnesses, discussing matters, and making a proper report back to the chamber as a whole is the best way to go. I think this is a very important report and I hope that most, if not all, of its recommendations are adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on, first of all, the third and the fourth reports of the Procedure Committee and then refer my remarks to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, so ably chaired. The third report of the Procedure Committee dealt with three issues: firstly, the disclosure of in camera evidence; secondly, written questions in Estimates committees; and, thirdly, the broadcasting of committee proceedings. On behalf of my Australian Democrats colleagues, I indicate that we support, basically in terms of the disclosure, the retention of the 1984 position. I think, in fact, there are probably no other viable options, given the nature of the circumstances in this chamber. In regard to written questions in Estimates committees, I think the recommendations of the Procedure Committee ought to be adopted, as should the recommendations with regard to the draft procedures contained in appendices to the report on the broadcasting of committee proceedings. I think that that is a fair and reasonable set of rules that will obviously over time be developed as this procedure is used more often.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one comment that I would like to make on the broadcasting of committee proceedings and it is one which probably will come up more when we are looking at the possible broadcasting of this chamber; that is, I think that the selective broadcasting in itself can be a very unfair weapon, not only with regard to the committee or the people who are on the committee, but also with regard to witnesses. Likewise, selective broadcasting in this chamber could be a very unfair weapon. But more of that at a later stage.

As to the fourth report-on notices of motion-I think that the recommendation is a reasonable one. However, I think that it puts far too much of a political onus on the President. The wording in the recommended standing order is that the President `may' delete extraneous matters from notices and `may' require a senator giving a notice contrary to the standing order to reframe the notice. I think both of those should be written so as to contain the word `shall', because the reason that to date the President has tended to be fairly circumspect, shall we say, in using the powers which are obviously there under previous rulings of Presidents on these matters is that there is in fact that discretion. I think that the onus should be on the President to so remove those extraneous matters and to require the senator to recast the notice of motion.

In terms of the recommendations of the Committee that you chaired, Mr Acting Deputy President, the comments made by Senator Hamer are a full and accurate rendition of what we were attempting to do. However, I wish to make an additional point, that is, what we are looking at is a package. Fairly obviously, these types of changes can never be acceptable to everybody in the chamber. Nor can some of the changes be acceptable to people who are currently in opposition, and some of the changes cannot be acceptable to the people who are in government. What was done here was a fair and reasonable attempt to come up with changes, some of which do favour the Opposition and others of which tend to favour the parties in government. As a whole, they are neutral with regard to both sides. At the moment there is a reasonable amount of suspicion that, when we come to the final vote on these recommendations, we may get some up and not others.

Quite frankly, that political impasse is delaying adoption of these recommendations. That type of thing is to be expected, but I would hope that we might devise a method of dealing with these which simply takes them as a whole-and that they stand or fail on that basis. We get either everything or nothing, because that is the way the Committee looked at this issue. This Committee, unlike other committees, was given leave of the Senate to consult people outside of the Committee on a day to day basis. We have suggested a package and if we do not get it as a package I do not think that we can get anything at all. My feeling is that that these recommendations should not be put singly; they should be put as a whole and a vote taken as a whole.

Recommendation No. 8 relating to a quorum of the Senate will require legislative action. Reducing a quorum from one-third to one-quarter will obviously assist the Government, particularly Ministers. I think that that is a perfectly reasonable proposition. While the quorum is a tactic that oppositions will use and should be able to continue to use, I do not believe that it should be used, as is necessary in this chamber, to take senators who are Ministers of the Crown and perhaps in a Cabinet meeting out of that meeting. I do not believe that that is a rational and reasonable way for this chamber to proceed. The punishment of the Government, as it were, by the use of the quorum is sufficient because a third is still a very large number in the Senate once one takes out Ministers from any government in the foreseeable future. One is getting sufficiently at the Government, as it were, in terms of backbenchers because they would all have to turn up to make that third.

Under the new arrangement in the Senate, in terms of proportional representation with six senators elected at every half Senate election, the numbers in this place will not differ a great deal from election to election. By and large I think that that is a reasonable recommendation, but it does tend to favour the Government. On the other hand, the bulk of the recommendations of the committee of inquiry into government legislation favour non-government senators in this chamber. Regardless of the rhetoric, undoubtedly the Government wants its legislation to remain untouched. After all, it is its legislation. It managed to get it through the House of Representatives untouched. Presumably, that same force and fervour for every written word in the legislation holds true of the Government when it gets its legislation up here. A minute and detailed examination of each clause of legislation is not a most desirable activity from an executive government point of view, but it is something on which the Senate has increased its skills over the years. It will continue to do it well because this place will always, in the foreseeable future, have a non-government majority. Hence we are giving a very large weighting of the exercise to non-government senators.

Moving the thing somewhat back in the Government's favour, it is looking at reorganising Estimates committees to save time. One would like to say, publicly, a few things about the Estimates committees, but it would probably be inappropriate to do so in terms of getting people offside in the attempt to get these recommendations accepted. Referring to historical antecedents rather than the present company in the Senate, I think that all of us would have names that would leap to mind in terms of consuming probably 80 per cent of the time of the Committee of the Whole on Estimates. Not all were opposition senators although they tended to be in opposition at the time. I remember listening to some extraordinary speeches by a South Australian senator of revered memory in this place who on his own was able to consume vast quantities of the chamber's time on matters which undoubtedly were extremely important to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —And chickens.
—I am not quite sure how important they were to anybody else or even to things outside, but they were certainly very important to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Here lies the rub, I think, in that quite a number of senators feel that some individual senators will be deprived of their privileges in this chamber. I am not sure how fair it is to all other senators for one individual senator to take up literally 80 per cent of the time of Estimates committees, which, of course, on average have often run to 20 hours of sitting time. Twenty hours of sitting time is a vast amount of the time of this chamber.

These recommendations aim at a fair distribution of time between all honourable senators. That cannot be done by giving any individual senator unlicensed, untrammelled time in this chamber. The only fair way we can deal with it is to have reasonably circumscribed speaking times. This chamber has recognised that. When I first came here in 1980, which is not too long ago, we were allowed to speak for an hour. I remember having to speak for an hour one morning between 2 o'clock and 3 o'clock because we were waiting for a Bill to come back from the other chamber. We were still in the old Parliament House. I could not see the person who was fronting for the Government or the person who was fronting for the Opposition because they were both flat out on the seats. The person in the chair was asleep at the time. I took that as a personal comment on my scintillating contribution to the debate from 2 a.m. to 3 a.m. Being a very junior senator at that time, I obviously knew what I was supposed to do, which was to keep talking until we could get the Bill back from the House of Representatives. The conclusion that the Senate very quickly came to was that it was fairer to all honourable senators to reduce that speaking time to half an hour. It was not a curtailment of the privileges of individual senators; it was a fairer sharing. Likewise, when we put limits on a variety of other items, it is an attempt to share the available time amongst all honourable senators.

Hence, recommendation 7 on urgency debates, as Senator Hamer quite fairly put it, is an attempt to share what is a political exercise between a number of people who may wish to speak. Again, any time that is taken up on an urgency motion is time not available for a committee stage debate on a Bill. The only alternative to the proposition I have just put is an agreement by honourable senators to expand the number of sitting days-and that does not seem to be on. I would be quite happy to move a motion for that to happen if I felt there would be a clamour of support for extending the sitting times, because then a number of these recommendations would not be necessary. But, if the time available is to remain static, every hour taken in discussing a motion for the suspension of standing orders that will be lost is an hour that is not available for a committee stage of a Bill. Some honourable senators do not seem to be able to understand those mathematics. There is a strictly limited amount of time available.

I see the scrutinising of legislation in committee as the primary task of this chamber and the task that differentiates it from the other place. Let us be clear that the second reading stage is, by and large, a political exercise. I would not be at all upset if it disappeared completely from this chamber because it is done well in the other place. Our contribution-and something that we do well-is to look at Bills in detail in the committee stage, or in committees outside this place. The more time we can make available for that exercise, the happier I will be. There are other things in the nature of politics in this country that we have to deal with and that we should deal with, but let us try to keep them in some kind of perspective.

We support these recommendations. We think recommendations Nos 1 to 7 should be taken as a whole. Recommendation No. 8 is necessary, of course, and I think we should express our support for it. We should then initiate the legislative procedure to bring it in. While each of these recommendations, taken on its own, might need to be dealt with differently, taken together I think they are a fair representation of what should be the position and would move us closer towards what ought to be a major task of scrutinising legislation. I think they fairly distribute between all senators the time that is available within a limited cake.

I would certainly recommend that we deal with these recommendations now. The motion we are debating suggests that we look at them on 1 December. I would hope that when we come to 1 December we actually have a vote. I hope that we will not have an exercise that we have had so often in this place of some individual senators delaying the vote which would determine the wish of the Senate with regard to its own rules and the way in which it conducts its business. Let us get an expression of the view of the Senate as to how it wishes to conduct its business. I think these are good, basic, rational, reasonable reforms that will take us forward. They are in the interests of the legislative procedure although they may not necessarily be in the interests of any particular party. Our task is to look in detail at legislation. These recommendations will improve that task. Let us support them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this cognate debate to address my remarks to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures. I want to give very strong support to the general recommendation of that Committee that more Bills than at present be referred to committees and its recommendation for a procedure to encourage and give effect to that objective.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the very useful and helpful appendices to this report, it is very interesting to note that it seems that the first recorded case of a Bill being referred to a committee by this Senate was on 13 October 1971, which somewhat to my horror I find was just after I became a member of this Senate. So this whole process of referring Bills to committees has occurred during the period in which I have served in this place. Certainly it is a development which I have always supported and which I strongly believe can be improved.

It is interesting that it has taken us 18 years to get to the point where we now are suggesting that a formal procedure be established for the reference of Bills to committees. It may be another case of formalising matters when in fact the problem has been solved. It is quite clear from the appendices that the Senate has been increasingly developing this practice. Indeed, large numbers of very important Bills have been referred to committees. The first one was in fact a private member's Bill introduced in October 1971 by the then Leader of the Opposition, Senator Murphy. I remember it very well because I was on the committee to which it was referred. In the process of its consideration, that committee entirely gutted the actual working of the Bill, although the Senate subsequently had to determine the principle. But I think the process of referring that Bill to a committee greatly improved the quality of its drafting.

A very significant number of Bills have been referred to committees and governments of different shapes have accepted a large number of their recommendations. These facts are set out in the appendices. One that I might mention in passing is the Freedom of Information Bill which, as a result of my motion, was sent to a committee in 1978. That Bill resulted in a large number of recommendations and the acceptance of a large number of them by the Government. I notice that that is not in fact included in the particular appendix, but I just mention it by way of comment. However, the general principle is undoubtedly one that should be formalised in some way, and the proposals of the Committee are very sound in that respect.

I would like to make a cautionary statement in relation to this matter. I would not want to see us get too enthusiastic, so to speak, about referring Bills to committees. The recommendation is a very sober one, namely, that more Bills should be referred to committees, but there is no point in referring a Bill to a committee unless it is a Bill of a kind which is going to be benefited by a committee consideration. Clearly a large number of Bills that go through this chamber do not satisfy that criterion and, therefore, it would be foolish for us to go overboard and to start referring almost all Bills to committees. That would just choke up the system and would lose a lot of the benefits that can be gained.

Another cautionary note I would like to strike is that I would not like to see the development of referring more Bills to committees in any way reducing the role of this chamber in the work of the Committee of the Whole. I was interested in what Senator Macklin said in his strong support for the work that can be done in the Committee of the Whole. I do not think that is suggested, and it is certainly not suggested here; I am just mentioning it because it may deserve some caution. The value of a committee consideration and of a report to the Senate is that it can, of course, greatly improve the work of the Committee of the Whole.

Of course, there are many amendments which can be moved in the Committee of the Whole and which may not have found favour with a committee or which may not even have been considered by a committee. Committee work is of various kinds-not necessarily of varying quality, although that does occur-but also the attention that a committee gives to Bills may vary. It depends to a large extent, I suppose, on the amount of interest that is shown in it at that time by the people who come before it and make submissions to it, and so on. When a committee report comes up for debate in the Committee of the Whole, there are often other considerations and there has been greater study of Bills. Therefore, the work of the Committee of the Whole should not be reduced in any way simply because we have sent a Bill off to a committee. I would not like to see that attitude develop in any way.

The most recent example of a major committee debate in this Senate was that on the War Crimes Bill. The report of the committee on that Bill had been made many months before and pointed the way to a number of amendments which were subsequently developed, but the Committee itself had limited terms of reference and its report was greatly supplemented by many further amendments that were developed because of the public debate as time went on.

Another great advantage, of course, of sending Bills to committees is that the process enables members of the public to learn more about a Bill and gives them the opportunity of making their views known to the Parliament. One of the vices of the modern Parliament, one which this Senate has in recent years sought to correct, is the speed with which legislation is introduced, debated and passed. That is particularly apparent in the House of Representatives, which adds to that vice the even greater vice of the guillotine process. Senator Macklin said that second readings are debated very well in the House of Representatives. However, it could do even better if it had more time for second reading debates. It does not give itself enough time.

I do not subscribe to Senator Macklin's view that we should give up second reading debates. One of the important roles of the Senate is to hold up legislation so that the public can be given an opportunity to study it. Governments, and to some extent even ourselves as members of parliament, do not appreciate the difficulty that even expert lobby groups have in getting hold of legislation and getting time to give it proper consideration. It is a very time consuming process for our electors, our constituents. That is the great advantage of having a bicameral system, but even a bicameral system can fail. I have been here when several pieces of legislation have gone through both Houses of this Parliament in one day. There may have been special reasons for that. Fortunately, the Senate would agree to that only in very special cases. The Senate's tradition of looking carefully at legislation has led, I think, to a great improvement in the legislative process in Australia. Its experiment of referring Bills to committees is another tool that it has developed and it is an area which clearly can be improved.

The proposal to establish a selection of Bills committee is a practical way of handling the matter. As I said, I think that caution must be exercised. That can be exercised by the Senate itself, in many cases on political grounds, but that is what we are here for. We should send only a number of Bills, perhaps not very many more than we have sent in recent years. I think that we worked out a pretty good method of selecting Bills to go to committees. I think that sound decisions have been made on that. Although I can see that a number of other Bills could usefully be sent to committees I do not know that a great many more Bills will be sent, or should be sent, under the new procedures but, nevertheless, it is valuable to have the process formalised.

I take a different view from Senator Macklin as to how we should go about this proposal. The motion nominates 1 December as the date for its further consideration. I suppose that date will come pretty quickly and we do have many other things to do in the meantime. However, I hope that on 1 December we will not try to get agreement upon this so-called package as a whole. I believe that there are two quite separate packages in the Committee's recommendations. The first deals with the establishment of a selection of Bills committee and the principles of sending Bills to committees. The second deals with proposals on saving time, as time will be lost as a result of sitting on committees one day a week. It is probably wrong to assume that the work of the committees can be done on only one day of the week. If there is a major Bill the committee will probably have to sit on non-sitting days anyway. I would prefer to see us working out how much more time is needed and how the committees can organise their time before getting into what will be very controversial proposals. I want to make some very strong criticism of one or two of the other proposals and indicate a feeling that I am sure will be shared by a number of other senators.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations: What is the estimated cost to business of the further 3 per cent compulsory superannuation contribution foreshadowed in the Treasurer's Budget Speech last night? What will be the total cost to business in this financial year of the changes to company tax and pay as you earn (PAYE) collections, changes which amount to a disguised increase in the rate of company tax? Why in an allegedly pro-savings Budget has the Government decided to attack corporate savings in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of incorrect assumptions--
—Where were you when the Budget was drawn up?

—I was there, Senator. There are a number of incorrect assumptions in this question. While I might surprise Senator Lewis, he does not surprise me. I might say at the beginning that the Treasurer in the Budget Speech only flagged the possibility of a further 3 per cent superannuation round next year. That would be a matter which would have to be addressed in the run-up to those arrangements and not at this time.

ANSWER.PARA: There is in the question a second assumption which is incorrect: describing the changes to the business taxation arrangements as a disguised increase in company tax. It is nothing of the sort. The revised company tax collection arrangements alter the timing of payments within the financial year, but they do not--

TALK.START.PARA: —An extra $1.4 billion.
—They do not alter the amount payable.
—If you rip off--
—Order! Senator Lewis, you have asked your question.

—Senator Lewis could perhaps argue this question out in the sticks on behalf of ordinary taxpayers, who do not get the benefit which companies get of interest accruing on the tax payments which they have to make much later in the year.
—A great help to industry!

—The honourable senator says that it is a great help to industry, but something that he has scarcely been prepared to acknowledge is that in the last four years in the period of this Government company profitability in this country has been at record levels. That is the second point I would make in relation to this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: If I might recapitulate: revised company tax collection arrangements alter the timing within the financial year but not the amount payable. There is no change to corporate tax rates. From next year the initial instalment of company tax will be payable in the first month after the end of each company's 1989-90 income year, with the balance due nine months later.

There is an equity issue in this, as I have just pointed out. The tax deferral available to companies is not available to individuals and other taxpayers. What we are doing is removing essentially interest-free loans from the Government to companies, something which is not available to individuals and something which, of course, affects the level of aggregate public savings. I would also make the point that from 1 December 1989 certain employers with annual PAYE remittances-some 800 employers; the largest in Australia-will be required to make payments twice a month rather than once a month. This also increases equity by removing the benefits to large businesses from the deferral of tax payments. After all, corporations are in business. They have core businesses, and their core businesses are not usually gleaning interest from deferred tax payments.

These two changes have been made, as I pointed out, at a time of historically high company profits. If we are going to make these changes in the interests of equity and in the interests, if you like, of increasing revenue in one year, it is not a bad time to do it when company profits are at an historically high level. The changes are aimed at increasing equity in the tax system, not at increasing corporate taxation. I do not believe any particular damage will be done as a result of these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade provide the Senate with details of the circumstances of the death of Miss Jacqueline Hamill, the Australian hostage killed in the seige incident in the Philippines yesterday? Would it have been possible for the Australian Government to have intervened or taken any other action to assist the Philippines authorities in handling the tragic events in Davao city which might have led to the safe release of Miss Hamill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I received an interim report from the Australian Embassy in Manila giving the fullest details available at this time concerning the tragic death of Miss Jacqueline Hamill. As I announced last night when expressing the Government's shock and sadness at the circumstances of her death, I have instructed the Ambassador to make clear representations to the Philippines Government of the Australian Government's concern that fullest possible investigations be carried out. I have instructed my Department to stay in close touch with Miss Hamill's parents and family, as it did throughout the day yesterday and as I have done this morning, to extend all possible consular assistance in the aftermath of this tragedy. On the instructions of the family, the Embassy is making arrangements to have her body returned as soon as possible to Queenstown in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: There is still some confusion and conflicting accounts about the events that took place inside the prison during the almost 48 hours of the seige. According to the doctor who examined Miss Hamill's body when it was brought to the Davao doctor's hospital, the cause of death was a gunshot wound from the back of the left chest region, exiting near the collar bone. There was no other visible evidence of injury. Reports that her throat was cut are quite incorrect. In the doctor's opinion, death was instantaneous and had occurred some hours previously, which would indicate that she was shot during the attempted escape incident in the morning.

The following is, on the latest reliable information available, an outline of what happened. Negotiating with the prisoners had been going on since early yesterday morning, 15 August. At approximately 10.30, while negotiations were still going on, the prisoners decided to break out using the hostages as shields to cross the compound and then take any available transport. During that escape attempt, gunfire was exchanged between prisoners and soldiers during which one of the prisoners and the hostage that prisoner was using as a shield-not Miss Hamill-were killed. The prisoners then decided to retreat to the prison with the hostages. Miss Hamill was seen to slump as the group retreated through a gateway to the inner compound immediately in front of the prison block. It is not clear where the fatal shot came from. That is, of course, one of the matters that we are particularly asking the Philippines authorities now to investigate. Miss Hamill remained there until after the soldiers stormed the prison at 3 o'clock-some 4 1/2 hours later. She was then taken to an ambulance by two soldiers and from there to the hospital where the examination to which I have referred took place.

In answer to the honourable senator's question about Australian Government intervention, it is important to remember that the police and security authorities of any state, any country, have the primary responsibility to deal with law enforcement incidents in their own country and within their own jurisdiction. That is an attribute of every state's sovereignty in international responsibility. The Philippines authorities did not seek assistance from the Australian Government during the course of this incident. That is, I suppose, not surprising, given that, of the 15 prisoners and 15 hostages we believe were involved in the whole matter, only one person was an Australian. Moreover, our own assessment was that in the circumstances prevailing yesterday and in the time available there was no practical scope for any direct Australian involvement which would at that stage have provided any basis for resolution-or a more satisfactory resolution-of the Davao crisis. The situation was urgent, local and specific and one in which foreign governments would have had neither standing nor local knowledge.

So, tragic as the outcome undoubtedly was, I am confident that, unfortunately, in all the circumstances and in the time available, there was no way in which Australia could have intervened or involved itself in any practical way which would have changed the course of events. We did, of course, have a consular official on the scene who went there immediately on the Monday afternoon when the news of the incident came through to Manila, and he was in touch with the authorities throughout. Beyond that, it was not possible for us to play any more substantial role. I do fully appreciate, as does the Prime Minister, the understandable grief and shock of the family, and I really do want to assure them publicly, as I have privately, that the Government and embassy did everything within their power to assist. I do want to take this opportunity again to express our very deepest sympathy to Ms Hamill's family over their most tragic loss.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I note his reply to an earlier question from Senator Lewis and I refer to the same matter, that is, the Government's Budget changes to the timing of company tax payments and pay as you earn taxation instalments. Does the Minister agree that these measures will affect a company's cash flow position and its ability to save, and hence will reduce that company's ability to reinvest in plant and equipment ? As one of the reasons given by the Government to reduce the company tax rate to 39 per cent from 1 July this year was to stimulate business investment which was needed to trade our way out of our present balance of payments problems, why now is the Government offsetting this earlier measure with these latest punitive tax changes?

—I am not able to say in the case of each company, of course, whether the changes will affect a company's cash flow. But I suspect the answer to that question in most cases, or practically all cases, would be yes.
—Of course it would.

—It depends whether cash flow is relevant, Senator Chaney, to the question of investment, which Senator Messner asked about. I do not mind the honourable senator smiling. It was just the idiot grin which concerned me. It clearly suggested that he did not understand what I was talking about again. Senator Messner has asked the question, and I will answer it. Of course, a company's cash flow is relevant to the question of investment. If a company is not investing it may, of course, be less relevant. But I think the answer to that part of the question is yes.
—What are you talking about?

—I will come back to the answer that I gave earlier. We are talking about companies which, by and large, in the last four years have enjoyed record profitability. We are talking about major companies-big companies. Senator Messner went on to ask me whether it would affect a company's capacity to reinvest in plant and equipment. In a marginal sort of way, it might. I just want to give him the figures which he can find in the Budget Papers. Who is he to ask questions about this? If he looks at page 239 of the Budget Papers, he will see that between 1984 and 1985 the increase in private business fixed investment was 10.8 on average. When the honourable senator was in government, in each of the periods between 1974 and 1979, and 1979 and 1983, the average investment in plant and equipment and so on was 2.3 and 1.6. The 1.6 figure covered the much vaunted and talked up resources boom. I simply make the point that investment levels in this country have been running at a record high in the last year or two. Company profits have been running at a record high. If he makes the point that reduction of cash flow might arise in one year from the timing of tax collections by the Taxation Office from businesses, yes, I think that is probably correct. But in terms of the larger picture, if I might borrow that phrase from a colleague of mine, it is not very significant.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Given that the Minister has just told us that these are years of record profitability, why then did the Government reduce the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent, starting on 1 July?

—I suppose there are a number of reasons for that, but corporate tax rates are competitive around the world, and the Australian corporate tax rate was high compared with those of other countries prior to that deduction. That is one very good reason.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. If the Government is seriously considering renting out an area of attractive land in South Australia larger than England to allow Australian and foreign companies to live-test munitions and weapons systems, under what conditions will these companies operate? Is the French military giant Thompson CSF one of the companies interested in using the proposed weapons range? If so, will the Government seek assurances that the company will not test nuclear capable missile delivery systems on the range to complement the warheads tested at Mururoa? Is it possible that missiles or other munitions tested on the range could disturb the thinly covered plutonium contaminating the land of the Maralinga Tjarutja people and cause more widespread plutonium contamination, a matter of great concern to the Aboriginal people in the area after tests by the Australian Radiation Laboratory found about 25 kilograms more plutonium than was thought to be in the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I hasten to say that I am answering the question in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. The Department of Defence has issued a request for proposals for the commercialisation of the Woomera range, and whether or not we will find an operator interested in doing that remains to be seen. I do not think commenting on any particular companies at this stage of the game would be of assistance, but if a commercial range operator were found, then obviously an agreement would have to be negotiated by the Commonwealth with that operator. That agreement would provide for all of the control measures that Senator Dunn might consider necessary to ensure the protection of Australia's national interest. No tests relating to nuclear weapons systems would be permitted. Acceptance of particular range customers would be a matter for the commercial judgment of the range operator acting within the constraints of the control arrangements that have been made with the Commonwealth. No range activities would be permitted on or near Maralinga areas where there is residual radioactive contamination.

ANSWER.PARA: The Woomera prohibited area has been declared as such for the testing of war material in the interests of the safety or defence of Australia. The prohibited area includes freehold land owned by the Maralinga and Pitjantjatjara Aboriginal people. It also includes traditional tribal lands from the Kokatha people. The Department of Defence is awaiting a response from the Maralinga Tjarutja to its draft memorandum of understanding on access to the Maralinga lands that are within the prohibited area. There is nothing in that proposed memorandum that is not negotiable. The issue of British Government compensation in relation to the clean-up of the test sites is a matter for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask whether, if the Maralinga people did not consent to their lands being used for testing, they would have power to veto under the circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a question that I would much rather check with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs before I answer it, but one would imagine that there are arrangements with the people already for the weapon range that is in place now. I do not believe that that would change if we were to allow a commercial operator to move in. Obviously, the arrangements that we have would continue.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the cut in real terms of 8 per cent in the international aid budget mean that the Government has totally rejected the recent recommendation of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that the foreign aid budget rise to 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product by 1992? Secondly, does the Minister agree that the Budget allocations will send confusing signals about Australia's foreign policy interests because, while we are committing $50m to nuclear weapon capable countries such as India and Pakistan, the Government has refused in the Budget to renew funding to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), which focuses on increasing food production in the poorest agricultural countries? Lastly, does the Minister agree that this cut in the aid budget-and, indeed, the lowest allocation in 30 years-will adversely affect Australia's standing in the international community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Budget Papers, particularly Budget related Paper No. 4, make very clear, the cut in this year's Budget aid allocation, both in real percentage terms and as a proportion of gross national product (GNP), is really more apparent than real. I say that because of the particular circumstance which is explained in the Budget Papers whereby in round figures $100m of expenditure that would in the normal course have had to be incurred this financial year, 1989-90, was in the last weeks of the last financial year brought back into the 1988-89 figures. In particular I am referring to some contributions that were due to the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank about which there was some flexibility of timing and it was, in fact, because of the constraints that I knew would be applicable in going better than the Forward Estimates so far as this year's Budget was concerned, and because of the very real problems I knew would be experienced in getting an additional $100m into this year's allocation to cover those additional imposts which were falling due in one way and another this year, that when the opportunity arose to bring forward that expenditure, as it did last year, I grabbed it-to be frank-with both hands with the result that last year's figure is inflated beyond that which was in the Budget projections. It is really a very respectable outcome indeed but by contrast this year's allocation does not look so good. It represents a decline in real terms and further decline in the ratio which would not have occurred had that $100m in fact been spent not last year but this year.

ANSWER.PARA: So in terms of the substantive programs themselves, the bilateral programs, the contributions to multilateral agencies and all the rest of the targets for our aid that Senator Macklin feels strongly about-and I assure him that I feel strongly about them too-we have effectively been able in all those areas to maintain the real value of our contributions or, where not entirely the real value, as is the case with some multilateral contributions, at least the nominal value and very often very close to the real value. So it is really a steady as you go outcome.

Some of the more extravagant claims that have been made about the aid budget, in particular from the spokesman from the Australian Council for Overseas Aid to the effect that there was a $20m cut in the aid program to Indonesia, are totally misconceived. In fact, as the Budget Papers make clear, there has been an increase in programmable aid to Indonesia from $45.4m to $48.3m this year. In terms of the International Fund for Agricultural Development, no further contribution is in fact due by Australia this financial year pursuant to our existing obligations and, as I have made clear publicly on a number of occasions, I am actively reviewing-and the Government, through the Cabinet, will very shortly be in the process of actively reviewing-the decision that was made previously to withdraw from IFAD. I cannot say any more about that at the moment but I acknowledge the force of the submissions that have been made to me from a very large number of people and organisations that IFAD is an organisation that delivers soundly targeted and effective aid and that Australia's position on that ought to be reconsidered.

It remains the case that if we look at the Budget in the way that I have said in fairness it should be looked at, we have in effect, for all practical purposes, maintained the ratio at around the 0.36 level, taking into account that $100m which was brought forward by a few weeks. That is still better than the average for developed countries in terms of their contribution but falls a long way short of the 0.7 per cent target as a proportion of overseas development assistance to GNP that we would very much like to be able to meet. It certainly falls short of my own private aspiration which I perhaps unwisely communicated publicly on a number of occasions. I would like to get that back up to around 0.4 per cent as soon as possible. But the difficulty remains that when we are in straitened budgetary and economic circumstances of the kind that this country is in, we cannot always realise our expenditure aspirations and to be able to maintain programs of this kind effectively in real terms is in all the circumstances probably the best we can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. It concerns the provision of child-care facilities in new government buildings. As a member of the Joint Public Works Committee, I have been advised on many occasions by Commonwealth officers at public hearings that provision for child-care is not made when planning new buildings as this would be contrary to Government policy. This advice was again given to the Committee as recently as last Wednesday at the Hobart public hearing on the new Commonwealth Government centre. Could the Minister please clarify the Government's policy in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a priority of the Government to provide community-based child-care centres, and I think that any reasonable person would recognise that this Government has an outstanding record in relation to child-care. But we emphasise that any government has to set priorities, and our priority has been community-based child-care. However, Commonwealth Government employees have access to these on the same basis as other members of the community. Commonwealth Government employers or unions have facilitated the establishment of a number of community-based centres, and I think this indicates a way in which Commonwealth unions can ensure that their members are getting access to the benefits of the child-care policy that this Government has pursued. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Staff Association child-care centre in Woolloomooloo is just one example: 50 to 70 per cent of users are ABC staff. At the Jennifer Lockwood Childcare Centre in Perth, which was initiated by the Australian Public Service Association, Telecom staff are among its main users. There is a centre adjacent to the Telecom industries group in Bentleigh East in Melbourne on land made available by Telecom, and again Telecom staff are among the main users. A child-care centre has been built by the Ku-ring-Gai Council on land leased from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The CSIRO leased the land to the council on the condition that a child-care centre be built and that CSIRO have representation on the centre's board of management. However, as the centre is a community facility, the council cannot guarantee priority places for children of CSIRO employees.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I turn to an area in which I know Senator Newman will have a special interest-the Department of Defence. Department of Defence-owned houses may be used to run family day-care centres funded under the normal arrangements. Surplus facilities on bases are sometimes used for child-care on a self-help basis. Land on the outskirts of Holsworthy army base has been made available for a child-care centre for the use of local residents, including service families.

I think that reflects the fact that the Government's policy of giving absolute priority to community-based care is the way that we see child-care provision at this stage. It is obvious that Senator Devereux raises an issue that is of great concern to public sector employees, but it is important that we set our priorities; and we believe that the most important thing for the Australian community at the moment is community-based child-care.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Treasurer's claim last night that `the full force of the Government's resolve' will be directed towards reducing the current account deficit. If this is the case, and in light of today's disastrous balance of payments deficit figure of $1.7 billion for July, why has the Government brought down a Budget which does absolutely nothing in either direct or indirect terms to ease the current account crisis? In the absence of any action by the Government to increase productivity and international competitiveness, is it not a fact that the Government's only real hope now of reducing the current account deficit is through economic recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of points made in Senator Stone's question. The first one I would like to refer to is that the Government strategy over the last few months, quite apart from anything in the Budget-this has been a matter of comment and discussion in the Senate-has been to reduce levels of demand in the Australian economy.
—Very high interest rates.

—Yes, everybody knows that. There is no secret about that. That has been pursued for several months now and I must say that there are a number of signs now of slackening in demand in the Australian economy. Slackening of demand in the Australian economy will mean fewer imports and should mean a growth of net--
—That is not what you forecast.

—I know that but Senator Stone understands-it is no good his pretending he does not-the purpose of the strategy. It is to reduce imports and to produce a growth in net exports. It is very easy to come in here and telescope timescales. In the absence--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis, have a look back over the past few years. If there is a reduction in demand in the Australian economy a lot of it flows through into exports. That is a fact, and if we look at what happened in 1985-86--
—Do you mean imports?

—No, I said that flows through into exports. I know what I mean; I am quite clear about that. Let me explain for the benefit of Senator Lewis. Let me give him a simple example which he might understand. In the last two years Australian exports of steel have fallen right away. Why? It is because there has been an enormous increase in domestic demand for steel which BHP could not satisfy. Not only could BHP not satisfy the domestic demand for steel; it actually imported steel on occasions to satisfy that level of domestic demand. Now if you reduce the domestic demand, that frees up BHP production for export purposes and it also stops it importing steel into this country. That is a simple example which the honourable senator might understand, I hope he does, I put it in those terms in order that there might be some understanding of this issue raised in Senator Stone's question. Senator Stone then goes on to ask: In the absence of anything being done about productivity in this country-and he knows he could get a pimple on his tongue for that one; it is an issue we debated yesterday-what is the Government doing about these issues? First of all, there is no absence of things being done. Everything which is talked about by his Party in this context is about long term measures which will not solve today's current account problem and he well knows that. It is totally specious to try to telescope all these issues by taking one month's current account figure, asking what we are doing about productivity and suggesting we provide some solution.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I have listened with the greatest goodwill to the Leader of the Government's attempted response to the question but I have to put it to him again: when he has got the level of demand depressed by the high interest rates, as he has fallen back on once again in his answer, when he has got the level of growth in the economy down to zero, or something approaching zero, by the end of this financial year-he makes the point that there is a difference through the year compared to the year as a whole-what is he going to do then? Is he going to let the economy run along flat, with unemployment continuing to rise? Or is he simply going to resort to the same stop-go policies which 10 years ago he was criticising his predecessors for?

—I always thought that a lot of people in this country suffer from the problem of addressing the issues of the 1960s and the 1970s and I did not think the honourable senator was one of them. I must say that it requires a far better mind than mine to understand the supplementary question which the honourable senator asked me. Why does he not have a look at the Budget figures? A 2 1/2 per cent growth rate is forecast for next year. That is something which the honourable senator rarely enjoyed during his period of occupancy at the Treasury. The honourable senator talks about employment. He talks about people becoming unemployed. That is something that he knows all about because that is precisely what he and the Fraser Government did in 1982 to try to rectify these problems. It is not what this Government has presided over and it is not what it will preside over because we have had consistent employment growth during our period of government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to the announcement in last night's Budget that additional Australian Federal Police liaison officers are to be posted overseas. Can the Minister inform the Senate of where these liaison officers will be located?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for his question, which is merely yet another instance of his continuing interest in the fight against organised crime and particularly drug trafficking. He has taken a particular interest in that matter. The men and women members of the Australian Federal Police who serve overseas in our various embassies as liaison officers are certainly on the front line in the international fight against organised crime and drug trafficking. On my recent overseas visit I was able to confirm the fact that they are held in extremely high regard, and justly so, because--
—Just tell him Rangoon and Shanghai.

—Senator, that is not all I have to say. I have to put this in context. Over 60 per cent of the seizures of imported heroin, cannabis and cocaine into this country last year resulted from the intelligence gathered by our Federal Police liaison officers overseas. I think I am well justified in taking some time to paint the picture of the close cooperation that members of the Federal Police have achieved with the law enforcement agencies overseas. At the moment they are appointed to London, Cyprus, Islamabad, Hong Kong, Manila, Singapore, Washington and Buenos Aires.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the additional funding that has been obtained in last night's Budget, to which the honourable senator refers in his question, an additional officer will be posted to Manila and, when language educated officers become available, new posts will be opened in Chiang Mai, Rome and Tokyo, which has been a matter of interest and concern to members of the Senate with questions being asked in this chamber concerning the possibility of opening that post. There are some difficulties, of course, in getting somebody with the requisite language skills but as soon as that is achieved that posting will be made.

I believe that the posting of these officers overseas is, as I say, extremely important. Timely intelligence of those who would target Australia, particularly in relation to drugs which can ravage and cause devastation amongst our young Australians, is something which I think all members of the Senate would applaud. I certainly wish to place on the record my appreciation of the work of the Australian Federal Police in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with Mr Simon Crean that the Government has not done enough to get inflation down? Why has the Government given up on the fight against inflation, leaving Australia saddled with a rate well above that of our major trading partners?

—It is not correct to assert that the Government has given up on inflation. Indeed, as was made very clear in the Budget Speech and in a number of subsequent interviews by certainly the Treasurer and me, and probably the Prime Minister, we do expect a very substantial decline in the rate of inflation during this year. It is, however, correct--
—What?
—It is in the Budget Speech, among other places. The honourable senators must have noticed it there.
—That does not make it correct.

—That is correct of course, Senator Stone. Expectations are not always realised. For example, I well remember the honourable senator saying at the end of 1987-not just saying but actually writing and publishing-that one economic certainty in the world is that there would be a global recession in 1988. It did not happen. But likewise, Mr President, at the time that the 1988 Budget was presented, the Government's economic advisers from within the bureaucracy, and every private sector commentator or analyst that I know of, seriously underestimated the strength of domestic demand-an error which, I suggest, grew substantially out of the 1987 stock market crash. There had not been such an event, or anything remotely resembling it since World War II, and the consequences of it were pretty uncertain. Now because domestic demand was very much stronger than anticipated at the time of the 1988 Budget, both the inflation rate and the current account deficit unfortunately reached levels much higher than forecast in that Budget.
—I have a supplementary, question, Mr President. Is Mr Crean right or wrong?
—I did not hear Mr Crean. I think Senator Reid alleged or implied that Mr Crean had said the Government had given up on inflation. If he said that, he is wrong.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Finance in that capacity and also in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen the Chanticleer column in today's Australian Financial Review expressing fears about the impact of proposed initiatives in the area of superannuation? Will the Government's policies affect Australia's superannuation industry in the ways set out in the article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and it deals with two points. Firstly, it provides information on the results of the superannuation reforms that have already been put in place by the present Government since 1983 and analyses the effects of the initiatives that were announced last night. In the years when the present shadow Treasurer was advising the then Treasurer-that is, in the late 1970s and the earlier 1980s-virtually nothing was done to promote occupational superannuation as a vehicle for true long term private saving for the provision of retirement income.
—Nothing was done, full stop. That is the problem.

—Instead of that, Senator Button, what we had were cherry picker schemes, superannuation cover for a well paid minority, cashing out lump sums several times in a lifetime. In other words, it was not superannuation. It was deferred wages, concessionally taxed. Once the lump sum had been obtained the proceeds were either spent or hidden in low income assets in order to double dip. There has been a vast change since then. As Chanticleer says in today's article:

ANSWER.PARA: Since the Hawke Government started fixing up the retirement incomes system in 1983, the superannuation pool has increased from $17 billion to $105 billion.

Chanticleer goes on to argue that with the additional policy initiatives announced last night, that pool could grow from the present $105 billion to $500 billion within a decade. I quote from the article again:

It would mean that within about 15 years, the savings position of the nation will have been transformed to the point where foreign debt of the size we are all now so worried about will either disappear or become irrelevant.
And what's more it will be long-term savings-not short-term bank accounts as would be encouraged by such measures as providing tax relief on interest income.

I suppose that could be summed up in short by saying that Chanticleer prefers meat to feathers. Of course, Chanticleer's comment is not an isolated example because those with a true understanding of Australia's saving investment problems recognise that the retirement income's policy announced by the Government is the responsible and proper way to tackle the two problems of insufficient, inadequate domestic savings relative to the level of investment required, and the longer term Budget outlays problem of an ageing population.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Minister of a statement by the Prime Minister in his 1987 policy speech that:

QUESTION.PARA: This Government sets the welfare of the Australian family as its top priority.

I also remind the Minister that many of the causes of youth homelessness and child poverty in Australia are the direct result of the breakdown of those families and marriages through divorce. I ask the Minister: How does the Government justify the current spending on marriage education and marriage counselling of just $7m compared to funding for opera at $8.2m and total spending on music at $14.3m? I also ask the Minister whether this low priority given to the maintenance of marriages means the Government has decided its responsibilities to Australian families are too hard and that therefore it will ignore them?

TALK.START.PARA: —A flippant answer to the question might be that most people prefer music and so on to marriage breakdown. I think any government would take the view that in a period of rapid social change which has affected the stability of marriages and which has been occurring in Australia for the last 10 or 15 years at least, the function of government in helping people in that process is probably a fairly limited one. That is to say, the size of the problem does not dictate the size of the amount we spend on it, which is the implication of the honourable senator's question. I do not know about the adequacy of marriage guidance facilities and so on, some of which, of course, are provided by government and some of which are provided by non-government organisations. It may be that if they were better, there would be less marital breakdown; it may not be-I do not know. If I can obtain a better informed answer to the honourable senator's question on the issue of marriage counselling, I will do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and relates to Shark Bay, Western Australia. Is the Minister aware that applications for mineral sand mining tenements affect most of Dirk Hartog Island and that the application by Mr Ross Lightfoot's company, A-CAP Development Ltd, is to be considered in the Perth Mining Warden's Court on Friday, 18 August? Secondly, is the Minister aware that under section 111 (a) of the Western Australian Mining Act, the tenement applications are subject to disallowance in the public interest? Thirdly, on what date did the Australian Heritage Commission include Dirk Hartog Island on the Register of the National Estate? Fourthly, what powers does the Minister have to prevent destruction of the unique natural values of Dirk Hartog Island, which is one of the valuable components by virtue of which the Shark Bay region is qualified for World Heritage nomination? Fifthly, in view of the fact that Western Australian environmental protection agencies refrain from lodging objections to the mining tenement applications although such tenements are contrary to the Shark Bay region plan, will the Minister take urgent action to ensure that sand mining does not commence at Dirk Hartog Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions have been asked. I am aware that applications for mineral sand mining tenements have been lodged for Dirk Hartog Island and they are obviously causing some controversy. There is no doubt that mineral sand mining on the island could cause some damage to what are, I think, very significant heritage values in the area. It is on the National Estate and I think that is--
—It has nothing to do with you.
—It is entered on the Register of the National Estate.
—That doesn't--

—Unfortunately for Senator Boswell, it does and, unfortunately for him, it will for a long time to come. His ignorance of the National Estate is profound. I did not believe that anyone could get more ignorant, but he does so on a daily basis. Because of my concern about those values, I wrote to the Western Australian Minister-I do not have the date but it was in the last six weeks-expressing my concern about the potential threat to the values of the Shark Bay area. I sought information on how the granting of mineral lease tenements fits into the Shark Bay region plan and how the mining leases on Dirk Hartog Island are viewed by his Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question asks whether I am aware of a section of the Western Australian Act. Yes. I am aware of the Act but obviously that is entirely the responsibility of the Western Australian Government and not mine. I understand, Mr President, that the issue of sand mining on Dirk Hartog Island was referred to the State Planning Commission by the Western Australian Mines Department.
