The Commission advised the Mines Department that any proposals for mining and exploration on the island should be opposed as they would cause disturbance to the natural environment, so it is my opinion, therefore, that it would be quite proper if this application were disallowed. The third question was: On what date did the Heritage Commission include the island on the register? That occurred on 21 March 1989. Shark Bay, of course, is not entered on the World Heritage List and no nomination for it has yet been lodged. I am discussing that issue with the Western Australian Government, and with the Western Australian and South Australian governments we are also looking at nomination for the Nullarbor.

I think it is worth stating that we do not have sufficient information yet to lodge any nomination for Shark Bay. A number of studies have been carried out, some by the Heritage Commission, some by the Western Australian Government, but so far I do not think there would be enough to pursue a nomination. That is something we will have to look at in the future. At the moment talk of World Heritage listing is somewhat premature. I do not think it is by any means clear-cut that these mining applications will be approved. We will have to wait and see. But in the interim, there is nought that I can do about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the 2 1/2 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan unable to return to their homes because villages and roads are mined and rocket attacks and fighting continue. Even if these difficulties were overcome in the near future, the current planting season is almost over, which means another winter in the refugee camps. Is the Minister aware of the fact that many donor countries have ceased or reduced aid to these refugees so that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is suddenly faced with a shortfall of $4m to the end of this year? Is Australia maintaining multilateral and bilateral aid to the Afghan refugees in Pakistan, 75 per cent of whom are women and children, in many cases without resources and unable to fend for themselves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government shares Senator Giles's concern with the situation of Afghan refugees. Our funding support is as follows: in June 1988 we pledged $20m over three financial years in response to a United Nations (UN) appeal for humanitarian and economic assistance programs for Afghanistan. Most of that Australian pledge will be channelled through the UN with some funds being allocated for the activities of non-government organisations. Under these programs the resettlement of several million Afghan refugees and displaced persons will be coordinated by international agencies and non-government organisations (NGOs). Our contribution will be used mainly to provide food.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the Soviet withdrawal, the Australian Government is providing $3.2m of that pledge this financial year. The bulk of these funds are being channelled through the UN coordinator's office for allocation to the UNHCR, the world food program and the coordinator's office itself. Funds have also been provided to the International Committee of the Red Cross-$250,000-and another $50,000 has been provided to the agency coordinating body for Afghan relief, which is an NGO umbrella body.

Australian assistance for the Afghan refugees, including those located in Pakistan, for the period since the Soviet invasion in 1979, when it is all added up, totals almost $48m. It is expected that a significant part of the remainder of the $20m pledge will be spent in the coming year, a large part in the form of food aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In light of Simon Crean's comment that the Budget does not contain a trading strategy and in light of today's current account deficit of over $1.7 billion for July, when will the Government remove impediments to export growth, such as its illogical three mines uranium policy, the floor price on uranium and the coal export levy?

—I do not think the Government will deal with those matters in the light of Simon Crean's comments. They are not matters about which I can give the honourable senator an answer at present, but they are matters which impinge upon the portfolios of various Ministers. But of course the process of removing impediments has been going on and will go on.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. This Government's commitment to child-care is beyond question, but complaints are sometimes raised about its accessibility for all who want to use it. Can the Minister inform the Senate what steps the Government has taken to ensure that child-care remains within the reach of lower income families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —The theme of Budget initiatives in child-care this year is affordability and equity. All honourable senators would know that the Hawke Government has financed an unprecedented expansion of publicly funded child-care services. The Government has more than doubled the number of child-care places, from 46,000 to 114,000, and targeted new services for people in need. Last year's Budget pledged another 30,000 new child-care places by 1992, and over 8,200 will be available by the end of this financial year. This year's Budget concentrates on ensuring that child-care remains affordable to lower income families. Honourable senators will recall that it was this Government which introduced fee relief assistance to low income families, in 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: For the first time now the Government has decided to index fee relief payments annually. Fee relief ceilings for government-funded child-care centres and family day care schemes will rise to $92.50 and $68 respectively. The Government has also decided to increase threshold income at which users start to pay more than the minimum fee from $255 to $280 per week gross. These initiatives will mean a rise of $7 per week per child in government assistance to families receiving fee relief, which will be adjusted each year in line with inflation.

Operational subsidies for all kinds of government-funded child care, including occasional care centres and family day care schemes, will also be increased this year. Further, the Government is proposing a new fee relief scheme to assist low income families using outside school hours care and will approach States to cost-share. These measures acknowledge the crucial role child-care plays in achieving the Government's social policy goals and are a major step in guaranteeing affordable quality child-care into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business: Is the Minister aware that Australia's sole remaining tractor manufacturer is being forced to move its operations offshore because of an absurd legislative anomaly which the Government ignores? Is the Minister aware of the case of Waltanna Tractors, which is having to pay high customs duties to import components, most of which are not available in Australia? Does the Minister find it illogical that customs duties are being charged on the components used in manufacturing a tractor when the fully imported tractor can be imported duty free? Having been advised as far back as 1987 that this anomaly existed and warned of the dire consequences if nothing was done, why has the Government done nothing?

—It is not that the Government has done nothing. I know that the honourable senator has been psyched up to ask this question by the public exposure of the issue by his colleague, Mr David Hawker, who has made several representations on this issue over the past 18 months-and I, of course, have been aware of them-but there are certain assumptions in the honourable senator's question which are not correct. It is true that Waltanna Tractors and other manufacturers in various industries are paying tariff duties on various imported components. But there is a remedy for that which, hopefully, would lead the company to apply for a commercial tariff concession. The company has not done that, although it has been advised that it could. When I say that it has not done it, I mean that it has made one such application, in November 1988, for something which is described as a `log loader', a special purpose implement added to the front of the tractor-not a standard tractor part. I really think that companies such as this and, indeed, members of parliament who write letters to the paper on their behalf should be better informed about what the opportunities available to them are. I would hope that Waltanna Tractors would make the appropriate application, and that may be of some general assistance to the company.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. As I understand the Minister, he is agreeing that there is an anomaly in the Government's legislative procedures with respect to duty. Am I to understand that we accept that anomaly, which is easily correctable, and use a device that may or may not circumvent it? After all, is this not exactly the same sort of assistance to the tractor industry as the Government is prepared to offer to the Sarich company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest of respect, if the honourable senator understands me to be saying that, he may understand that but he does not understand anything else. He is talking about an anomaly and a device to avoid an anomaly. It is not an anomaly for a manufacturing business to pay duty on imported components, and it never has been. In so far as there is a device, as the honourable senator puts it, to avoid the payment of duty, particularly in respect of manufactured goods which are subsequently exported, there are two ways of dealing with the anomaly, and the device, so-called, has been written into the Australian tariff law for as long as-well, I cannot think of when.
—You have a policy that forces these people offshore. That is what he is complaining about.
—I am delighted by Senator Alston's juvenile wisdom on this matter. He does not understand it any better than Senator MacGibbon does.
—I read the letter and the--

—What I am saying to the honourable senator is that if we have a tariff regime at all, we will inevitably have tariff duties on certain components brought into the country. If those components used in the process of manufacture are components which are not made in Australia, there will be a commercial tariff concession granted if somebody applies for it. That is the system. The honourable senator might not like it. That is the system.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, if the goods which are manufactured are to be exported, there will be a by-law for export scheme applicable, as there always has been in the tariff system. A by-law for export will be available to the manufacturer who exports his goods and the by-law is available in respect of the imported componentry. That is the system. It is not an anomaly and it is not a device; it is the system. If the honourable senator does not understand it after his lengthy experience as shadow Minister for Customs, it is time he did. I suggest that he go back to the books and try to understand the tariff system and how it operates if he is going to make any sense at all as a shadow Minister for Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in the course of my answer today to Senator Macklin on aid programming, I did not disagree with an assertion he made along the way that there was nothing budgeted for the International Fund for Agricultural Development this financial year, 1989-90. In fact, as I should have recalled, $1m has been budgeted to cover our existing replenishment obligations, and I should have mentioned that. The question in issue remains, however, whether Australia will participate in the third replenishment, which is due to take place and which will require a further payment from us in 1993-94, and that is the matter that is still under review.

—Yesterday Senator Schacht asked me a question relating to the arrest and detention of the Burmese Opposition Leader, Aung San Suu Kyi. I can now confirm that information was received yesterday afternoon that Aung San Suu Kyi gave up her hunger strike on 1 August.
—I heard that on the news the day before.

—Well, it had not been confirmed. Senator Hill, with his new exalted status, might have lines of access which are denied to us lesser mortals, but we do not respond to every passing rumour, we respond only to confirmed evidence. She gave up her hunger strike after receiving assurances from the military regime about the treatment of her detained senior party colleagues. I can also confirm that she is now reported to be fast regaining her health and full physical capacity, even though, obviously, Senator Hill knew that already and does not need to have any such reassurance. The Government will continue to follow the situation in Myanmar closely and we hope that the restrictions on Aung San Suu Kyi and other opposition members which still remain, and which are still just as indefensible, will soon be lifted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is listed on the Notice Paper today that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade will present to the Senate its report on visits to Australia by nuclear-armed ships. Yet in this morning's newspapers prior to the presentation of that report, and contrary to Standing Orders and to long established practice, there are substantial press reports purporting to summarise the report, and some aspects of the report with a particular bias. Accordingly, I have just some minutes ago given to you a letter, addressed to you as President, raising the concern of members of the Committee that there has been a breach of parliamentary privilege. I, with other members of the Committee, brought this to the attention of the Chairman of the Committee. I understand from him that he will be following this up very carefully at the next meeting of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know of any member of the Committee, Opposition or Government, who is not concerned about this. I am concerned that the disclosure may have come from deliberate leaks to the press by someone close to the Committee, if not a member of the Committee. Secondly, and more generally, I am concerned that the media has facilitated this breach even though it is well known in the media that it is contrary to Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't start impugning the staff before you know what you are talking about.

—I hear Senator Collins. I am not impugning staff; I am not impugning anybody. I am raising this matter as a general breach of the long established parliamentary privilege of the Senate. It is a grave breach, and it is right that we refer to it today in the Senate and that it be followed up. Accordingly, Mr President, I have, with my colleagues, given a letter to you about this matter and I ask for your consideration in the usual way.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Newman proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The record of the Hawke Labor Government in failing Australian women.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Labor Government has utterly failed Australian women, and I am talking about where it counts. It has failed Australian women in the basic fundamentals. This Government's economic mismanagement and its policy of high interest rates have been to the detriment of every Australian woman.
—Ha, ha!
—You might think it's a laughing matter, Senator Button.

—Senator Button does think it is a laughing matter. Senator Button says there is nothing the Government can do about first home owners losing their homes. Single women trying to make it on their own and be self-reliant are finding it increasingly difficult to acquire and retain a home of their own. Under this Government's policies it is getting more and more difficult for them to do so. Married women, women who are contributing to the maintenance of a family budget, are finding it difficult too. Even with a joint income these days, repaying the housing loan for an Australian family is becoming almost impossible to cope with. The Housing Industry Association told us only recently that 500,000 Australian families are at risk of losing their homes due to the high interest rate policies of this Government. The present economic situation and high interest rates have given rise to more problems for women than the Government cares to acknowledge. The Real Estate Institute of Australia says that in the March quarter of this year the average home loan repayment in Melbourne required 34.2 per cent of the median family income. Last year it was only 25.7 per cent. In Sydney, 41.1 per cent of the family income was needed in the March quarter to service a family loan, compared with 31.7 per cent a year ago-a 10 per cent increase over a year. Of course, both those figures are far and away above the traditional limit for loans of 25 per cent of income which was applied by lending institutions to assess applicants' ability. This situation is affecting women in a very real way. It goes to the core of their being and their need to keep a roof over their own head and their families' heads.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just a question of housing. The Marriage Guidance Council (MGC) tells us that Federal Government's economic solution of high interest rates is contributing to marital stress and breakdowns and associated problems, such as high levels of sick leave, homelessness and youth problems. The Marriage Guidance Council claims that high home loan interest rates and house prices are causing more couples to seek professional marriage guidance. I am told that in Victoria there was a 25 per cent increase in the number of couples who saw the MGC between April and May this year; 1,981 couples were counselled in May. This figure represents only 80 per cent of those who sought help because one in five had to be turned away, put on a waiting list or referred to welfare.

In Hobart this month, the Marriage Guidance Council tells me, 40 people were turned away because its budget is now in deficit. That is because it has had to help so many people who cannot even afford the set fees. It escapes me how Government members can sit there and make comments like Senator Button did a few months ago that even if first homes are being put out of the reach of ordinary Australians there is little the Government can do. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, says that if he was in France he would be given the Legion d'Honneur, and the United States would dream up some congressional medal for him for his efforts on the economy. We know what we in this country would give him-the order of the boot. It is women who constantly suffer in regard to home affordability. They also suffer the family stress that goes with the breakup of marriages and the associated family problems.

Let us turn to small business. Small business is the largest single employer group in this country. It accounts for nearly 52 per cent of the total private sector work force. There were 248,700 women in small business in 1986-87, which were the latest figures I could get. That in itself was an increase of 15 per cent on a couple of years before. A third of all small businesses are owned by women. Most women start small businesses for two or three reasons. One reason is so that they can have flexible working hours to suit themselves-something which under this Government they have no hope of gaining. The accord between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government has been an unholy accord as far as women are concerned because they cannot get the flexible working hours that they need. There has also been an increasing trend for firms to contract services out and increased technology, which reduces the start-up costs for small businesses. Many women, like men, operate their businesses on an overdraft, and we all know what has happened to overdrafts under this Government's high interest policies. People are paying 23, 24 and 25 per cent to service an overdraft, thus crippling their small business.

How does this Government expect women, and men, to pay their overdrafts, housing loans and everything else that has to come out of their budgets and maintain an adequate standard of living? Mandrake the magician, commonly known as the Treasurer, keeps saying that everything is economically on track and that all will be okay with just a wave of his magic wand. However, he has been wand-waving for seven Budgets now and he has not yet pulled the rabbit out of the hat. I do not believe that he can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or brought home the bacon.
—He has not brought home the bacon, either, and he has not a feather to fly with.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to inflation, having had a good look at interest rates and small business. Any woman, married or single, is finding it difficult to budget with the current escalation of costs. Women know what inflation is doing to the budgets of Australians. They do not need to read about it in the newspapers. Every time they open their purses they know what has happened to this country. I think the Treasurer of this country needs some instruction. Let me remind the members of the Government what has happened to prices. I have some figures for Hobart, which are replicated all over the country. I have figures for 1983 when this Government came into office and I have figures for this year. The price of a kilogram of laundry detergent has gone from $2.49 to $4.18; a bottle of strawberry jam from $1.30 to $1.90; a loaf of white bread from 83c to $1.16; a litre of milk from 74c to 88c; cornflakes from $1.15 to $2.41; baked beans from 60c to 86c; and petrol from 48.1c to 61.8c. Those are some of the prices that the women in Hobart are having to contend with under the inflation that has been presided over by this Government.

Let us look at what has happened to car prices under the Hawke Labor Government-and, after all, Senator Button has had a great interest in this area. When the Fraser Government left office, 29 1/2 working weeks, at average weekly earnings of $231.90, were needed to buy a six-cylinder family car which was then priced at $6,850. Last year, 41.4 working weeks were needed to buy that family car although average weekly earnings had gone up to $483, which is more than double the 1983 rate. The price of the car had gone up to $20,000. That is the reality of what has happened under this Government in terms of inflation.

With the inability to control inflation and bring down interest rates, women have been limited in their freedom of choice. That is, after all, what we claim that we all want for women. Many of them have been forced into the work force against their will. A recent study estimated that 38 per cent of the women in the work force were not there because they wanted to be. These are the women that we call economic conscripts. They are forced to work just to make their family ends meet and to keep a roof over their heads. These women are resentful of the Government because it has them in a financial bind. For many of them with small children, half of their wages at least are wiped out with the cost of child-care, the Medicare levy and tax.

Today Senator Reynolds, and Senator Richardson who spoke after her, tried to make much of what the Government has been doing in the area of child-care. The fact is that a lot of this is jolly talk-talk, talk, talk. There are inadequate resources. The fact of the matter is that the Government has no effective child-care policy. Consultations, brochures and talk take the place of adequate action. Right across the nation there has been an overwhelming plea for affordable and available child-care but the Government has ignored these pleas. Two hundred and fifty thousand women have joined the full time work force in the past decade. Women now account for 40 per cent of the work force. So there is an overwhelming need for extra child-care places.

A family with two infant children and earning more than $32,000 a year will have to pay $260 a week for 40 hours of child-care. For some lower income families, a 20 per cent increase in the child-care bill will put their daily child-care bill in excess of their daily income. Even at expensive child-care centres, places are few and far between and people are registering for places at birth. The Government is neglecting its commitment to provide in real terms a program to ensure that parents and children have access to quality child-care, regardless of cultural background, disability or geographic isolation and in proportion to income. Women, we know, are now taking children to lectures. Women are taking children to work or they are having them come to work after school. In my home town of Launceston I am told by a child-care centre that has already lost a number of children since the fee rises on 1 July that some of those children are now being left alone at home or are going back to granny for her to raise the next generation.

The fee relief that Senator Richardson was trying to talk to us about is simply a question of $2.50 a week. A family with three children is getting an extra $7.50 a week but since 30 June its costs have gone up by $60. Some help! It is sheer hypocrisy for the Government to say that it wants more women in the work force and then, on the other hand, to deny those women adequate child-care. The 30,000 child-care places that Mr Keating has been saying he will produce over four years, by 1992, is not enough even if they are provided. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has stated that 80,000 to 90,000 mothers, each with an estimated 1.5 children, say they would rejoin the work force now but they cannot find affordable or adequate child-care. If one estimates that 40 to 50 per cent of these women are looking for formal child-care, 60,000 child-care places are needed immediately-not half that number by 1992.

The Government's track record is full of rhetoric. One has only to look at the way it treats its own employees. I have not time today to go into this in great detail; I have done so over and over again in this place. The Government cannot produce a child-care policy for the Defence Force personnel it sends thousands of miles from their extended families. Yet it spends a lot of time trying to convince employers in the private sector that, on the grounds of productivity, they should provide child-care for their employees. Let us see the Government lead by example.

The Government is also failing in the area of equal opportunity for its employees. Back in March this year the Australian Council of Trade Unions said that probably the most disturbing aspect of the Federal Government's attempt to legislate against discrimination has been the number of government departments that have still not submitted equal employment opportunity plans. In fact, as the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) was attacking private companies for failing to comply with the affirmative action legislation, his own Department still had not submitted its plans. It is just not good enough that the Federal Government pushes private enterprise around on the subject of equal opportunity but does not produce the goods itself. There are many examples of this that I could give, but time makes it very difficult. The Canberra Times said in its editorial:
There is some evidence that the affirmative action program changed virtually nothing in the Public Service except the modus operandi of senior administrators.

Let us just look at one small example. Senator Reynolds might like to take this home and study it. It is just a straw poll I conducted myself in recent weeks on the subject of Commonwealth cars. Has Senator Crowley ever thought of how many drive her around in Commonwealth cars? In Western Australia there are two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two what?

—There are only two women who drive Commonwealth cars in Perth. In Canberra, where I understand there are 147 Commonwealth car drivers, we may be lucky; five of them are women. Let the Commonwealth put its own house in order.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of health because for women that also has to be an economic issue. There are 600,000 women aged over 40 and in the work force. They are the group in danger of developing breast cancer. A total of 1,200,000 women over 40 have to care for dependants. Those women are in the danger group for breast cancer, which kills about 2,200 women every year in Australia. But this Government has a wretched record in its approach to breast cancer. Even though it will try to tell us that something is being done about it in this Budget, the Government really has done no more than put its toe in the water. This is the only X-ray for which one cannot get a Medicare rebate.

Last night the Government said it will extend the breast and cervical screening program for a further two years at an additional cost of $0.6m. This does nothing to implement the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council which five years ago said that all women over 40 should be screened for breast cancer. What a joke that is when we see that in this Budget over $40m has been given as a contribution to sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Elite sports.

—For elite sports; I thank Senator Puplick. The Government can find only $0.6m to try to save the 2,200 women who die from breast cancer every year. This Government gives kicking a ball higher priority than women's health. On the 60 Minutes program on 5 March, the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, when asked about Government spending on screening programs for breast cancer, said that they will cost us about $50m a year and we have to make sure that it is spent in the most responsible, high quality way. He said, `You cannot go along and have an X-ray in this country just to see if there is anything wrong with you'. What sort of an attitude is that from the Minister for Health of this nation?
—It is what he calls preventive health.

—Yes, he likes to talk about preventive health, but I understand that the cost of treating the cases of breast cancer diagnosed each year is in the area of $100m. It would cost $50m to prevent them happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the realities of what this Government has done. It has given us masses of glossies; a booklet on women's health that does not include anything about breast cancer; a glossy national agenda for women which is not specific only to women anyway; a women in sport glossy which came out in 1985; two papers on women in advertising which have not been made public; a booklet entitled Women in Advertising, Sex Portrayal in the Media which is soon to be released; and recently there has been a glossy called Child Care in the Work Place, which is basically a study into the cost and benefits of employer provided child-care with a do it yourself survey of child-care needs in the back. There is lots of gloss with this Government; there is not much substance. Let me just tell honourable senators one highlight that the women's Budget for 1989-90 produced. I was reading it this morning. It says that one of the highlights of last year's Budget-the highlight of the Government's activities last year-was that it achieved a chapter on non-sexist language for the first time in the Government Style Manual. Can it possibly be serious? How many Australian women would consider this a highlight, for goodness sake?

The true failure of the Hawke Labor Government in its dealings with women is shown by its abject failure to deal with the economic imperatives. Any Australian woman managing a family budget could do better than Mandrake Keating. Any Australian woman knows the reality of our economic situation better than he does. Australian women know how much things cost and how far the dollar has to stretch. If Mandrake took a few lessons from Australian women maybe he would get his spells right. As it is, all he can do is turn a hawk into a turkey.

An increasing percentage of Australian women are showing up in studies as being seriously concerned at the Government's economic management. It will be enough to change their vote and I warn Government members that they cannot take this lightly. A litany of measures on the periphery of this subject will do nothing to convince Australian women that they have any understanding of their needs and the problems they are facing. Australian women have already seen the Government's priorities and they are not in the area of economic management which is the area in which Australian women are hurting so desperately, as are their husbands, their lovers, their sons, their daughters. This Government stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this matter of public importance this afternoon. It gives me the opportunity, if anyone on the Opposition benches is interested, to table the National Agenda for Women: Implementation Report. Senator Newman has made a great play of rhetoric and said that the Government has not done enough. The Government is prepared to scrutinise closely its record in terms of the National Agenda for Women and in tabling this document I invite Senator Newman to read it and see what progress has been made. Unlike Senator Newman I would not boast and claim that all has been done for Australian women. That is probably because so little was done by predominantly Liberal-National Party governments over the last many years. I would not talk too loudly if I were Senator Newman about the Opposition's policies-what we know of them-in relation to the status of women.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman started by talking about high interest rates; asking what we were doing for single women; and asking what we were doing about prices and child-care-a rhetoric of accusations. But what does the Opposition intend to do about interest rates? I have a press clipping here from the Australian of 3 August. `Mortgage Relief Not on the Agenda' says Senator Newman's Leader. Fifteen million dollars was added to the mortgage rent relief scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rank and file of Australian families?

—I challenge Senator Newman to go out into the marketplace in Tasmania and talk to her constituents, to ask them which they would rather have-`Mortgage relief not on the agenda, says Peacock', or $15m additional to what the Hawke Government gives. That is the first thing that demolishes Senator Newman's arguments about interest rates because she, as the Opposition spokesman, cannot come up with any alternative.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, she goes on about what we are doing in relation to child-care, what we are doing in relation to planning for single parents and for older women. Let me challenge her to detail her child-care policy. I have never heard of an Opposition child-care policy. Where is its equal opportunity policy? When will it be released? Will the Opposition maintain the family allowance supplement? Senator Stone, who unfortunately is not in the chamber-I do not suppose he is very interested in debating the status of Australian women-is very keen on demolishing assistance to Australian women and their families. Senator Newman is the one who lacks substance. She gets on her feet and does nothing but criticise the Government in terms of what it is doing in relation to the status of women. I must admit that I think I would prefer Senator Newman's colleague from South Australia to be the Opposition spokesperson. At least Senator Vanstone made her position quite clear in a statement to the Liberal Women's Convention-I think it would have been last year-when she quoted the Opposition's former leader, John Howard, saying, `What unites us is greater than that which divides us'. That was her response to dealing with the National Agenda for Women. I have always remembered that particular comment from Senator Vanstone because, for all the questions and the disagreements that we might have across this chamber, I believe that Senator Vanstone is committed to the National Agenda for Women. I imagine that she could be relied upon to fight for it to be implemented under the unlikely possibility of a coalition government. What does Senator Newman say about the National Agenda for Women? I will be closely checking the Hansard, but I did not pick up anything that indicated that Senator Newman, as the new Opposition spokesperson, was in the least bit interested in maintaining a commitment to the National Agenda for Women.

It is of great concern that an Opposition spokesperson is not prepared to give bipartisan support to the National Agenda for Women. Around this country Australian women recognise that the Hawke Government has been the first government to develop comprehensive policies for women and to be prepared to monitor how those policies are implemented. It is well known that the Australian Government is the first to adopt the United Nations Forward Working Strategies towards the year 2000 in terms of recognising the need to lift the status of women around the world, and the Australian Government is proudly the first government to implement its own Forward Working Strategies through the National Agenda for Women. It is also the first government in the world to produce a women's budget. Senator Newman is long on rhetoric about all the alleged sins of the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Answer the facts, Senator. There are plenty of facts you have to answer.

—I am coming to those facts in plenty of time. Senator Newman was very light on facts. We did not get anything of her policies. I come back to the fact that this is the only government that has been prepared to introduce comprehensive status of women policies. I now come to the implementation report. I challenge Senator Newman to come into this place and tell me three things: Firstly, will she guarantee that the Opposition will adopt, on a bipartisan basis, the National Agenda for Women? Secondly, I ask her, because she made such efforts to denounce the work of this Government, to come into this chamber and, on behalf of the Opposition, detail what her alleged government-she is boasting that the Opposition could be in government-would do about breast cancer screenings?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone sits over there saying `Cut, cut, cut'. John Hewson continually talks about cutbacks in expenditure. What would the Opposition do in the area of women's health policy? Would it be maintained? Finally, in regard to these three challenges I would like to know precisely what the Opposition's child-care policy is. Again, we hear absolutely nothing about the Opposition's child-care policy, about whether the Opposition would be able to maintain the very fine record of the Hawke Government. I certainly am extremely sceptical.

Far from failing Australian women, this Government is encouraging and supporting them and presenting them with real choices in their lives. When the Government came to power in 1983, only 44 per cent of girls completed year 12; now almost 60 per cent complete year 12; very recognisable progress. In 1983, the unemployment rate for women was 10.4 per cent. By June this year it had fallen to 6.6 per cent; again, clearly an improvement in regard to job opportunities for Australian women. By 1992 this Government will have provided an extra 98,000 child-care places, trebling the number of places available in 1983.

Under this Government the standard pension has increased by 8.3 per cent in real terms compared with a fall of 2.5 per cent over the seven years of the previous Government. Assistance to families has increased dramatically under this Government. Family allowance rates are now $9 per week for the first three children and $12 per week for each subsequent child. Could we rely on John Stone to maintain that kind of support for Australian families? Other payments for children have increased, too. The family allowance supplement-which is a Brian Howe and Hawke Government initiative-ensures for the first time that significant financial assistance is provided for the children of low income families.

This short list of facts and figures could be expanded on considerably if there were more time. What is important from this listing of achievements is the positive impact these changes have had on the day to day lives of Australian women. For the first time in Australian history we are providing women with choices in their lives. We are saying to them that is okay to stay on at school, that it is okay for them to expect the better paying jobs that come from a better education. We recognise that for most women their first priority is their children and we are providing women with the support to combine paid employment with child rearing if they choose.

For those who stay at home with children for longer periods, payments for families provide meaningful levels of assistance. The question is: What would the Opposition do with these payments if it were to win the next election? On the one hand, one half of the Opposition says that all government payments will be cut back and that the Government is spending far too much on health, education and housing assistance. Meanwhile, the other half of the Opposition says that this Government is forcing women not to have children because of the cost of living. Opposition members should make up their minds. The Opposition is trying to manipulate women into believing that the abolition of Medicare will not affect their families, that cutting back on education spending will not affect their families, that cutting back on funding for services to the aged and the disabled will not affect their families. We are presented with a saccharine sweet picture of the family on the cover of John Howard's Future Directions while the Opposition prepares to demolish funding for the very services which support and nurture the family.

The electorate was given the option to give the Opposition's divisive policies a go in 1987 and it rejected them. In any future election the electorate will be equally able to see through the image of cosy families to discern that the very supports of the family would be knocked out by Opposition policies. I cannot pretend that this Government has simple answers for women. Neither does this document pretend to do that. But this document indicates that this Government takes women's issues seriously and we are prepared to monitor closely and give a yearly account of what we have achieved.

The economic circumstances that the Government faces are daunting. We have been honest with the electorate. We have not pretended that there are simple solutions. What we have done is ensure that one section of Australian society is not asked to bear a disproportionate share of the difficulties which have affected the economy. The Government's commitment to equity remains firm. `Equity' is not a word that I believe Senator Newman used in her speech. We have protected the very poorest and, despite the economic climate, we have increased the assistance they receive. This is important for women as women are the largest group of pensioners and are over-represented in low income groups. Women appreciate the importance of family allowances, the family allowance supplement and other payments for children. They are mostly responsible for paying the expense of the household and know the difference these payments make to the household budget. They also recognise that the child support scheme introduced by this Government means that they can now receive regular maintenance payments at a decent level. These are changes which have improved women's lives.

The Hawke Government is providing women with hope and the concrete assistance that they need. We are not failing Australian women. This Government is also providing women with a way out of their dependency on pensions and low incomes. The Government's policy on retirement incomes recognises that women's broken involvement in the labour force has meant that they have been unable to accumulate significant levels of superannuation in the past. We have modified the arrangements to better suit women's employment patterns, their broken patterns and their particular experience. In relation to that, honourable senators may be interested to know that Neville Norman, a well known economist, praised this move by the Government in its Budget announcements last night. He said this morning on, I believe, Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio, in response to a question about superannuation:

It's directed particularly to improving the position in relation to women. There is by the way a complete women's budget statement, which I spent part of the night reading. It's very good actually. It's written in more understandable language and I'd advise men as well to read that.
He later said:
Yes, it's very well done. I would actually recommend it. I read it out of intrigue and I kept reading and it tells you a lot more . . .
And so it goes on. I believe that that is considerable praise from Mr Neville Norman, who I understand is a conservative economist.

Let me return to initiatives under the Hawke Government that have assisted Australian women. The jobs, education and training (JET) program is about encouraging sole parents into employment. Senator Newman did not mention the JET program. I do not suppose she has bothered to make inquiries about how it is operating in her home State. She just talked about child-care and said that we were doing nothing in this area. I presume she has not visited one of the new centres that I know have been opened in her home State.

TALK.START.PARA: —You presume too much, Senator.
—How can the honourable senator attend, how can she enjoy--
—They are very concerned about your policies and they are losing children who can't afford to stay. They are the facts in Tasmania now.

—Let me ask the honourable senator this very simple question: how can she on one hand enjoy the options to go and visit new child-care centres that we have provided and perhaps bask in a little reflected--
—That the taxpayer has provided, Senator.

—All right, the taxpayer. But because of this Government's priorities, taxes have been directed to child-care. Neither the honourable senator, John Stone, Andrew Peacock nor John Hewson have been able to reassure me, let alone Australian families, that the cutbacks that they are continually referring to will not impact on child-care. I will be delighted if Senator Newman can come into this place with policies and commitments that she will not go back on, without Senator Stone contradicting, to reassure me and to reassure Australian women. But I am not holding my breath waiting for that. The Government strategy for improving the lives of women is outlined in the national agenda. The document provides comprehensive details on strategies which the Government will implement. The agenda was not based on the whims of government; it represents the aspirations of women for their lives. The Government consulted with women in drawing it up. We continue to base policies affecting women on the needs of women, as expressed by women. In this year's Budget the women's health strategy draws on the needs of women for their health services. Likewise, before the retirement incomes policy was finalised the Government asked women for their views.

SPEECH.PARA: This consultative approach contrasts with the Opposition's bossy generalisations about women's lives which owe more to the fantasies of ad men than to the needs of Australian women. Nor does the Government assume that Australian women are a homogeneous group. We recognise that young women have different needs. We understand that women fleeing violent relationships need unique services, and we appreciate that women from non-English speaking backgrounds want different services again. But we understand that government has a responsibility to continue to improve opportunities and services for Australian women.

Against this I place the record of the Opposition. For all its rhetoric there was very little to show for women while it was in government. Among its achievements prior to 1983 we could list a recession that led to record rates of unemployment for women and teenage girls; and social security policies that condemned older women, sole parents and their children and the unemployed to lives of bitter poverty. Senator Newman was not in the Senate in those days but she conveniently forgets the record of the Fraser years. If Senator Newman can convince me that Andrew Peacock is a new broom, if she can convince me that Senator Stone, John Hewson and John Elliott will not be the ones to dictate the policies of the coalition, I will welcome her announcements. But I am afraid the Opposition has a long way to go before it assures Australian women that it is committed to any more than just political attacks on the present Government, which is doing the very best it can for all Australian women under tough economic circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon a matter of public importance introduced by Senator Newman which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the Hawke Labor Government in failing Australian women.

I remind the Senate, and Senator Newman, that while the Labor Government certainly holds sway at the moment and has, of course, since 1983 it does not control the Senate and while the Liberals are in opposition they and we combine to hold a majority in here. So much of the Government's legislative program can, if a majority in this place believes it to be inequitable to one group or another, be hijacked, shanghaied, amended, opposed, done to death or whatever. The fact of the matter, of course, is that many--

TALK.START.PARA: —And passed.

—And occasionally passed. Senator Crowley has reminded me of the fact that the majority of the Government's legislation which has gone through the Parliament since 1983 has in fact gone through, not with the support of the Democrats but with the support of the Liberal and National parties, either together or separately. Of course, many of the things that are disadvantaging women; that are keeping women as the majority group living below the poverty line; that are hindering women in taking full advantage of some of the legislative programs that should be offering them full choice; have gone through this Parliament with the support of the Liberal and National parties. I refer to the delay of six weeks to the consumer price index increases in pensions in 1986 and the fact that 45-year-old women were required to go off the Class B widow's pension and onto unemployment benefit when their youngest child turned 16. Those sorts of things have gone through this place only because of the support of the Opposition parties. So to quite a large extent the Opposition has contributed to the parlous state in which many women now find themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years women in Australia have had to put up with a great deal of prejudice, a great many hurdles, and all the inevitable inequities that go with that prejudice and those hurdles, as well as legal impediments preventing them from participating fully in the community. They have ranged from the most extraordinary judicial decisions which have defined women as non-persons, for one reason or another, through to the inability of women to vote in many States, or indeed to stand for election to parliament in some States until the early 1920s, and things such as women needing different grounds for divorce than their husbands needed to divorce them; lower pay scales; limited access to education and the employment and promotion that followed from that education and so on. Women in Australia have confronted all those issues through the decades and centuries. Rural, migrant and Aboriginal women have suffered from all those problems, plus additional ones. They have not been fully overcome.

We still have a situation where a man's average weekly earnings are $521.80 and a woman's, on average, are $338.30. About 3.15 million women are in the Australian work force but only 1.9 million of those are in full time employment, the other 1.2 million being employed part time. Australia does not have an across the board system with things such as permanent part time work with the pro rata benefits-access to superannuation and so on-that would allow women, and men too, to share the income earning and child rearing in families. Inevitably women are still clustered into the lowest paying jobs. A total of 73.8 per cent of all clerical positions are held by women; over 60 per cent of service, sport and recreation positions are held by women; and over half of all sales positions are held by women. Inevitably that means that they are in a minority, sometimes a quite small minority, in the higher paying, more promotion geared positions in administration, as well as executive and managerial positions. As a consequence of much of that women have limited access to superannuation. Considerably fewer than 40 per cent of employed women belong to some sort of superannuation scheme compared with over 60 per cent of men. That means that not only are they disadvantaged during their working life, but also they are considerably more disadvantaged than men in their post-retirement years.

Many of the problems that women have are compounded for those who live in country areas or come from a migrant background. Women as a group spend more time below the poverty line than men as a group do. The pressure on rural women is much greater than that on their female colleagues in city areas. There are problems with access to public transport, the cost of private transport, the lack of educational facilities, the high cost of petrol and the high cost of all goods, given transport costs and the fact that freight is a component of sales tax.

Lack of decent affordable child-care affects women in rural areas much more than it does even women in the city and there is that additional pressure on women in rural areas to fulfil a multitude of roles as times get tougher on the land. I must say that if I hear one more woman who works with her husband on a property call herself `only a farmer's wife' I may commit an assault. Those women work on tractors and among the stock. They take their role in planting, harvesting and so on and then go back into the home and accept all the additional responsibilities that women have in the unpaid work force in the home of rearing children and getting the shopping, the cooking, the cleaning and so on done. Yet they will still persist in saying that they are only a farmer's wife.

There are, of course, fewer health services available in country areas and there is the additional stress of knowing that your child is often going to have to leave home to go to school and almost always leaves home to get a job. The isolated children's allowance has been eroded under this Government by inflation and by an unsympathetic ear as far as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is concerned. Migrant women face the sorts of problems that come from language difficulties, from being in many jobs that are non-unionised and from dealing with unions that perhaps do not particularly care about the role of women in the work force.

Ninety-five per cent of all outworkers are women and large numbers of these are migrant women. They are working for the sort of pittance and under conditions that are not much different from the sort that women had to confront in the nineteenth century when they were forced to work long hours for very small pay. While women generally are still much worse off economically and as far as choice is concerned, both in education and in employment, than men are, there are a number of groups of women who are by comparison particularly badly off and those are women in rural areas and migrant women.

Of course, many of the problems facing women in the community are the results of traditional attitudes about the roles of men and women. But others have had their basis in legislation or often, perhaps more properly put, the failure of governments to legislate or to lead the way for change in some way. In Question Time today, for example, the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) said that the Government's top priority in child-care was community-based child-care. Yet how can she, we or the community expect the private sector to look to work-based child-care as is being done not only in the United States of America but also in Europe if the Government will not look at government funded work-based child-care? It is important that we look to see what is happening in other countries and how not only the public sector but the private sector is coping with, and indeed helping, women in the work force. I might add that the whole attitude towards the status of women in the community has not been helped by comments made by people like Senator Puplick towards the Minister I was just referring to. He alleged a couple of months ago, with no real proof, that Senator Reynolds is on the front bench, not because of the number of neurones she can put together, but because of the number of chromosomes she can. That sort of comment made in the Parliament by a frontbencher from the Opposition parties does not do a great deal to improve the status of women in this place or outside it. I would suggest that Senator Newman take Senator Puplick quietly away in a corner and, after she has beaten him up a little, tell him that this is perhaps not the way that he ought to be talking about women generally. Senator Newman has a little work to do on her own colleagues.

Senator Newman also claims that the Government has failed the women of Australia in a wide range of areas, and I mentioned earlier that not only has her own Party given the Government the support it needed to deny women real choices and a decent standard of living but also it has actively opposed some of the measures which were in the interests of women in the community.

Women in Australia, I guess, have a lot to be grateful to the Labor Party for-in opposition and in government. Not as much, I acknowledge, as I would like to see. They also have a lot to be grateful for because from time to time the Democrats have been able to use a balance of power in the Senate. For example, back in 1981 under the then Liberal Government, Senator Chaney tried to get through the Parliament a quite draconian piece of legislation that would have punished the wives and children of men whose unions had taken them out on strike by denying them access to a range of social welfare benefits. We managed by a combination in the Senate to stop that.

On the other hand, Opposition members in large numbers opposed both the sex discrimination legislation and the affirmative action legislation when they were introduced into this place. Women in Australia would also have been less hurt by the current Labor Government if some of its more draconian cost-cutting measures had not been supported by the Liberal and National parties. As I said earlier, in late 1986 pensioners would not have faced the delay by six weeks of the consumer price indexation of their pensions had the Opposition joined the Australian Democrats in voting against that measure.

I mentioned the problems facing 45-year-old women taken off the widow's class B pension and put on unemployment benefit. Cuts to Austudy for 15-year-olds in their last two years of school caused havoc, particularly to many sole parent families where the head of the family was a woman. She simply had to take the child out of school because there was not enough money coming into the family for her to be able to afford the excursions, the books and the adequate clothing that a child needs.

Senator Newman mentioned high interest rates and the problems they are causing to women who are trying to buy their own homes and who are forced out into the work force, not from choice but because they need to supplement their husbands' incomes. That would not have occurred without the enthusiastic support of the Opposition for deregulation. I point out that a couple of months ago the Opposition voted against a measure to give mortgage relief to home buyers. The Opposition also supported the sales tax legislation introduced by this Government that increased housekeeping costs-that increased the price of milk products and, worse, soy milk products for families who have a child with an allergy. Fruit juice products and so on have all contributed to the housekeeping hardship faced by women in the community. Of course, imposing tertiary fees on students at university will make matters worse for many women and perhaps change the profiles of universities.

There are two remaining problems that I will not have time to discuss today that are facing women in the community. One is the need to change the United Nations system of national accounts definition of gross domestic product so that the unpaid work done by women, in particular in the home and the community, is recognised as productive. The other is to change attitudes of the business community to women, from promotion practices to maternity leave, to child care-to all the things that European employers recognise as contributing to productivity and to equitable work practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -Today we are discussing a matter of public importance raised by Senator Newman which is examining `the record of the Hawke Labor Government in failing Australian women'. Senator Reynolds in her speech asked what we would do for women with regard to breast cancer. In answer to the question, at least we have a commitment to rebate the cost of mammography. The question we would bounce back to her is, `Why has the Government refused to do this?'. If there is so much commitment to women's health, why is not the cost of mammography rebatable? Also, I am interested to find that, during Senator Reynolds's introduction to the Labor contribution to debate on this issue, there seemed to be no men in the chamber on the Labor side who were at all interested in this issue-so much for rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one can escape the impact of this Government's high taxing, high inflation, high interest rate, high indebtedness policies. Older Australians are no exception. In fact, with reduced and often fixed incomes, reduced mobility, and in some cases reduced ability to cope with changes in legislation and regulations, older Australians are particularly vulnerable. Over the next 35 years the number of elderly people in Australia will grow at twice the population rate of Australia as a whole. One-quarter of our population is presently over 50 years of age. In 2021 it will increase to one-third. The fastest growing group will be those over 85.

There are many more women than men at all ages over 65, and among those over 80 there are twice as many women as men. Over 90 per cent of older women live in private dwellings and half of the women over 75 in private residences live alone. So government policy on the aged impacts greatly on older women. As I said, nobody can escape the impact of this Government's high taxing, high inflation, high interest rate, high indebtedness policies. The least able to buffer themselves are the aged, and the bulk of them, as I said before, are women.

Not only are women bearing the brunt of Labor's economic mismanagement but the women in their middle years-the so-called `sandwich generation'-are sandwiched between the responsibility of dependent children, dependent parents and sometimes even dependent grandparents and, as Senator Newman said earlier in the debate, are now also looking after dependent grandchildren because of the low availability of child-care. As I said, 90 per cent of the aged live at home and it often falls to the daughter to assist in a myriad of ways-with transport, arranging for services such as visits to the doctor, shopping, laundry and so on. The Australian Bureau of Statistics is not even prepared to acknowledge the economic effort of unpaid work, the majority of which is undertaken by women. Let me assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if it were not for the army of unpaid workers our aged care bill would be astronomical.

In talking about the aged care bill, let us not be fooled by last night's Budget figures. Assistance to the aged, we were told, is to increase by 11.6 per cent, and we are told that this is a 4 per cent increase in real terms. While this may be true in straight money measurement, all is not as it seems to be. With an ageing population, more people move into this category every year. If we were to calculate or be given the per capita increase for assistance to the aged we would see that it was less than 4 per cent.

As people get older the two things that concern them are their health and their finances. They have every right to be concerned and worried about their health. We have seen recently major changes to nursing home funding and nursing home care. The majority of people in nursing home care are women. A recent study was carried out in Victoria to examine the impact of the new Commonwealth funding arrangements for nursing homes. This study was carried out in 27 Victorian nursing homes. It gives great cause for concern. Four clear conclusions emerged. One hundred and thirty four people were asked to participate in a questionnaire. The first of the four conclusions was as follows:
WORKING CONDITIONS
Working conditions for nurses and other staff are pressured and strained, and this is already causing major stresses in the system.
The second area of concern that was identified was communication with residents. This is what the repondents said:

A rushed atmosphere is discernible in homes which have experienced funding cuts and have accommodated these cuts by staff reductions. Nursing home activities and procedures are being reduced to necessary custodial care and communication with residents and their relatives has declined.

We have just recently had a report presented to us on residents' rights and standards in nursing homes, and we see a sham-Government cuts and changes in funding have produced the very sort of thing that is sought to be corrected in the residents' rights paper: reduced communication with residents and their relatives. The sorts of standards, the sorts of rights, that we ought to be concerned about are being denied because of the funding situation. The third issue that came out of this report was the diminution of choice. The conclusion was:

The overall pattern that was observable was one of paring activities back to medical and nursing necessities in a tense and pressured environment. This is seen as emerging from staffing cuts and from the need to accept only more dependent residents. The creation of a homelike atmosphere is seen as increasingly difficult in this context. The quantity and quality of external activities available to residents had been reduced, meal options were being constrained and residents' wishes were often seen as not being met because of pressure on staff.

A wonderful situation for our elderly people! As I said, the majority of these people are women. Another issue of major concern was that the maintenance of buildings and equipment was a casualty of the reduced funding. So the report talks about working conditions for the staff affecting residents, a reduction of choice, reduction of care and services and a reduction in the capital equipment. The report concluded with the statement that the overwhelming majority of respondents reported anxiety that the situation seemed set only to worsen further-a very different complexion from what we see when the Government talks about its record on aged care.

I must say that I was heartened to see in the Budget the beginnings of the recognition of the particular needs of small communities in rural or remote areas. I hope it is not a case of too little too late. If it is and small rural institutions are forced to close, it will be aged rural women and their carers, mainly women, who will bear the brunt of being moved long distances, if they are residents, or travelling long distances to obtain services and to visit relatives in aged care.

One of the issues that last night's Budget failed to address was the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Eighty-two per cent of expenditure in this scheme is for pensioners and most of these pensioners would be age pensioners. We have had the problem of generic prescribing and brand names being on again, off again and now on again. This is all guaranteed to confuse the elderly. Who are those elderly? They are mainly women. If the never ending changes to the scheme result in the closure of pharmacies, it is again likely to be the less mobile, the elderly and again, mainly women who will be affected.

Older Australians will not be fooled by last night's pre-election hand-outs. They know that Medicare has not meant universal health care. What it has meant is longer waiting lists in public hospitals. Of elderly people, women are more likely to get sick than men and there are more older women. If we were to examine the May 1989 queue of 25,000 people waiting for a bed in a Victorian public hospital, we would have seen mainly women waiting months--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Senator Giles can say `Oh'. The 25,000 will be mainly women waiting months--
—They are queuing up in Flinders Street.

—The honourable senator will have her turn. They have been waiting months for a total hip replacement and much longer for a cataract replacement. I hope that the honourable senator does not need a hip replacement at some stage under Medicare because if she does she will have to wait a long time. Nor will the aged be hoodwinked by Budget hand-outs. What Labor giveth, Labor hath taken away. Over the past five years hundreds of millions of dollars have been stripped from the health funds, placing strains on these funds and the services they can offer, in particular services to the elderly. Some of the money that we have seen in the Budget is just the $200m that has been stripped off the elderly from another source. Those strains on the health funds will not be alleviated by the $20m fix that was offered by the Government in the last session of Parliament. Hopefully, the committee that the Senate has set up will be able to address that issue and try to guide the Government in terms of dealing with it in some sort of decent way.

SPEECH.PARA: The rural aged in isolated communities know that Medicare is not synonymous with universal health care. Where there are no public hospitals available, the sick elderly can be cared for only in their own communities-and that is an important thing when one is old-in private hospitals. For that they need private health insurance. So much for universal health care. Pensioners are struggling to pay their health benefits so they can have the privilege-it seems, under this Labor Government-of being treated in their own community.

The other major problem which affects the elderly and those planning for their old age is their finances. That brings me to the centrepiece of last night's Budget-Mr Howe's Better Incomes: Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century. In November last year the coalition gave Australia its first ever retirement incomes policy. The Government has now given us an Opposition-driven policy. The Government has done nothing about inflation. Keating says that last year's inflation was too high, but then he tells us that the increase in the consumer price index is expected to be little changed at around 7.5 per cent. As a community, we must reduce inflation, but the Government does not apparently have to take a lead in this.

Inflation is eroding the value of retirement savings. Modest savings in traditional investment sources-banks and building societies-are being taxed not just on the earnings on the capital, but on the capital itself. Nothing is being done about these high interest rates, and they are affecting the aged in particular. Keating has presided over massive change to the structure and tax situation of superannuation funds in recent years, particularly with the change which took effect from 1 July. Nothing in the Budget undoes the damage of that new taxing regime. The fact is that superannuation has had an effective tax increase of 1,000 per cent under the robber baron of the Treasury. For people on low incomes, mostly women, there is now less, not more, encouragement to enter a superannuation fund, to try to provide for their own retirement.

Since the 1 July tax cuts, a person on $15,000 a year pays tax of 21c on each extra dollar of wages, leaving 79c of each dollar for immediate spending. However, if the person's employer paid the same $1 into a superannuation fund, the employee would receive only the equivalent of 70c. Great incentive to invest in superannuation-79c in the hand and 70c in the investment fund! I know where many people who are on the breadline would put that money, the 79c in the hand.

There are a number of other initiatives which the Government has put in. I do not have time to discuss them, but they include such things as home equity conversions, which are absolutely hopeless, whereby pensioners can borrow $40,000 against the value of their homes. I am sure there are a lot of pensioners who will be able to pay back $650 a month at 20 per cent interest! Superannuation schemes have also been looked at, and the Government has tried to do things to encourage women to invest in superannuation. Yet we see things like vesting being delayed for six years. What incentive is that? It is a policy which means that women who have not been able to stay in a job for 10 years would not be able to take advantage of that. This Government has failed women, it has failed elderly women, and it is failing all women. The Government will be delivered with the answer in the next election when women of Australia say no to the Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to remind the Senate and the listeners of what we are debating, it is a matter of public importance proposed by Senator Newman. I am not sure whether she is condemning it or not, or just listing it. But as I read it, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the Hawke Labor Government in failing Australian women.

I have heard from both Senator Newman and Senator Patterson contributions that are entirely unpersuasive to this point. In fact, Senator Newman should get marks for what I think Senator Puplick would agree was metaphorical mayhem. We cannot resort to recollections of what Senator Newman was saying, but we had mixed metaphors as though they were going out of fashion, followed by a lovely line which I tried to write down: `A litany of measures on the periphery'. If ever I heard a statement of a litany of measures on the periphery, it was Senator Newman's contribution. That is an excellent assessment of Senator Newman's contribution. Senator, stay over there; stick on the periphery. We will go to the centre, the hard issues, doing things for women, as we have been doing since we got into government.

It is fascinating to discover that those in the Opposition have now learned to spell `women', a bit of an improvement on their performance in the years before the Hawke Government actually put women on the agenda; and it is Labor governments, State and Federal, that have put women on the agenda. It is Labor governments that have the commitment-not only the record-into the future on what they will continue to do for and on behalf of women.

I have in this place a number of times debated issues of concern for women. I remember Senator Hill, from the Opposition, once accusing the Government of creating expectations for women. I was delighted to say then, and I am delighted to say it again, `You bet we have'. It is because we have created expectations, have addressed them all and are looking to keep on doing that that we are the government of defensible record on behalf of women. It is precisely because we have created expectations. Women know that this Government will listen to them. This Government has delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has failed to deliver and you know that, Senator.

—This Government has consulted; this Government has heard from women; this Government is committed to women. I received a copy of Senator Vanstone's paper in my office yesterday and I have to say that it is not bad; it covered most of the issues. As my colleague Senator Reynolds said, the honourable senator has some record in terms of speaking on behalf of women but she has a long way to go before persuading her Opposition colleagues, besides which she is in opposition and her voice is a cry in the wilderness when she tries to convince the Opposition on behalf of women.
—Not for much longer.

—Let us see what the women of Australia say, let alone the men of Australia, at the next election. They know which government has put women on the record, which government has actually consulted with women. It is the Hawke Government that has done that. The Hawke Government consulted extensively, heard what women said, created a national agenda and itemised its priorities, and it is delivering on them. From time to time in this place one hears from the Opposition a litany of those measures at the periphery. The Government knows what the priorities are for women. They are as they have always been-income security, peace in the home and peace internationally, so that they have a place and a haven for themselves and their children. It has never been otherwise. They are the commitments that the Hawke Government has given them through its policies for women and all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Somehow or other Senator Newman believes it is appalling that families that are stuck with bills and difficulties to meet in terms of payments might actually have to go out to work to earn income. Even if I accepted her line-and I would like to make it clear that I do not-that women are being forced into the work force, I would have to say that they have a job to go to. They did not have a job under the previous Government, but they have one under this Government. One and a half million jobs have been created since the Hawke Government came to office in 1983. More than 56 per cent of those jobs have gone to women. That is what this Government has done for women.
