If women are out there in droves being conscripted into the work force I have not heard about it. They are not ringing me to say, `I've got to go to work'. They are ringing me to say, `I am so pleased I can go to work. I want to work at all sorts of things. I want an education to give me better opportunities. I've got them under the Hawke Government'. As Senator Reynolds said, before 1983 44 per cent of girls completed year 12. Now the figure is well over 66 per cent. For the first time ever more than 50 per cent of students in our tertiary institutions are women. Women have got the real gain under the Hawke Government. They have jobs, education, access to health care, Medicare and the benefits that it has for women. They have the things that matter.

What the Opposition says is just amazing. Senator Newman took us through the shopping list. She told us what most everyone knows-that prices rise over time. Prices rise for baked beans and cars. But I am not too sure that her understanding has risen at all. None of that was too exciting. If she wanted to show the way prices have increased, why did she not list the way family incomes have increased? Why did she not list-I think that she was ashamed to do so-what this Government has done through the increased income that it has given families directly-tax-free income under the family allowance and the family allowance supplement?

Who indexed the family allowance for the first time so as to provide a hedge against increasing prices into the future-an absolutely monumental achievement? The Hawke Labor Government did. It did so because it is concerned about women, the costs that women bear on behalf of children and because of their commitment to families. That is on the record. Women appreciate those increases in their family allowance cheques as they come through. Honourable senators opposite should ask them about that, as I have. They say that they see the increase and are pleased to have it. They have also received an increase in the family allowance supplement. As of April last, that has gone to $34.10 per week, tax-free, for a child aged between 13 and 15. What a fantastic commitment! That is the sort of contribution this Government has made to working families on low incomes as well as those on pensions. If they cannot afford the baked beans under the Opposition they will begin to afford them under this Government because we know that payments made to women are spent on children. There is a lot of research to document that and the Government has targeted its increases for and on behalf of children to women through the family allowance and family allowance supplement. They are getting it; they are appreciating it; it is a huge and quite extraordinary contribution to the incomes of families to address the sorts of problems Senator Newman gave as a litany of costs.

I would also want to reiterate the points that Senator Giles made by way of interjection again and again. What are the Opposition's policies? Is the Opposition going to cut the family allowance supplement? Is that what we can conclude from what Senator Stone or Dr Hewson say? They want to see cuts in these areas. Are they going to cut the very things that Senator Newman is in here asking for? We do not know; she is not telling us. As for child-care, how dare Senator Newman stand in here and say that we do not have an adequate child-care policy. We have a comprehensive child-care policy. We have more than doubled the number of places. We have a commitment into the future for an extra 30,000 places. One thousand of those places are employment related. We have the data. Senator Newman calls information glossy; good luck to her. We actually plan on data and information. We have addressed the problems of child-care in the defence forces. Senator Newman is the very same senator who, time and time again in this place, has talked about the dreadful business of child-care that is assisting women to have their children placed into the care of the state, taken away from their nurturing and all of those sorts of things, and then--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crowley is totally misrepresenting me. I have never said anything of the sort in this place. In fact, I am constantly reminding her Government of how it has failed to provide sufficient child-care, especially to its own employees.
—Order! There is no point of order. Please resume your seat. If you feel you have been misrepresented there is a way of dealing with it afterwards.

—Senator Newman can check the record as I have and as I have alluded it to her in the past. It took her a while to realise, `Whoops, I cannot come in here and demand child-care for the defence force spouses but on the other side of the argument be opposed to child-care'. It took a while; we needled her into getting her act together. Her policies, or at least her thinking, is now becoming consistent. We are pleased that she is at least learning that. We have a policy of child-care. We are implementing it. Our policy of child-care, like everything else this Government has done, is comprehensive, thoughtful, properly funded and targeted to those in need. In principle, the child-care policy provides the places and assistance for those at the lowest income level, fee relief for those in the middle level and full tote odds are paid by those who can afford the child-care places. The payment is related to the family income. That is one of the other things this Government has been concerned to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that we need to make clear in this place is that child-care is something of a novelty for the Opposition; so are women as an item on the agenda. But if one goes back to the forward-looking strategies, and one does have to go back to them, one will find about two column-inches devoted to child-care. Can I conclude that the Opposition has abandoned its forward-looking strategies? Is that what I can conclude? Is child-care now going to get a bigger guernsey from the Opposition? Or is it that the forward strategies set Opposition policy and out of all those pages and all that rhetoric devoted to family, two column-inches go to child-care? I do not find that convincing and this Government's record stands.

Of course, it is not enough when you have to start from almost nothing and build against years of neglect under the Fraser Government. Of course we cannot achieve our objective straight away. But the Government is committed; it has its child-care places on the ground; it is increasing those; and it is looking at ways not only to increase the distribution of the places, but also to make sure the delivery of child-care places meets the varying needs of women. Whether women are in rural and isolated areas, whether they need family day care assistance, whether they need after hours school assistance, the Government's child-care policy is there. We have a policy. Senator Newman knows that. She can lag us in the Senate, but we know that that is mischievous and wrong. The Government's policy on child-care is in place and it is on target. It is welcomed and it is good.

The point the honourable senator wanted to make seemed essentially to be that this Government has not done very well for women because it has reduced their income. The facts point to the opposite. This Government has increased opportunities for women in an extraordinary way, providing them with job opportunities, education opportunities and the benefit of health care under Medicare which, as we all know, is of huge benefit to women because women not only seek health services on their own behalf but also, very often, on behalf of those in their care, such as children or elderly folk. Our achievements are on the record. Women in the community are experiencing the benefit of those right now.

Senator Newman's misrepresentation of facts is, at the kindest, due to misunderstanding and at the worst, probably quite mischievous. If Senator Newman wants to go through the cervical and breast screening programs-my colleague Senator Giles will deal with them in more detail-the monetary figure the honourable senator cited is not for an allocation to the services, but for a continuation of a proper evaluation program. I am delighted to hear from Senator Patterson that the Opposition would rebate the cost of mammography in breast cancer screening. My goodness me! Has she checked how much that will cost with either Mr Shack or Dr Hewson? Is she sure that she can win, all the way to the next proposed Budget, and keep that piece of spending? Senator Newman might want child-care for the defence forces. I would be interested to see how she negotiates this, particularly when the Opposition wants to cut everything. Opposition senators come in here and complain about our not doing enough. Opposition policies are totally absent. It has a policy of cost constraint. Senator Stone suggests that things should be cut back in every direction, but will not tell us where. The Opposition criticises us by saying no more than that we are not doing enough. Well, get your act together, troops! Does the Opposition want to spend money in these areas or does it have a policy to cost contain? It is not convincing me. It is certainly not convincing the listening public. The Australian women know that this Government has policies for women and this Government has implemented those policies. It will continue to do so. It is a government on the record and with the record, and it is a government that the women of Australia appreciate and will stay with, for their benefit and for the benefit of all they care for.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that just a few minutes ago Senator Crowley claimed that I oppose child-care and child-care centres. That is quite disgraceful misrepresentation. I do not oppose child-care centres. I have been on the record on many occasions in this place pointing out the inadequacies in the Government's provision of child-care centres, in particular for the defence forces.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. If it is a personal explanation the honourable senator should say what is wrong and not make a speech. I ask you to direct Senator Newman to stick to the personal explanation.
—I call Senator Newman.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. On one occasion a year or so ago, this Government tried to introduce a child-care centre into the Parliamentary Triangle. You will recall that it did so without consultation with the National Trust and without going through the required-
—Senator Newman, you are going beyond your personal explanation.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am explaining the circumstances surrounding the only occasion to which Senator Crowley could possibly be referring. She was misrepresenting me and exaggerating the situation. So, if I may explain, in regard to the child-care centre that was to be introduced into the Parliamentary Triangle, the Government did not go through the normal procedures which have to be followed with developments in the Parliamentary Triangle, nor did it consult with the National Trust, which it was required to do. On those grounds I objected to the Government's high-handed attitude in trying to put a child care-centre in that location. I am, however, a strong believer in child-care as a productivity issue, not as a welfare issue. The Government has failed to provide any sort of leadership in the child-care area because it is determined that child-care will be provided only by the taxpayer, at enormous expense. There are other mechanisms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to participate in this debate, which is a discussion of a matter of public importance in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the Hawke Labor Government in failing Australian women.
Obviously, it has hit a sore nerve because on the other side of the chamber people are getting rather excited about this debate, and I think that is very good.

TALK.START.PARA: —A deplorable record.

—That is right; it is a poor record of the Hawke Labor Government that has caused this debate to be brought on. In the time that I have available today I would like to concentrate my remarks on how the Hawke Labor Government has failed the rural women of Australia. While this Government has failed rural people in a most cynical and calculated manner, the group who take the greater share of this discrimination are in fact rural women. There are 1.8 million women living in rural Australia. While I live in rural Australia, I cannot profess to appreciate the isolation, the loneliness and the sheer hard slog that women in the inland of this country and even in western New South Wales live under. I live some 110 kilometres from a major rural city and some 50 kilometres from a country town, but I do understand some of the concerns that are being expressed here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Probably the three most important concerns for rural and regional Australians are our record interest rates, roads, and the increasing cost to the housewife, wherever she may be. In these three areas alone this Government, in last night's Budget, has done nothing. While the Treasurer might make a big splash about the $116m being spent on roads, that is not money that the Government has allocated for that purpose; it is money that almost entirely is coming out of fuel excise revenue, out of the pockets of the motorists, the people who live in the country and the city areas. On the question of interest rates, the attitude of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) appears to be, `Tough; sweat it out as best you can'. On inflation he says, `Let 'er rip'. These three issues alone have had an enormous impact on women living in rural areas. High interest rates for farmers have meant that wives are increasingly going off the farm to provide a cash flow to service interest debts. While outside careers might be the popular choice for city women, it is unbelievably harder for women in rural Australia to take a job off the farm. I will return to that point later.

A recent University of New England study of rural media advertisements concluded that the prevailing ideology in the country is that men are the real farmers and that women not only accept this but encourage the stereotype of themselves as homemakers. And they are. The women are a vital part of our community, because they help and encourage their male spouses, wherever they happen to be. This study covered 1,478 advertisements, and not one of them showed a woman doing a farm job. Yet a recent national survey of rural women commissioned by the Federal Government showed that 72 per cent of farm women do farm work. In fact, almost 70 per cent of farm wives are the farm's business managers-not a bad number. Additionally, more then 90 per cent of them do manual work on the farm, and for 5,400 farms women are the sole owners and managers.

For those women who have been forced to take work off the farm, the pressures have become enormous. They invariably do a day's work before they leave in the morning, often to travel a great distance over appalling roads; and at the end of the day their task is to buy the groceries or collect the children from the school before tackling the bad roads to go home again. Senator Bjelke-Petersen was saying to me only this morning that that is the place where women see the real inflation costs-when they go to buy their groceries and when they drive across the rural roads that are being neglected by this Government. This year, with the extended wet weather, of course, the roads in New South Wales are an absolute disgrace and a death trap. The Budget which was brought down last night gives no joy to people travelling on those roads.

The Federal Government has in recent years actually recognised that women living in rural Australia are disadvantaged. But what has it done? There have been surveys, studies and meetings, but that is all the Government has done: words and glossy brochures. Another glossy brochure came to the Senate today. When it comes to the hard cash and the real initiatives, the Government has done nothing. It has failed the women of Australia.

A report issued by the Federal Government in February last year and titled Life has never been easy attempted to portray life for women in rural Australia. The study involved some 14,000 women across Australia, questioned with the assistance of the Country Women's Association. The dominant theme of this study was that isolation, loneliness, lack of medical services and inadequate transport and communication were the key issues. An equal number of women suggested the biggest problems facing country women were the rural crisis, the high cost of living and running a farm. They listed as priorities roads and transport.

Of course, there are other issues, such as Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport where the third runway should be put in to service the people of the rural communities. Women who send their children away to school and people who come to the country to visit women do not have a decent aeroplane service because this Government has neglected Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

This report contains a litany of complaints, from rural women, mainly about telephone services-the difficulties of 21 sharing a party line; the cost of subscriber trunk dialling rates; the lack of radio and television services; and the difficulties of educating their children or themselves. The report showed that about half of rural women now work as wage or salary earners. For rural women volunteer workers are a necessary adjunct of their daily life. There is no local caterer for the clearing sales. Volunteers do it for fund-raising. Services such as meals on wheels, social workers and rape crisis centres do not exist in the country areas so rural women have to look after themselves.

The survey was greeted with much fanfare. Of course, there is always fanfare when the Government produces bits of papers. The Government has spent its money on publishing the report but spends nothing on the implementation of its recommendations. That is where this Government stands condemned: it spends plenty on words but nothing on actually putting them into practice.

In March of last year the Government published another report, Overcoming distance: Isolated rural women's access to TAFE across Australia. In launching the report, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, said:

This is an important report. It contains recommendations that offer practical, cost effective solutions to overcoming the problems of isolation faced by women as well as men in country areas. While many of the problems faced by isolated women around Australia are similar, different solutions are often required.

They are fine words and enough to give one a great sense of expectation. A month later yet another report was issued titled A Fair Go: The Federal Government's Strategy for Rural Education and Training. It contained more fine words and led to further expectation. But this Government is still neglecting the people of rural Australia, especially the women. That is why honourable senators sitting on that side of the chamber stand condemned.
In a rather large document in the Budget Papers issued last night, Women's Budget Statement, at pages 23 and 24, we see more words, more reports and a notation that states:
A number of measures . . . will be taken within the existing policy and budgetary framework.

In other words, despite all the reports and studies, the only funding available will have to come from some other area of education already squeezed to the limit. I say, `Big deal, big failure by the Hawke Labor Government to the women of Australia'.

Rural education is one area that has had a raw deal for a very long time. One needs only to talk with Mrs Helen Withers from the Isolated Children's Parents Association to realise that for rural women with children things have got progressively worse over the past six years. In 1973, for example, an isolated children's allowance of approximately half the cost of average boarding fees was paid to parents to enable them to send their children away, especially for secondary education. Today, that fee is exactly the same but is now only 20 per cent of the boarding component for education.

This Government has neglected the people of rural Australia, especially the women. For years the Association has been trying to get tax deductability for governesses-a necessary addition to a rural family. The only alternative is to take the mother away from her outside farm duties to teach the children. Many families cannot afford a governess so the mother becomes the teacher. The children's education suffers accordingly when activities on the farm require her presence outside. There is no additional funding this year for equipment for teaching children at home; there is no assistance for travel when correspondence schools have their biannual get-togethers. In fact, one of the most common reasons that farm workers leave rural employment is lack of secondary education facilities. Again, there is nothing in this Budget for that-another failure for the women of rural Australia. The Gough Whitlam attitude-and I know that he did not care very much about the farm women-was that everyone had never had it so good, or words to that effect. That attitude is alive and well and living in the hearts and minds of those in the Labor Party today. They do not care about rural women. This Budget document-the yellow Women's Budget Statement-is evidence of that: two paragraphs full of platitudes and waffle and no substance. In fact, the Labor Party does not care about people generally, but especially the women of Australia.

The black hole of Australian poverty exists not in some run-down city ghetto or depressed industrial sector, but in the rural sector. Julian Cribb, the well-known rural writer, recently made the point that, of the 37 poorest electorates in Australia, 33 are in rural Australia. It is interesting that the Labor Party holds only 27 per cent of Australia's poorest electorates and 37 per cent of its wealthiest. That explains a great deal about why rural Australia is so neglected and so poor. The extent of rural poverty in country towns is largely hidden. It is normal for young people either to remain unemployed or to leave town to find work. Women have difficulty finding jobs in country areas, and this Government's policies of reducing country centres to ghost towns through squeezing small business is only making this situation much worse.

Another area that needs discussion is last night's decision on superannuation. Senator Patterson has already made remarks about this. While I applaud the Government's initiative in taking up some of the options outlined in our coalition policy which came out last year, especially in areas affecting women, it has done essentially nothing; and what it has done is not good enough. For example, the Labor Party policy enunciated last night said that a woman who is out of the work force for two years can maintain her superannuation contributions, but after that she cannot continue with her superannuation contribution. That means that after two years she is going to be forced back into the work force. I do not think that it is a good thing to be forced back into anything. Women are being discriminated against in that regard. Our policy says they can go out of the work force and they can make contributions for a lifetime.

Recent surveys into superannuation have found that most superannuation schemes do not appeal to women, because they depend on long and continuous service. Most working women have career breaks to have families and superannuation schemes do not cover such breaks. Our superannuation schemes will cover those breaks for those women who want to go out of the work force. If the Government is genuine about encouraging people to provide for their retirement, it ought to realise that women are a significant part of the work force. In fact, as at August 1988 there were some 2.5 million women in the work force and, of those, only 723,000-that is 28 per cent-had any kind of superannuation coverage.

Our superannuation policies do not discriminate against women, as the Labor Party's policies do. The Labor Party has failed the women of Australia. It has especially failed the rural women. It has taken no account of the enormous contribution they make to generating export income and the absolutely outstanding contribution they make to keeping home and family together and raising children. That is something that this Government-this Hawke Labor Government-stands condemned for. It does not care about the family; it does not care about the people who want to bring up their children in good surroundings and make sure that they have a good life ahead of themselves. It stands condemned for not caring about the women of Australia. This matter raised by Senator Newman earlier in the afternoon is something that I hope, if we were to divide on it, would be carried unanimously by this Government and this Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance that we are debating this afternoon alleges that the Hawke Government has failed Australian women. I find this topic quite an extraordinary one to be debating in this place. A number of issues that have arisen this afternoon would have made excellent topics for the debate, and I hope that one day we will have the opportunity to go quite deeply into questions such as the relative merits of screening for breast cancer, for example. As it is, we are faced with an amazing barrage of allegations from people who are extraordinarily poorly equipped to debate the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw attention to the coalition's record on some of these issues. I am aware that I am dealing with history but it is quite easy to link some of these facts with what is happening today. For example, I recall very clearly the strenuous opposition from the coalition to sex discrimination legislation, to equal opportunity in the public service legislation, to affirmative action legislation-not only opposition, but filibustering and keeping us here almost until Christmas Eve on a number of occasions.

Okay, this is history; it happened some years ago. It is now just on five years since our sex discrimination legislation was proclaimed, and maybe we could forget what happened if it were not for the fact that we have been assured by the coalition time and time again that in government it would abolish the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Is it not relevant to today's debate that those opposite would remove the machinery whereby that legislation has been implemented? The Opposition has called for implementation. That is implementation, and it is implementation which the Australian community accepts very largely. The most recent poll I have seen on the matter showed that acceptance of sex discrimination legislation was in excess of 75 per cent.

The kindest interpretation to put on much of what we have heard this afternoon, and on other occasions, is that it has demonstrated an abysmal lack of knowledge. We have witnessed this time and time again when the coalition has raised issues concerning welfare, the structure of industry, the changing structure of women's place in the work force, and attitudinal matters. Even things that are actually under way seem somehow to escape the notice of the coalition, although they are being done very publicly. An example of this was a notice of motion on domestic violence brought before the Senate just a few weeks ago which was meant to be very embarrassing to the Government. We had no difficulty agreeing with this notice of motion because what it was calling for we were already doing. We had under way a campaign for awareness of domestic violence on which, we discovered when notes were exchanged, we could take a bipartisan position. It is a great pity that we do not see that bipartisan position taken more often, as used to be the case in the past. I must say it was very disappointing when we offered the coalition full briefing on the domestic violence issue to find that none of the Opposition women where able to attend.

It seems quite extraordinary that we hear from Senator Brownhill at great length about the difficulties of rural women. That is no surprise to this Government. It is no surprise to anybody in Australia. But one does wonder whether those women were having difficulties prior to 1983 or whether suddenly their isolation, loneliness, income problems and so on developed in 1983. One wonders why absolutely nothing was done about it prior to that.

Of course, over the years there have been informed Liberal-National Party members and senators and we have had support from members of those parties on issues such as community child-care, education and work force issues. We have had absolutely splendid support from at least one of the shadow Ministers for women's affairs and Mr Macphee was gracious enough to join us in launching a document by the name of Fair Exposure. It was Senator Newman who raised the issue of non-sexist language when she poured scorn on the government Style Manual and its chapter on non-sexist language and wondered who in the name of fortune might be interested in that. I will tell Senator Newman who is interested in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a highlight of your year.

—It was one of the many highlights of the year. For people who deal with language and who like to use accurate language-and I might say that there are not too many on Senator Newman's side of the chamber-it was a very important event. However, we have another document that Senator Newman might be interested to find in the Liberal Party library, if in fact such a thing exists. She should have a look at Fair Exposure which, some years ago, was saying exactly the same thing, and which received total support from the shadow Minister for women's affairs. While I am talking about Mr Macphee, I would like to quote something he once told us. He said that the Liberals:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . still have the view that a woman's place is in the home and when she has children she stays there and doesn't go into the paid workforce and therefore you don't have child care and those sorts of issues, and I firmly stand for equal opportunity for women that they then paint this as being anti-family, it's not of course, but that's the way in which many of the delegates thought, the delegates themselves not having an experience of their wives or the women themselves being in the paid workforce. That was a problem, and I also found that they didn't understand even their own daughters-in-law who in fact held the same views as I did and wanted equal opportunity.

I think Opposition members have come a little way since then, but it is absolutely incumbent upon them to check their facts a little better than they have done on this occasion. What would happen if the Liberal Party were in power? I am just going on what we have been told over the years, not on anything very enlightening that has occurred today. We would have income-splitting-the most regressive way of treating the second income in a household. We would have regressive deductions, such as those for the costs of child-care which, of course, help those on the highest incomes and provide no extra places for low income people. We would have very little increase in the number of available child-care places as a result except, of course, from the private sector which has no obligation to provide child-care in the areas where it is most needed. It has no obligation to provide child-care for tiny children below the age of two or for those with special needs. What would happen to things like women's refuges, women's health care houses, the Child Support Agency that we have established, the family allowance supplements? We have gone through these things this afternoon. Would we go back to the federalism which put a stopper on any advance in any of those services during the years of the Fraser Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the Fraser years with women's shelters.
—I would really like to know where Senator Newman has been in the last 6 1/2 years, for the previous seven years for that matter.
—I was running a women's shelter. That is what I was doing.

—Maybe Senator Newman should have had a look outside that one shelter to what is happening in a number of other States and should take a more visionary approach than the one she appears to be taking. Let us consider women's employment. Senator Newman seems to be very worried about the motivation of women who work. Let us have a look at employment growth. I am sure that Senator Newman knows this, but since 1983, the women's employment rate has grown by over 5 per cent, the participation rate of women in the labour force aged 15 and over has grown by almost 7 per cent, the women's unemployment rate has fallen by four percentage points and the unemployment rate for young women has fallen by 10 percentage points-from over 27.5 per cent to 17.5 per cent. Is the Opposition suggesting that reducing unemployment for women-in other words, a growing economy, which gives people the opportunities to have money in their purses when they open them-is failing women?

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the Opposition has been terribly keen lately to go into the reasons why women join the work force. It is very interesting. The Opposition was not too worried about the fact that when it was in government almost 30 per cent of young women were unemployed. Now it is a matter of national concern that some women may work to help to pay for their home. There is nothing new in that. Women in low income families have always had to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —You skite about that.

—I am not skiting about that; it is absolutely true. Senator Newman's comment about women who feel they have been conscripted into the work force is very interesting to me. She gives no source for those figures. I wonder whether the question was asked: How many men feel they are conscripted into the work force. Why should there be any difference? I am aware of a report called Beyond the Stereotypes which was done by Clemenger and Associates. I am sure Senator Newman would find it extremely interesting. It is still available and there is a copy in my office if she would like to borrow it. It surveyed large numbers of women in all age groups-those in the home, those in the work force, those who had worked, those who were wanting to work, those who did not want to work and certainly those with small children.

SPEECH.PARA: It was discovered that the vast majority of Australian women would dearly love to be in the work force for the very same reason that men would dearly love to be in the work force-for luxuries like food, clothing and paying the rent. For women the question of whether to enter paid work is determined by many factors: their age, marital status, family and domestic responsibilities, the availability of child-care, their education and skills and the level of wages. Equally important is the availability of jobs, both full time and part time. The whole issue of jobs, the quality of jobs, the availability of a wide range of training opportunities, the availability of opportunities to progress through the work force is one of the extremely important features of the work that we have been doing for women in the work force over the last few years.

The Industrial Relations Commission in its May review of the structural adjustment principle under the wage fixing guidelines referred employers and employees to statements forming an important element of restructuring awards in Australia. I am referring here to statements made at a tripartite conference on legislative and award restrictions to women's employment which was held just recently here in Canberra. Is it failing young women actually to provide in low income families an amount of money which will allow them to stay at school rather than leave school and go onto unemployment benefit? Austudy has been one of the greatest reforms of this Government. I think if I were looking for one reform that is going to have long lasting effects for women, it might be encouraging young people to stay in the education system.

When we came into office the retention of girls to year 12 was around 44 per cent. It is now almost 62 per cent-a rise of about 18 per cent in six years. It means that a vast number of young women are now leaving school with a range of skills and a real chance of making their way in the world. In higher education women's participation has shown a similar pattern of growth-up from around 44 per cent to almost 51.5 per cent of enrolments. Women now recognise that it is worthwhile to invest in their own education because they see the opportunities are there through award restructuring and affirmative action. Discrimination is being removed through the legislation that we introduced and that many honourable senators opposite opposed. Their employment prospects are brighter because this Government has tackled the essential support structures such as child-care.

I wish to refer to a matter that I referred to a little earlier-screening for breast cancer. Reference was made to a National Health and Medical Research Council report which advocated widespread screening for women. That is still a very problematic issue. There is not a great deal of agreement about whether wide screening, as expensive as it is and subjecting people to doses of X-rays as it does, is the best way to go or that it is even very effective. There are international studies that show it is not necessarily very effective. I think in the meantime Senator Newman and I, and probably every public spirited woman, should be encouraging women to self-examine their breasts, to be conscious of the risks they face. I just have this feeling that it is as pointless to screen every woman in the community for breast cancer as it would be to screen every male in the community for enlarged prostate glands. Just as many men die from cancer of the prostate as women do of breast cancer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a lot more can be done than there is now.

—I am quite sure that a great deal more can be done especially for rural people, but let us not forget the responsibilities of the State governments in this matter and the fact that some State governments have taken up the challenge and are dealing with it. Mr Acting Deputy President, I have come to the end of my time. There is no sense in which the Hawke Government can be said to have failed Australian women and Australian women are very, very well aware of the fact.
—The discussion on the matter of public importance is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report for the calendar year 1988 covers the twenty-first year of operation of the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). As is well known, the college was established and a large number of colleges of advanced education (CAEs) were developed in this country as a result of the report of the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia. The binary system is at an end and we now have one system of higher education institutions.

This year, 1988, in many ways marks the end of an era for the CCAE, which now has to consider new options for the future. In another sense, this is a particularly important transition year in that the present Government, wanting to set the pace for amalgamation of higher education institutions, introduced legislation into the Senate to facilitate the amalgamation of the Australian National University and the CCAE. This was proposed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) with inadequate consultation with those two important higher education institutions in this city of Canberra. The legislation has not proceeded because it is the view of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that it does not have sound educational foundations, that it has many extra costs and, indeed, that it may well compromise the particular missions of the two institutions as they now exist.

At this juncture, the mission of the Canberra College of Advanced Education is well recognised, at least by the Opposition, as something that should be retained. It should not be lost by the college aping a university in the sense of pure research or in the sense of a greater emphasis upon research than on teaching. Rather, the college should remain true to its 20-year established record of serving, as a priority, the people of Canberra and this region. It should cater for the applied needs of a wide number of professions in a way which is now distinctly seen as being specific to colleges rather than to universities. It is important that the end of the binary system should not lead to a bureaucratic bar on some applied areas of higher education, including the full involvement in research and postgraduate degrees. There is direct reference in the report before us to these matters taking up a great deal of the college's time. On page 6 there is an important reference to the amalgamation procedure. The report clearly states:
The College Council expressed to the Minister-
Minister Dawkins-

its preference for the College to remain a separate institution. Despite this preference, Council agreed that the College should enter negotiations with the ANU and CITA over the terms on which the proposed merger might take place.

I note that another development is the report by the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly on the CAE and higher education generally. I note three of the findings of the report: namely, that the merger not proceed, that the CCAE be under the care of the ACT government and that it be redesignated a university as soon as possible. These are views that I expressed a year ago in this chamber. I note that and I note that these findings bear upon the institution directly, so it may well be that in a year's time when we see the annual report there will be developments in this direction. I wish the college well and acknowledge the substance of the report before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Council report of 1988 of the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE). As Senator Teague has mentioned, 1988 was the college's twentieth year and, as has been mentioned, the question of amalgamation was referred to in the report. It has been a fairly dramatic year for the college, I would suggest, in view of the things it had to face with the Federal Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) hell bent, one might almost say, on forcing amalgamations and in particular using those in which he was involved specifically for the purpose of doing so. He seemed to ignore the fact that other institutions around the country rejected the concept of merger. He certainly seemed to ignore the views of both the institutions in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Only recently has he backed away from the merger in face of the criticism of a number of people in this Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National University (ANU) and the CCAE are both tertiary institutions and they serve very different purposes. The CCAE has an excellent reputation. Anybody reading the report will be impressed by the college's range of activities and what it has achieved, providing courses for people in the ACT, the surrounding region and others who come here. It fills a vital role. Many people were concerned that what was happening would have amounted to a takeover by the ANU whereby the unique characteristics of the CCAE would be lost. I do not think that the ANU had such aspirations, but that was an aspect of the concern.

The matter has now been discussed by the ACT Legislative Assembly. It has reported and has recommended what should occur. It has recommended that the Commonwealth Government transfer the CCAE to the ACT Government with funding under the existing arrangements. It says that, whatever its eventual status, the CCAE should be established under ACT legislation as a university as soon as possible. It dealt with a number of other matters which, hopefully, will be considered by the Federal Minister. It is hoped that he will take some note of the report and the matters that have been discussed in it. It seems clear to me that any amalgamation ought to be deferred and looked at from the point of view of this report and the other views that have been presented. The earlier report that he commissioned dealt merely with how it would be done. I have never seen any evidence from the Minister that it was going to be good for students or anybody. It was merely to satisfy his whim that this, in fact, should be the case.

There have been discussions, I understand, between the CCAE and Monash University for a sponsorship relationship to exist between the two. Many courses overlap between them and there seems to be considerable merit in looking at that aspect of the development. The CCAE has considerable strength in Asian languages which could also be a boon to Monash's languages institute. There are other ways of looking at working together than the blind amalgamation path that the Minister would have these institutions tread.

I hope that the matter will be looked at differently. The one thing of which we must be quite certain is retaining the CCAE's unique status. It has certainly been a baptism of fire for Professor Roger Scott who took over the position of Principal only at the beginning of last year. He has certainly seen turbulent times since then, but I believe that the institution is still-as is indicated in the report-flourishing. It would be my wish that it continue to do so and that no changes be made which would interfere with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by congratulating the Principal of Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE), Roger Scott, and the others associated with the institution on another very successful year. In that context, it gives me great pleasure to join with those who have spoken to the report of the Canberra College of Advanced Education. This year has been very significant for two reasons. Obviously, there has been the discussion on amalgamation and I will refer to that subsequently. But, firstly, this has been the year of transition to self-government in the Australian Capital Territory and this has put new pressures on the tertiary institutions in the Territory and in particular on the CCAE which has, as is stated on page six of the report, seen its primary orientation as a higher education institution serving the Australian Capital Territory and the region. That particular focus has meant that its integration with the rest of the education institutions in Canberra and in the surrounding region is very important. It has always had a very sensible and progressive relationship with the technical and further education sector here and I welcome the fact that Roger Scott has joined the Australian Capital Territory Education and Training Council. He was an active member of the Australian Capital Territory Administration coordination committee in the days before self-government. The Council supported that because it was an important part of confirming that orientation, that regional direction, which is important not only for the CCAE, but also for the region.

SPEECH.PARA: But this has also been a year in which the CCAE has been moving towards university status. I am not so concerned at the moment to debate how it makes that move, but it is important that it does make it. It cannot be left on the shelf as the only college of advanced education. Which route it takes to university status is a secondary question. For me, it is a matter for the institution itself to sort out, but I was concerned that it should not be forced down a particular route. I therefore welcome the Minister's assurance given to the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and me that that will not be the case and the developments in relation to Monash are important in that regard.

It is inevitable that there will be closer links between the CCAE under whatever name it subsequently operates and the ANU. They must work more closely together. The integration needs to be substantially enhanced. The engineering situation-I almost said fiasco, but will not-has been the prime example of the need for better coordination. But that brings me to the question of the very successful development that has taken place at the CCAE this year in the emphasis in engineering. It has made a planning decision to provide for growth in the areas of nursing and engineering in its educational profile. I think that is a very appropriate decision. It is suitable to the educational needs of the region. It is fitting into a niche that is required and I am very pleased that the Federal Government provided funds to the college for an information, sciences and engineering building and that in the draft Australian Capital Territory Budget for 1989 there is a proposal for a major new nursing education building, consistent with the priorities of the college itself.

The other area I want to refer to gets away from the more controversial and big issues of the year concerning self-government and the move towards the university. I comment on, and support, a development going on at the college with regard to the development of cultural heritage management and cultural heritage studies. It is something which the CCAE does almost uniquely and, in some ways, almost uniquely in the world. It is a very important contribution to the preservation of our Aboriginal heritage and it is very important that, whatever form of subsequent educational institution the college becomes, it retains the right and capacity to do that. It receives international funding recognising the unique contribution it makes in the study of the preservation of rock art and it does outstanding work in other areas. In concluding and in congratulating, as I did at the commencement of my speech, Roger Scott and the others, I want to make particular reference to Dr Galla, the lecturer in the cultural heritage management courses. They make a substantial contribution to Canberra and the region but, more broadly, to Australia and to the preservation of indigenous cultures throughout the world. I congratulate the college on that innovative contribution and on the centre which it recently opened to enhance that development. DEBATE.TITLE: RESIDENTS' RIGHTS IN NURSING HOMES AND HOSTELS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise to speak to the final report in the series Residents' Rights in Nursing Homes And Hostels. The principles on which this report are based are set out at the front of the report and include the principle that every resident of a nursing home or a hostel has a right to be treated as an individual. Other principles relate to information being available to the residents, to their having a sense of involvement, and to their rights not being reduced by their capacity to exercise those rights but to have those rights exercised for them.

In Western Australia concern is being expressed by many people about the lack of involvement of patients in various hospitals and nursing homes in decisions which are being made on their behalf. I certainly believe that, if the proposed charter were to be implemented as set out in this report, many of those patients' rights would be addressed. In fact, in Western Australia a health watch group has been set up because of people's concern. This health watch group has set itself up to actually survey what is going on in hospitals and nursing homes.
I would like to draw the Senate's attention to certain of the clauses in the proposed charter. The second clause states:
The charter shall provide that all residents have . . .

(ii)the right to maintain personal independence, personal choice and personal responsibility for all actions, including a recognition that some actions may involve an element of risk which the resident accepts and which should not be used to prevent or restrict those actions;

The health watch group has discovered that in some homes for the aged harnesses are being used against the wishes of the patients and against the wishes of the relatives of those patients. I regard that as something that needs looking into. Perhaps more seriously, clause (xi) states, in part:
the right to be treated with dignity and respect

It has also been brought to my attention, through the health watch group, that a very disturbing event is happening in some of our homes for the aged, C class hospitals and nursing homes. We have three completely independent reports from three different hospitals of what is happening. We are finding that some older patients are being given a drug called melleril, which is a tranquilliser. One of the side effects of this drug is incontinence. These people are having their underclothes removed, are being placed in short gowns, and are being seated on padded cushions as a result of the incontinence caused by this drug. In fact, one constituent has related how his 89-year-old mother, who while being cared for at home needed no medication whatsoever, when placed in a C class hospital in order to give some respite to the carers was given the drug melleril, with the effect which I have just mentioned. When she was placed back at home, of course, the incontinence disappeared as she was no longer on the drug. I believe that this is not a situation which can be supported by our society. I would, therefore, with all caution, refer also to clause (xix) of the charter, which says that the residents should have:
the responsibility for their own health, as far as is possible, and to undertake all prescribed medical treatment . . .

I think we need to qualify that with a mention of informed consent with regard to that sort of treatment, either by the patient or by the patient's advocate. This chamber may well soon be discussing the rights of the unborn, so surely we must place top priority on the rights of the living. I certainly commend this report and would hope that there would be full and open discussion on the proposed charter of the rights and responsibilities of residents in nursing homes. I would like to mention just briefly a report in today's West Australian that there has now been published a long-awaited report into patient abuse at Graylands Hospital which confirmed that mistreatment of patients by nurses had occurred.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY BUILDING STANDARDS COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The annual report of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Building Standards Committee is yet another of those very delayed papers representing incompetence by this Government. In relation to the ACT Administration Office of City Management, section 26A of the Building Ordinance of 1972 states that the Building Standards Committee shall, as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, prepare and furnish to the Minister a report of the operations of the Committee during that year. `As soon as practicable' is an interesting concept when the year ended on 30 June last and now, in August of the following year, the Government eventually gets around to tabling the report. It is the Government's fault because this report was submitted to it on 20 December 1988. It is, as I say, another example of Government incompetence or of the Government treating this chamber with contempt.

A matter of some concern is omitted from this report. There may be a sound reason. It relates to the failure of the Silverton Centre in this city to be of a sufficient standard to be capable of safe occupancy. In fact, this centre has been vacant since February because of major structural faults. That has involved the Commonwealth in enormous expenditure. One department alone, which was occupying the centre on a tenancy basis, has been obliged to spend $170,000 simply to relocate its computer. As reported in yesterday's Canberra Times, there are strong suggestions from the union movement that it is pretty uneasy about any suggestions that the building could be reoccupied even after structural improvements were made because it is not confident that those improvements will render it safe. This is despite the fact that last month the building's owners, the Commonwealth Bank, said that it could be repaired, that remedial work was due to start soon and that the building was expected to be ready for reoccupation early next year.

My concern is this: how effective is the Australian building code if this kind of structural mishap can take place-a mishap costing hundreds of thousands of dollars to Commonwealth departments apart from whatever costs were incurred by private sector occupants? No doubt the question of negligence will get thrashed out in the courts sooner or later. But we have here in the ACT an ordinance requiring safety in the construction of buildings. Yet this building-a brand new, modern building-has been found to be structurally unsound.

What were the inspectors appointed for the purpose, and presumably paid by this Government, doing when this building was being put up? How were the certificates of its safety obtained? In view of the enormous cost carried at this stage by the taxpayers of Australia resulting from the failure of this building to have been safely built, I believe the Government has an obligation to let this chamber know what it is all about. It is disappointing in those circumstances that this annual report of the Building Standards Committee makes no mention of the Silverton problem.

It may well be that this report at last coming before us covers a period so long ago that there was no evidence at the time that the Silverton building was in fact structurally unsound. But that is another example or another instance of why it is ludicrous for this Government to keep presenting these reports so late that they do not even cover a matter of enormous significance relating to building standards in the ACT-building standards that have been shown to be grossly inadequate and which have put many lives at risk because a report has said that this building could in fact have collapsed at any stage.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 August, on motion by Senator Short:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commenced my remarks on this report yesterday and some of the things I wanted to say I said then, so I will confine my remarks more than I would otherwise have done today. There is a great deal that can and should be said about the fourth report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which deals with the funding of political advertising during election campaigns and with the disclosure by political parties and third parties of income and expenditure for ongoing or maintenance activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The time for debate today is extremely limited, so let me just touch briefly on what I see as the real motivation behind the recommendations of the majority of the Committee, that is, essentially the Australian Labor Party members of the Committee and the Australian Democrats member, Senator Jenkins. As the Senate now knows, the Committee was deeply divided on its report. The three coalition members of the Committee, Dr Wooldridge, Mr Cobb and I, prepared a dissenting report which is to be found on pages 115 to 134 of the document-a dissenting report that I commend all members of the Senate and the wider community to read because we are talking about a report, the majority findings of which pose very real threats to the whole of our political and democratic system.

The three Liberal and National Party members totally rejected all the content and recommendations of the majority report. Those majority recommendations-there were 14 of them-to me boiled down to the following main proposals: first, that in future there should be no paid advertising on radio or television by any political party or interested organisation or individual during an election campaign; secondly, instead existing political parties should be provided with free time by the commercial radio and television stations on a rigidly controlled formula basis; thirdly, new political parties would be permitted to receive free advertising only if they not only contested Senate seats but also contested more than 50 per cent of the seats in at least the State in which they operate; fourthly, no other organisation or individual would be allowed legally to advertise at all on radio or television any matter even vaguely relevant to the issues of an election; and fifthly, political parties would be forced to disclose publicly all sources of income and expenditure for their ongoing day to day operations in addition to the existing provisions for public disclosure of revenue and expenditure for election purposes.

These recommendations are arguably the most anti-democratic recommendations ever put to any parliament in Australia by any parliamentary committee. They constitute a massive form of censorship on a scale and of a nature that we could never have envisaged possible in this great and free democratic nation. They make it virtually impossible for new political parties to receive advertising coverage on radio or television during election campaigns. What is even more draconian and totalitarian is that they would legally prohibit legitimate interest groups in our community from getting their views across on radio or television during election campaigns. For instance, the Australian Conservation Foundation would legally be prohibited from advertising its views on the environment. The National Farmers Federation would be legally prohibited from advertising its view on such issues as rural issues, economic management, interest rates, or the like. The Australian Council of Social Service would not be permitted to advertise its view on behalf of its social service clients. The Australian Automobile Association would be prohibited from advertising its view on road funding, and so on. The ban would apply to each and every interest group in our community. Freedom of choice for political parties and for legitimate interest groups would be dealt a death blow.

There is much more that could be said about these big brother, Orwellian, anti-democratic, and totalitarian proposals. Briefly, they are also discriminatory. They put all the cost of political advertising into commercial radio and television stations. Why should they have to bear the cost? Why should not political parties, if they want to advertise, pay for their own advertising?

The recommendations are illogical. For example, they do not include print media advertising. The only reason why they do not include that is that the Federal Government does not have the power in this area. Indeed, even the radio and television advertising recommendations are relying on the Broadcasting Act, not on the Electoral Act, as they should.

The proposals in respect of public disclosure might superficially be thought to have some higher and principled purpose, but that is not so either, because the only real effect of those proposals is to massively advantage the Labor Party. Under these proposals, for all practical purposes, the millions of dollars that are poured into the coffers of the Australian Labor Party from the trade unions would not be affected at all. This is because everyone knows of the compulsory trade union contribution to its political wing, the Australian Labor Party. It is an historic association; it is a formal association; it is something that everybody knows about. But not once in the majority report are trade union contributions to the Labor Party even acknowledged.

Taken as a whole, the recommendations of the majority report are nothing more than a blatant attempt to gain massive political electoral advantage at the next and following elections, and the Senate should note in that respect that all the recommendations will apply equally to State elections and to Federal elections. There again, the Committee, without any comment on it at all, blandly moves its way into the whole area of fundamental Federal-State relationships and the constitutional and other issues that that involves.

The recommendations, which were supported neither by the evidence presented to the Committee nor by reasonable analysis, amount to no more than a ringing endorsement of the Labor Party's own formal submission to the Committee's inquiry. The crude, naked politics behind the majority recommendations of Labor members of the Committee were supplemented yesterday by the introduction of another transparently political document, namely, the Budget-a Budget which completely ignored the fundamental problems facing the nation, which complacently accepted our dangerously uncompetitive inflation rate, our crippling level of interest rates and our horrendous $130 billion overseas debt, and which even accepted a larger balance of payments deficit for 1989-90 than the $17 1/2 billion deficit of 1988-89.

I have been the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and I am very pleased about and proud of that. That Committee and its predecessor, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, have done a great deal of very useful work over the last five or six years. What I very greatly regret is that in the preparation of this report we have seen the blatantly naked party political approach to very important issues that I believe does the Committee a disservice, the Parliament a disservice and the Australian Labor Party itself a disservice.

But the important thing is to recognise the recommendations for what they are-a blatant political attempt at grandstanding, and the introduction into this country in the area of political advertising of an anti-democratic totalitarian set of proposals that I would never have believed it possible to see introduced into this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters report titled Who pays the piper calls the tune-minimising the risks of political campaigns. I reject practically everything that Senator Short said in his remarks. I believe the report is an outstanding one. It deals with a very controversial issue; there is no denying that. But it deals simply, in an understandable way, with a growing problem in the operation of democracy in our country. Senator Short in his remarks, and the other critics of this report, failed to mention that most other Western democracies have some sort of limitation on the amount spent on advertising on television or radio in the commercial sector as well as the public sector of broadcasting.
—Most of them have first past the post voting. What argument is that?

—I have not had much time for Margaret Thatcher. But even I have to admit that in 10 years of her rule in Great Britain she has never attempted to introduce legislation to allow paid political advertising on commercial television and radio in that country. Everyone knows her ideological disposition in favour of the free market and so on. But neither she nor her Government has ever seen fit to propose the system that operates in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick interjected about first past the post in Australia. Senator Puplick must realise that in most of the countries of western Europe where there are restrictions on the amount of paid advertising the system is a proportional representation system, not first past the post. First past the post is in a minority of countries that we know as democratic.

An argument that I find most false is that this proposal is censorship, that we are going to restrict the right of people to broadcast their views on commercial television and radio. I have not heard one person explain to me what is the difference at the moment. There is censorship on paid broadcast on television and radio. The definition of the censorship is, `do you have access to large amounts of money?'. By 1990 it is estimated that on Sydney television it will cost $10,000 per 60 seconds. There are very few organisations in this country that have access to the large amounts of money needed to buy that sort of advertising. If democracy in this country is to be based upon the ability of people to buy advertising, and that alone, we will have a problem in the long term with the operation of democracy as we know it. Democracy does not represent money; it represents people and ideas. What we have with paid television and broadcasting in the way it is operating at the moment is a selection process based on one's access to money.

We have seen what this is doing to political parties. We had the extraordinary evidence given by Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that people used to go into his office and leave brown paper bags full of money on his desk but he could not remember who they were or how much money was involved. He just used to take it and put it into the Bjelke-Petersen fund. What was that fund used for? It was used overwhelmingly to pay for television and radio advertisements for the National Party of Australia at recent elections. It is estimated that the National Party's expenditure in the last week of the 1986 Queensland State election campaign was in excess of $1m and that went overwhelmingly on television advertising. It has been said that in the last three or four days of the television campaign most of the money was spent on buying every available election spot on commercial television in Brisbane to get the National Party over the line to maintain its absolute majority, still with 39 per cent of the vote. We have the evidence, the clear admission by the former National Party leader and Premier in Queensland, that people used to leave brown paper bags full of money on his desk or in his office, but he could not remember who they were. We all know the purpose for which the money was needed. If there was no paid advertising during an election campaign, the need for even the National Party in Queensland, as corrupt as it is, to go and solicit large donations from people it wishes to forget would not be necessary.

In recent days evidence has been given to the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales that both parties, the Labor Party and the National Party, have received donations from land developers in northern New South Wales. There was the extraordinary evidence of the Deputy Premier of New South Wales that it was just a coincidence that on or about the day he signed the approval for a development in northern New South Wales a cheque from the developers turned up in the National Party office. But there was also evidence from the Labor Party that it had received donations from the same developer. The only motivating factor for the parties to receive those donations was the extraordinary expense of election campaigns in Australia, and in particular New South Wales, to buy television advertising. They needed the money so they took decisions that most of us would probably disagree with if we did not have the pressure of raising the money to pay for an election campaign. I would like to know who is contributing the million dollars for the present paid advertising campaign on television by the Liberal Party as part of its mock election campaign.

It comes down to a question of whether we want democracy in this country based upon our ability to raise large amounts of money from whatever source it can be had or whether we are to have democracy based on ideas and the representation of people. This report illustrates clearly the dangers to our democratic system by the power of money. I have never seen any definition of democracy that says that money is basis of democracy. My colleague Senator Puplick, a small `l' Liberal, has written much about small `l' liberalism and has written books. I have read some of those books and I cannot remember him describing money as being the basis of democracy or how one gets representation in parliament. We have a major problem and it will get worse unless some action is taken.

The report also states that the system has to operate for State elections, there has to be full disclosure by all political parties at all times and there can be spot audits by the Australian Electoral Commission. Of course the National Party in Queensland-even the Liberal Party-is totally opposed to that. It does not want the people who turn up with brown paper bags full of money to be exposed because it would probably be very embarrassing to it. However, I think that in a democracy such as the one on which we pride ourselves in this country, the community has the right to know who contributes to political parties. As the title of the report says, `Who pays the piper calls the tune'. That has been said about the trade union movement in terms of its donations. People opposite do not realise that every donation from a trade union to the Labor Party, whether it is for administrative purposes or for elections, is publicly declared in the annual accounts of that union lodged with the Industrial Commission in each of the States or at the Federal level. If one gets the annual accounts, one will see listed how much was contributed to the Labor Party. If the honourable senators opposite are so keen about this, why can we not see them putting up a proposal that every publicly listed company that makes a donation to the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Party will be required to divulge in its annual report whom it gave its money to?

TALK.START.PARA: —You passed the Corporations Act. Why didn't you put it in when you were doing the corporations legislation, if you are so smart about it? You could have legislated when you had the corporations package here last year.

—Senator Puplick is now trying to divert attention by asking why we did not do it last time. We are now doing it under the Electoral Act, by this report. Senator Puplick is objecting to it because he wants to protect people who are afraid to let it be known that they have given money to his Party or to another political party. He wants secrecy, which is in my view incompatible with democracy. He argues that people--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which has now been brought forward by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters is illustrative of two important trends that are taking place in the political arena at the moment. It is typical of a government and its allies in a group like the Australian Democrats, when they perceive some electoral threat-particularly when the Democrats perceive some electoral threat-that the first thing they try to do is to corrupt the electoral system. This is precisely what this report attempts to do-to corrupt the Australian electoral system. Nobody had adduced the slightest degree of evidence that, in terms of the Federal elections which have taken place in this country since Federation, money or other influence has corrupted the political process. Nobody has adduced any evidence which relates to that particular allegation. Nor can they, because the evidence is not there.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of things which I wanted to start talking about in relation to comments made by Mr Lee, the honourable member for Dobell and Chairman of this Committee. In the statement which he produced and which was released together with the report, he says this:
The majority of the committee believes that if nothing is done political parties will become increasingly dependent on large donations from companies and wealthy individuals.

You will note, Mr Acting Deputy President, that he does not include in that trade unions. He does not include in that the question of disclosure but the question of increasing dependence upon particular sources of funds. And he identifies companies and wealthy individuals. It is clear from that statement that that is what this report is all about-identifying particular people and particular companies for the Labor Party's and the Democrats' political purpose.

Senator Schacht says that secrecy is incompatible with democracy. I presume that he does not extend the same argument to the secrecy of the ballot, because it used to be argued that the secrecy of the ballot was one of the things which corrupted the democratic process. Senator Schacht does not argue that, presumably. He argues that secrecy corrupts the political process. He says that, if an individual, an ordinary Australian citizen, wishes to make a donation of, say, $20 to a political party, that should be public information, that the privacy of that individual should be raped by the political connivance of the Labor Party and the Democrats, and that that particular person and private donation by an individual of a small sum of money should be made a matter of public concern, presumably so that people can say, `We see that you were a donor to Party X. How about becoming a donor to Party Y? And do you understand the consequences if you do not?'.

We have the other proposition in this report about the gagging of particular groups from advertising during election periods. Again, I quote from comments of Mr Lee, the Chairman of the Committee. An article in the Australian on 8 August, stated:
Mr Lee agreed these recommendations would have the effect of `gagging' lobby groups, for example conservationists or farmers, from political advertising during election campaigns.
And, as Ross Dunn said in the Australian Financial Review on the same date:
This provision is likely to greatly discriminate against green independent candidates who are expected to contest spots for the Senate, riding the new wave of concern for the environment.

That, of course, is the particular reason that the limpet fish of the Australian Democrats want to introduce this particular gag. They have seen the results in Tasmania, they have seen the results in the Australian Capital Territory where they cannot get themselves above one or 2 per cent, where they are having their constituency stolen from them by the Australian Conservation Foundation, by Green Independents, by Senator Vallentine, by Senator Dunn and all of the others. This party with a case of terminal electoral misfortunes visited upon it has decided, now that it is an established part of the system and now that it is particularly concerned about being in a terminal political position, that in terms of keeping the bastards honest, what it now wants to do is make sure that the bastards that are stealing its constituency will not be able to have access to advertising on the electronic media during critical periods of an election campaign.
