He said, `No, I was brought up in Bindoon'. I said, `Were you now? In which years were you there?'. He said, `1947 to 1952', which are exactly those years that were mentioned. I did not say another word from then on. He said to me, `Don't believe all those stories that you read in the papers and that are floated around'. He spoke for 20 minutes while I sat there, resulting in my nearly getting a parking ticket. He gave me the whole story. All those things that had been said were totally untrue.

I made a comment on a report in the West Australian at the time and my office received four or five rather nasty phone calls the first day, but when I replied it was a totally different story. When I questioned what happened things started to change. Then out of the woodwork came all the support for the other side-support for my point of view and support for the institution concerned. I will quote selectively from an article in the Subiaco Post-a weekly local-of 4 July, but later I will seek leave to have it incorporated. Obviously, sisters of the institution were accused of forcing children to touch corpses or of locking them up in a room with corpses. I will just give a few quotations:
Friends sprang to the defence of Wembley's Sisters of Mercy last week after reports . . .
Another reads:
``Welfare officers came to the orphanage every week to see if the children were treated all right. Why didn't they complain then?''.
Referring to a woman who worked at the institution at the time, the article stated:
She said she remembered the migrant children as no better and no worse than the other children staying in the orphanage.
I seek leave to have the article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
We didn't touch corpses, says orphanage child
Friends sprang to the defence of Wembley's Sisters of Mercy last week after reports in a daily newspaper that they had mistreated migrant children in their care some 40 years ago.
At the time the Sisters, many of whom are now dead, ran the St Joseph's Orphanage on the site of what is now the Catherine McAuley Centre.
The migrant children were a group shipped to Australia after the war and a small number of them spoke out last week criticising the treatment they received.
But Barrett Street resident Dot Patterson, one of this year's Perth City Council civic medallion winners for her community work, said the reports were blatant lies.
``I was brought up by the Sisters at the time the migrants were there and they were wonderful to me,'' she said.
``I still go round to visit them often and I wouldn't do that if they had made my life miserable, would I?''

Mrs Patterson said the report which had caused her and those Sisters still living the most grief, was one in which one of the migrants claimed the nuns had locked a child in the room with a corpse because she refused to kiss it.
``We weren't even allowed to touch the dead, let alone kiss them,'' Mrs Patterson said.
``I don't know why they come up with this 40 years after they claim it happened and after most of the people they are slandering are dead.
``Welfare officers came to the orphanage every week to see if the children were treated all right. Why didn't they complain then?''
Mrs Patterson said of the girls she had gone to school with at the orphanage, many had been so comfortable with the Sisters they had gone on to join the order.
She also credited the Sisters with giving her the upbringing which had turned her to community work.
``I remember those days as the best days of my life. We went on picnics, the Sisters taught us singing and dancing and looked after us,'' she said.
``They went without themselves, so that we could have more.
``It is a tragedy, now that many of them are dead, that these people are saying these things.''
Sister MacTill, one of the Sisters working at the orphanage at the time and who now lives in one of the cottages built on the grounds, said the reports had also distressed her.
``In all honesty, I don't remember the children being allowed to see the corpses, and they certainly weren't allowed in there on their own,'' she said.
She said she remembered the migrant children as no better and no worse than the other children staying in the orphanage.
``But many of them were Welsh and they had the most beautiful singing voices,'' she said.
``Everyone used to say I favoured them too much, because I always brought them out to sing on special occasions.''

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am sympathetic to the causes of the migrant children of those days, I consider that they were given a good chance to settle in a prosperous country-or a country that was prosperous at the time. There is quite a deal of doubt about that at present. I consider that most of them made good of their opportunities. Institutions were not the only places in which life was hard. It was no different for, say, a child migrant brought up on a developing farm in the rural areas around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on to the positives, I would like to carry on a little further along that line. As I said, I am sympathetic to the cause of these people, but the point is whether they are laying the blame for their problems in Australia, if there is any to lay, at the feet of the right people. Sympathetic as I am, I have to say that before they came to Australia someone gave them up to put them in institutions. Someone had to do that. These institutions did not go to England and kidnap them off the streets. They were given up in the first place. So if there is any ire amongst those people, that is where, unfortunately, it has to be directed.

Now let us look at the positives. There is now a society called the Child Migrant Society Inc. of Western Australia. The members of this society are joining together to help each other find their identity. I know that the Christian Brothers are helping with the records. I had a meeting with them last week before coming here. I had intended to speak on this matter. They have not burnt those records, as Senator Jenkins told us back in June and would have had us believe. I also know that the Department of Community Affairs in Western Australia is working on the matter. That Department is sympathetic, and there are far more records around than we were led to believe. Having worked on these files, I know that there are in Western Australia quite a few files which are completed as far as those in Western Australia can go. In other words, they have all the knowledge that they need.

These files now have been sent to England and to Ireland for further research. That is where the problem lies; the people that work overseas on the problem are either voluntary or part time workers. Of course, people overseas working on these files need investigative skills, rather than just being social workers, to be able to track down where these children came from. This is where the Federal Government can take a role-in providing funds or personnel. Senator McKiernan probably understands that, although the large populations in places in Ireland do not move far away, there are a lot of records to go through. I believe that the Commonwealth Government has a role to play, because Western Australia was not the only State that took child migrants. I know that New South Wales did, and I am pretty sure Victoria did the same. As I said, it is an Australia-wide problem, and I think that the Minister responsible should take it on board to try to work in that way. Time is important, because these migrant children are now in their fifties. I will quote from Senator Jenkins's speech:
Now a lot of these past child migrants are adults. They are searching for their records-and, indeed, their very identity . . .

I certainly hope that they are adults, because they migrated at least 40 years ago. As I said, they are now in their early fifties and the chances of their parents being alive are quite minimal and diminishing, but at least they may be able to find the rest of their families. Of course, finding their parents or their families might not be a pleasant surprise, nor might the family find it a pleasant surprise. That is why there is a need for better skilled personnel. That is where I believe the Federal Government should help, because we need the types of people who can convey messages, rather than people being given the shock horror of being told, `This is the son or the daughter you gave up and now he or she is back and knocking on the door'. Many of those families do not want to see their children any more, which is very sad. I consider that, even though problems may occur with their finding their families, these people in Western Australia, and anywhere else for that matter, should be given the chance to find their identity.

Senator Jenkins accuses the Christian Brothers of ill-doings which have not been substantiated because no complaints have come back for 40 years and we cannot find anyone who said anyone did this. All they tell us is that it happened to someone. We have not had anyone come forward who has said: `This happened to me'. I am speaking on this matter because I do not like to see these institutions and others, whether they belong to this faith which I am talking about or any other faith, being accused after 40 years. Most of these people are not around to defend themselves. Their families can hardly hop in and start defending them because they were not there on a first-off basis.

I do not like attack on the work that these orders have done and on those that have spent their lives in the care and education of someone else's children, as in the case of the Christian Brothers. I am proud to say that I am Christian Brother-educated. Many people in remote areas and many other migrants would not have had an education past a very basic primary school education if these teaching institutions had not existed. Not only did these institutions exist, but they provided education at a very low cost. If one looks around Australia one can see some very successful people who received that sort of low cost education. The teachers in these institutions gave up their lives to help others. As I said earlier, it is with regret that I stand up and speak on this matter, but in fairness to all concerned I thought that Senator Jenkins needed to be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware that Senator Panizza was going to raise these matters this evening, so I will speak only briefly. What I related in my speech about child migrants was information given to me personally, by people in my office for the most part. Indeed, as Senator Panizza knows, I had some of that information for some months before speaking out at all. Senator Panizza spoke as if I had stated that every child migrant in these institutions was cruelly dealt with. I did not say that at all. What I said was that certain of these children, who are now adults, of course, had come to me with great concern, primarily about their papers, but secondly, about the very cruel way that they were dealt with in some cases and about how they regretted that they had had to hide this fact all of their lives. In fact, most of these people, believe it or not, hid the fact that they were child migrants. Many women, for example, would deliberately keep this information from their neighbours.

SPEECH.PARA: Two books, that I have read and that I am aware of, have been written by ex-child migrants. These books are called Geordie and Lost Children of the Empire. There has been also a television program in the United Kingdom called Lost Children of the Empire. After my words in the Senate-and I must say that I have not put out a single press release on any of the issues; I merely delivered my speech in the Senate-two articles appeared in the West Australian. Some ex-child migrants telephoned the West Australian and told of other events of which I had not been aware because these people had not contacted me. About a week later, a journalist of the West Australian, Kent Acott, produced a front page article on this very subject. He spent a whole evening with a group of ex-child migrants who had formed themselves into the Child Migrant Friendship Society. Senator Panizza should also talk to Kent Acott of the West Australian, who may have other stories which he can relate to him of which I am not aware.

There is no doubt in my mind that some children at the time were cruelly treated and abused. But I am not suggesting that this happened to every child. Undoubtedly, the whole scheme was set up with the best of motives. What we have to remember is that these children at the time were particularly vulnerable. They had no family to turn to. In many instances their schooling was also inside the institution, so these stories were simply never told. I have in my possession a photocopy of a letter-I have seen the original, a hand written letter-which describes unbelievable cruelty which took place in an institution in Scotland. The person concerned came out to Australia as a child migrant hoping to have left that cruelty in Scotland, where he had his fingers broken with a cane and was denied hospital treatment for some days. When he came to Australia he hoped for better things, but he was one of the unfortunate ones who did not have a better time in Australia.

Since these remarks were made public I have had a very angry telephone call from a woman who also has been institutionalised. She was Australian born. She, and others like her, have formed another society called `Children who have suffered from institutional abuse', or some such title. She berated me for referring only to children who came here as migrants and for not bringing up the matter of Australian-born children who were reared in institutions. She recently obtained her records from child welfare. I have seen her files. All I can say, without having them before me, is that they show remarkable insensitivity. At some later stage, because I have her permission to do so, I will table the photocopies of the file.

I regret it if some of the institutions which have been mentioned felt offended. That was not the reason I spoke out. But when I am confronted by people in my electorate of Western Australia who have come to me with these concerns and problems, I feel that I cannot ignore them. Because this matter has been made public some of these people have had access to their files. I am helping people write letters to the editor and these are being published in newspapers in the United Kingdom-England, Scotland and Ireland-where people are trying to trace relatives and there seems to be no other way of doing so.

The Government departments are now being more helpful and that is to be commended. However, many of these people still have a long way to go. Many still have not been able to make contact with relatives who might still be alive. Some have. In some cases, they have made contact with a parent, even though they are middle-aged themselves-sometimes a parent is still alive-and in others with brothers and sisters. This is an unpleasant matter. It is not something which we like to talk about, but I believe that it is also not something which should be hidden, especially when the people concerned want the facts brought out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your contribution and Senators Panizza and Jenkins for their contributions to the adjournment debate this evening. I will draw the issues that have been raised to the attention of the relevant Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.09 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the current position of the Mogumber and Wandering Aboriginal Missions in Western Australia.
(2) What funding is provided to each Mission by the Commonwealth.

(3) Will the Minister provide any or all audit reports or financial statements which have been conducted into, or provided in relation to, the operation of each Mission over the past 5 years; if not, what are the financial details of each Mission for the past 5 years.
(4) In relation to the Wandering Mission, what debts, if any, are outstanding.

(5) In relation to the Mogumber Mission, was it the case that, when handed over to the Aborigines, it was intended that farming operations would be conducted; if so, are farming operations actually being conducted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Neither Mogumber nor Wandering have operated as missions for many years. No financial assistance has been provided to Mogumber by either the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) in recent years. Consequently, the current financial position is unknown. The property is being developed as a farm and there is no resident ``community'' as such.

As with Mogumber, there is no resident ``community'' at Wandering, which is operated as a farm and training centre by the Southern Aboriginal Corporation (SAC). The property has been under SAC administration since 1 July 1986.
(2) For Wandering the following information is provided in respect to current funding (1988-89) within the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio:
The Department of Aboriginal Affairs-Nil
Aboriginal Development Commission-$80,000
(3) Neither the ADC nor DAA have any audit reports for Mogumber, nor are they required to.
Audited reports in respect of Wandering are available and I will provide the honourable senator with copies.

This is done with the concurrence of the SAC Chairperson who has asked that it be noted that some accounting difficulties were encountered due to technical inadequacies while converting to a computerised accounting system in 1986-87 and inadequate human resources but that these matters have now been resolved.
(4) Officers of DAA are not aware of any outstanding debts.
(5) The Mogumber land is owned and operated by the WA Aboriginal Lands Trust which has advised that it was intended to operate the former Mission as a farm and this is being done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount of Department of Aboriginal Affairs and/or Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) funds have been committed and appropriated to Tranby Aboriginal Training College in Sydney for 1988-89, what remittances have been made and the proposed uses of the funds.

(2) What detailed assessment by the ADC, if any, was done regarding the Tranby Aboriginal Training College for its grant of $420,000 for secretariat and organisational functions relating to negotiations on the proposed treaty with Aboriginals: if no detailed assessment was made, what references for Tranby Aboriginal Training College were used for choosing Tranby to undertake this very significant task.

(3) Was the Minister and/or the ADC aware of any involvement of Tranby Aboriginal Training College activities with each of the following groups: (a) Young Socialists League of Australia; (b) World Federation of Democratic Youth; (c) Campaign for Solidarity with Cuba and Nicaragua; (d) Australians for Kanak Independence; (e) Campaign for Nuclear Free and Independent Pacific; (f) Kooris for Nicaragua; (g) The Bicentenary Protest Group; (h) International Union of Students; and (i) Committee to Defend Black Rights over the past 5 years and the nature of this involvement.

(4) Was the Minister and/or the ADC aware of any meetings which have been held at Tranby Aboriginal Training College by each of the following groups and whether any of these groups or any other organisations have paid for the use of the facilities at Tranby for these meetings; (a) Young Socialists League of Australia; (b) World Federation of Democratic Youth; (c) Campaign for Solidarity with Cuba and Nicaragua; (d) Australians for Kanak Independence; (e) Campaign for Nuclear Free and Independent Pacific; (f) Kooris for Nicaragua; (g) The Bicentenary Protest Group; (h) International Union of Students; and (i) Committee to Defend Black Rights, over the past 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) has informed me that it has committed funds to the Co-operative for Aborigines Limited, Glebe (Tranby Aboriginal Training College) in 1988/89 as follows:
Purpose...$
a To prepare training materials and provide training for directors of DAA and ADC-funded Aboriginal organisations in the Bourke, Broken Hill and Queanbeyan regions.
b To provide training for directors of DAA and ADC funded organisations in the Parramatta region.
c Property management training for Aboriginal housing companies, through the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales.
All funds have been released to Tranby Aboriginal College, or their release is being processed by the Department.
The Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) has informed me that it has committed funds to Tranby Aboriginal Training College for 1988/89; as follows:
Purpose...$
a Consultations concerning the proposed Treaty (expenses incurred by Tranby in conducting meetings at Framlingham and Cairns on behalf of the ADC).
b Management Advisory Services: Aboriginal Development Unit (Enterprises)
c Training Advisory Services: training for directors.
All these funds have been released, except for $1,000 for director training.

(2) The ADC has informed me that, although detailed discussions took place at the August 1988 meeting of the Commission, the ADC did not provide a grant of $420,000 to Tranby Aboriginal Training College.
(3) and (4) I had no knowledge of Tranby Aboriginal Training College's involvement with any of the organisations listed and the ADC has informed me that it had no knowledge of such involvement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 April 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister obtain and table in the Senate the documents dated 23 January and 3 February 1989 to which he referred in replying to a question about threatened suspension of Commonwealth funding to Hopevale Aboriginal Community.
(2) Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs given any consideration not to proceed with funding for the Hopevale Community for a reason other than a political point of view held by an individual.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In respect of the second part of the honourable senator's question, the Government has allocated $6 million to the Hopevale Aboriginal community under the 2 year Priority Communities Development Strategy; $3.8 million in 1988/89 and $2.2 million in 1989/90. Works undertaken under the strategy include roadworks, house construction and the provision of water and sewerage facilities. Consideration was not given at any stage to withdraw, defer, or decrease funding to the Hopevale Community as the Government recognises the need in this area and has always considered the funding to be essential.
Turning to the first part of the honourable senator's question, in view of the details above, I do not intend to table the documents of 23 January and 3 February 1989 as they are respectively:
a standard minute from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to his Departmental Secretary approving the Hopevale funding arrangements detailed above; and
a letter of offer from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Hopevale Aboriginal Community explaining the 1988/89 and 1989/90 funding arrangements.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Community Services and Health: Gold Coast Telephone Number

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 5 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Department have a 008 number which may be used by Gold Coast residents who wish to contact officers of the Department in Brisbane; if so, is this number listed in the Gold Coast telephone directory; if not, will the number be listed in future editions of the Gold Coast telephone directory and what is the number.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The only 008 number in the Department is for the First Home Owners Scheme and it is 008 177238. It is currently listed in the white pages of the 1988 Gold Coast district phone book, under the heading of Home Buyers Assistance. However, the National Health Act was recently amended with the inclusion of a new provision in Section 138a, which requires me to provide general access to the Department of Community Services and Health at the cost of a local call. I am currently having possible arrangements for the introduction of this access examined and this will, of course, include the Gold Coast area.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brunette Downs: Living Conditions of Aborigines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: On what date or dates did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, or any member of his staff or of his Department get in touch with Mr Anthony Hoy, or any other reporter or member of staff of the Australian, in relation to:
(a) a visit or visits by Mr Anthony Hoy or Mr Ray Strange to the NT pastoral property known as Brunette Downs; and
(b) 2 articles by Mr Hoy which appeared in the Australian on 5 and 16 May 1989, in relation to Aboriginal living conditions in Brunette Downs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has informed me that its officers had no involvement with Mr Anthony Hoy or any other reporter or member of the staff of the Australian in relation to two articles on the Northern Territory pastoral property, Brunette Downs, which appeared in the Australian on 5 and 16 May 1989.
Minister and members of their staff continually talk to working journalists.

Ministers and their staff members are not required to record contacts with members of the press. I will therefore not establish a precedent by commenting on any Ministerial contact which may have been made with Mr Hoy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ever stated publicly, or indicated in correspondence, that the reason for his failure to recommend proclamation of sub-section 50 (2D) and (2E) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 is on account of concerns on the part of Aboriginal communities over the lack of guarantees by pastoralists of commensurate excisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. I have indicated in correspondence to the Executive Director of the Northern Territory Cattlemen's Association, Mr Emerson, that the amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 limiting the right to claim stock routes and reserves would not be proclaimed until alternative arrangements are made for those groups who are ineligible to apply for excisions under the Northern Territory's Living Area Guidelines and for whom a stock route or reserve claim represents their only current prospect of obtaining secure land tenure.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Brunette Downs: Living Conditions of Aborigines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Aboriginal Affairs take part in a meeting in Darwin on 16 November 1988 which considered living conditions of Aboriginal people on Brunette Downs.
(2) Was one outcome of the meeting an agreement by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to replace 8 existing homes, upgrade the water supply and provide power to the community.
(3) Has work on these improvements yet begun.
(4) Was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs informed of the above matters when he wrote to the Australian on 19 May 1989.

(5) Can the Minister confirm that, although the Aboriginal people `have no title to the area of land on which they live', the Jarnha-Gadariangi Aboriginal Corporation holds the sub-lease to 4,000 hectares of land excised from Brunette Downs in 1982; that this area was selected by the community leaders in 1980; and that, notwithstanding the existence of this sub-lease, another sub-lease in an area known as the Two-Mile Waterhole has been sought by the community and agreed to in principle by the lease- holders.
(6) Can the Minister also confirm that the area of land on which the Aboriginal community live at present is very close to the Brunette Downs homestead.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The response to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) An outcome of the meeting on 16 November 1988 in Darwin was a subsequent meeting of a number of government agencies with the Aboriginal community at Brunette Downs. The Aboriginal community at that subsequent meeting sought assistance from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to improve their living conditions. There are complex legal questions in placing fixtures on land which is owned by another. As the community does not have title to the land they live on, the Department was obliged to seek advice from the Attorney-General's Department on what steps could be taken to assist them by placing improvements on the land. As a result of advice received, an agreement was negotia-ted with the Northern Territory Government and the pastoral lessee, the legal owners of the land, permitting the placing of limited improvements on that land.
(3) Yes.
(4) The Minister was aware of the outcome of the meetings.

(5) The Jarnha-Gadariangi Aboriginal Corporation was granted a sub-lease to Corella Creek in 1982. The Aboriginal community had also requested land tenure to the camp site adjacent to the homestead, where they still reside. Both areas hold strong traditional affiliations to the community. The Australian Agricultural Company offered an excision area to Two Mile Water-hole on the condition that the community be relocated and the present camp site was demolished.
(6) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to the assessment of mining proposals for Christmas Island, why did Mr Yeomans, although under no legal obligation to do so, not explore the matter of royalties with Century Metals and Mining.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All parties expressing an interest in acquiring the mining assets of PMCI and recommencing mining operations, including Century Metals and Mining, were given a full opportunity to put their proposals to the Liquidator. The Liquidator regarded his initial task as being to assess the proposals for the purpose of determining with whom he should negotiate and to advise the Minister on the matter. The Liquidator has advised that as the Century proposal was, on the basis of the material submitted, not the best proposal, negotiations with Century on any aspect of its proposal did not arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to Mr Booth's correspondence and submission to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) of 6 February 1989 regarding a mining proposal on Christmas Island:
(a) when did Mr Holding's office receive this material;
(b) when was it forwarded to the Department;
(c) who was it forwarded to in the Department;
(d) who else in the Department saw it;
(e) was it forwarded to the liquidator of the Phosphate Mining Corporation;
(f) was any internal response prepared to Mr Booth's claim that his consortium's proposal maximised returns to the Commonwealth, if so, what was the text of this response; and
(g) why has it taken so long for Mr Booth's missive to be answered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) On or about 13 February 1989.
(b) 13 February 1989.
(c) The External Territories Branch.

(d) First Assistant Secretary, Corporate Management, Information and Territories Division; Assistant Secretary, Territories Branch; officers of the Christmas Island Section involved in preparing a response and officers in the Parliamentary Liaison area who process such correspondence.
(e) Yes;

(f) Yes; A draft reply was prepared by the Department and forwarded to the Minister's office on 10 March 1989 advising Mr Booth that the Minister had not received any advice from the Liquidator to suggest that the Elders proposal had altered in such a way that he would believe their proposal was no longer superior to the others he assessed; that he had not been advised of any reason why negotiations could not go ahead with Elders and that the matters raised were more appropriately matters for the Liquidator to whom he had passed the correspondence for action.

(g) An initial response was provided to Mr Booth by the Minister's Senior Private Secretary on 13 April 1989. Mr Booth's missive was not insubstantial and contained a number of points which were the subject of telephone conversations between the Minister's office and Mr Booth prior to the provision of that letter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to Departmental documents pertaining to the selection of a process of assessment for Christmas Island Mining proposals, if so, do the documents succumb to an interpretation that, against the view of the Assistant Secretary for External Territories that this assessment be done by consultants, the Departmental Secretary ensured use of an alternative means of assessment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to his assertions in the Senate on 9 May 1989 regarding mining proposals for Christmas Island, how can the Minister maintain:
(a) the superiority of Elders Resources' proposal in matters going to capacity to pay offset Booth's superiority on royalties; and
(b) that Elders Resources' proposal maximises potential returns, when
(i) Mr Yeomans' assessment said Booth's price estimates appeared conservative, whereas Elders' price was fixed,
(ii) Elders' closeness to Booth on royalties is arbitrarily based on a comparison of Booth's proposal with the better, rather than the worse, of basically 2 Elders' options,
(iii) Booth's superiority on rehabilitation has a major positive financial implication, and
(iv) Booth also complied with Mr Punch's advice on employment preference for Islanders, whereas Elders' did not.

(2) With reference to his assertion in the Senate on 9 May 1989 that Mr Yeomans acted in accord with the Attorney-General's advice that he should not be concerned with the viability of proposals, except insofar as this affected a potential purchaser's capacity to pay:
(a) is not capacity to pay a question of threshold rather than degree; and
(b) did not the Booth Consortium satisfy this threshold.
(3) Will the Minister seek the Attorney-General's Department's opinion on whether Mr Yeomans acted in accord with their advice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) In this matter the then Minister accepted the judgment of the assessor, a professional liquidator and accountant, who recommended that negotiations be commenced with Elders despite his conclusion that Booth offered the potential for slightly higher royalties. In recommending Elders, the Liquidator believed that subject to satisfactory negotiations, the Elders proposal offered the greatest prospect of returns being maximised to the Commonwealth (including return on the Corporation's assets). This is consistent with the advice from the Attorney-General's Department. At no time did the Liquidator recommend that the Elders proposal be accepted as a final position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government's Phosphate Mining Corporation set aside $6.5 million in the event of mine closure, for the restoration and rehabilitation of large areas of Christmas Island scarred by mining, and did the Government decide to spend only $500,000 on selective rehabilitation.

(2) Is it not a fact that last year's cyclone caused massive damage to the Island's rainforest canopy, that thousands of trees were blown over and many Abbott's Boobies' chicks, fledgelings and nesting sites were lost, increasing concern over the long-term survival of the species.
(3) Has the selective rehabilitation of mined areas near nesting concentrations begun.

(4) Is the Department aware that the 1987-88 Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service Annual Report says `previously in this Report the need to implement a rehabilitation program has been stressed. Not to do so makes almost inevitable the loss of this species of great national and international concern', if so, what action is being taken.
(5) Has the nursery on the Island been abandoned; if so, what effect will this have and what plans are in train to compensate for this.

(6) Has the Island Administration, the Department or the Government ever received representations about the dangers of Newcastle Disease being imported in live poultry to Christmas Island from Singapore and Indonesia.
(7) Have any studies been done on whether Abbott's Booby or the Frigate Bird are susceptible to Newcastle Disease.
(8) What quarantine measures are in place to detect possible importation of Newcastle Disease to Christmas Island.

(9) On 15 March 1988 did the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) tell the Senate he would `very shortly almost double' the Christmas Island National Park, which then covered 17 per cent of the Island.
(10) What consultations had the Department at this stage undertaken with Christmas Islanders on this extension.

(11) Is it not a fact that the General-Secretary of the Union of Christmas Island Workers (Mr Bennett) wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying by all means extend the National Park, but do so in consultation with the community.
(12) Did any consultation occur with the community following this letter.

(13) Is it fair to say that this proposal to double the National Park was a fairly arbitrary one and that little consultation, other than with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, occurred on the boundaries.
(14) Is it fair to say that, under this proposal, areas of dubious significance were proposed to be included, while areas which should have been included were excluded.

(15) When referring to doubling the National Park, did Mr Arnaudon say in a minute of 22 March 1988 that ``all significant rainforest is included''; if so, why has the Department been working on quadrupling the size of the Christmas Island National Park to cover approximately 70 per cent of the Island.
(16) Why was it decided that the National Park should be quadrupled, when previously the Minister had been content that it be doubled.
(17) Who suggested and decided the National Park could be quadrupled and when did this happen.

(18) Is it not a fact that, following Senator Richardson's promise to double the Park, the previous Opposition Spokesman on External Territories (Mr Braithwaite) suggested that he personally believed the National Park could be tripled, without causing any problems to mining.
(19) Was the Department and the Minister made aware of this comment, which was reported in the ``Canberra Times''.
(20) On what date was the proposal to double the National Park, which in March 1988 was to be announced very shortly, put in doubt.
(21) What consultations has the Department had on the proposal to quadruple the National Park with Christmas Islanders and, in particular, the Christmas Island Community Council.
(22) Were there any consultations with mining companies on this extension.

(23) Do the new boundaries of the new National Park, as outlined in the Notice under subsection 7 (12) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, published in the ``Australian'' on 5 April 1989, contain areas of regrowth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the time the Government decided to close the mining operation on Christmas Island it made $500,000 available for rehabilitation of areas which would afford the Abbott's Booby the greatest protection as the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island had not set aside any rehabilitation funds.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Government's rehabilitation program has commenced with re-establishment of an Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service plant nursery on the Island. Plants are being propagated in the nursery and will be replanted in previously cleared areas of the island focusing initially on areas affording the Abbott's Booby the greatest protection.
(4) Yes. The Government's conservation strategy for the Island which focuses on the preservation of the Island's rare flora and fauna is being implemented. The strategy includes:
a Commonwealth funded $0.5 million programme for the selective rehabilitation of rain-forest clearings to promote breeding success of the endangered Abbott's Booby;
a major extension to the Christmas Island National Park, (which will increase the size of the present Park to cover between 60-70% of the Island);
the development of an appropriate plan for Park management; and
land which will remain outside the new Park boundaries will be managed in sympathy with Park management objectives.
(5) See (3) above.
(6) Yes.

(8) Since July this year, in accordance with Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service policy and under the provisions of the Territory's Prohibited Imports Ordinance 1988, no eggs, poultry or poultry products are permitted entry into Christmas Island unless they are sources from the Australian mainland.

(9) The Senate Hansard of 15 March 1988 records ``I am considering a further extension of the national park, which will almost double its size. Hopefully, I can announce that and a plan of management for the enlarged area very shortly.'' At the time of formal notification the agreed park boundaries exceeded the initial estimate quoted by the Minister.
(10) No formal consultation had occurred.

(11) Mr Bennett wrote to the Prime Minister on 9 May 1988 outlining his concern that the possible extension to the National Park may impact adversely on the proposals to reopen the mining industry. In the same letter Mr Bennett also requested that the local community be given the opportunity to make submissions on the proposed new boundaries.

(12) The former Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, replied to Mr Bennett on behalf of the Prime Minister on 2 September 1988. In his response Mr Punch informed Mr Bennett that representations on the proposed new boundaries would be called for from interested organisations and the public as required under Section 7 (12) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975.

(13) The proposed new park boundaries were established on the basis of known research and incorporate all areas identified by an independent consultant in 1985 as wildlife habitat of national or international significance and/or areas of high landscape value. Other areas of the Island subsequently identified in these categories have also been included. Areas of the Island of high local conservation value although not included in the park extension will be managed in sympathy with the park and are areas where some tourist development could proceed. These boundaries will be kept under review.
(14) It is considered that all areas included within the park boundaries were justified. Further areas which are currently excluded will be reconsidered for inclusion at some time in the future.
(15) See (13) above.
(16) See (13) above.

(17) In July 1988 the proposal to extend the National Park was agreed between the Minister for the Arts and Territories, (Hon. Clyde Holding MP), and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, (Senator Richardson), on the basis of a joint submission from my Department and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

(18) The Department has no record of any such comment by Mr Braithwaite. Mr Braithwaite was quoted in the ``Canberra Times'' on 22 March 1988 as saying that a coalition government would rehabilitate areas already mined and would be prepared to triple the area of rainforest currently included as national park. The article does not report Mr Braithwaite as saying that he would treble the size of the National Park. In fact the same article goes on to suggest that the Government should not limit private mining concerns to clearing stockpiles and that the Government should be prepared to allow the clearing of an additional 80 hectares of rainforest. In his media release of 21 March 1988 Mr Braithwaite does not rule out the need to clear additional areas of rainforest for a future mining operation.
(19) Officers of the Department were aware of the article, however, the Department does not have any record of the ``Canberra Times'' article specifically being brought to the Minister's attention.
(20) See (17) above.

(21) Prior to formal notification in April 1989, the proposed extension to the Park was informally raised by the Administrator with local community members and representatives both individually and in Community Consultative Group meetings. The formal consultation process has now commenced with the public being invited to provide comments as part of the formal notification process under the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Services Act. Information on the proposed extension is available on the Island in English, Chinese and Malay. The Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will fully consider any comments before final gazettal occurs.

(22) On 11 February 1988 the former Minister for Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch MP, stated in a media release that the Government would not allow any further rainforest clearing as this was not consistent with the Government's long term strategy for the Island. Potential mine operators were advised that mining was to be conducted only in previously mined and cleared areas on the Island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the Department's answer to my Estimates Committee question concerning the power station contract awarded to H & S Sales, is it not the case that:
(a) DASETT originally proposed a new fully-automated power station for Christmas Island at a cost of $1.4 million;
(b) in November 1988 a second proposal to automate the existing power station at a cost of $1 million was developed; and

(c) the Australian Construction Services has awarded the contract for this new work to H & S Sales, without new tenders being called; if so, (i) why was this done, and (ii) what is the status of the Department's answer to my Estimates question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Yes.

(b) In September 1988 the Department sought the assistance of the Australian Construction Services to automate the existing power generation equipment. The present estimate of costs is in the order of $0.97 million.

(c) and (c) (i) Australian Construction Services have advised that H & S Sales are not responsible for the total project but only for provision of site labour and minor components required as part of site installation, ie 26% of the total cost of the project.
Australian Construction Services issued a Certificate of Exemption from calling public tenders on the following grounds:
work was urgent;
H & S Sales were established on site-they had the electrical and mechanical tradespersons on Island under contract;
H & S Sales had previously carried out work on the power station;
H & S Sales were suitable contractors;
H & S Sales had the resources to carry out the work in specified time.

All contracts, including that with H & S Sales were awarded only following careful consideration, limitations set by existing equipment and the competitiveness of tenders from firms compared to Australian Construction Services' estimates.
(ii) The answer to your question in Senate Estimates Committee D referred to the contract for the operation of the power station not the automation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the media release issued by a former Minister, Mr Brown, on 16 September 1987, entitled `Christmas Island Mine May Close', in which Mr Brown said `The Federal Government is ready to shut down phosphate mining on Christmas Island if current industrial bans are not lifted' and that `there was work on the Island for 300 miners for a further 2.5 years before the eventual closure of the mine', did
(a) the Department draft this release for Mr Brown; if so, who drafted it;
(b) Mr Brown, when he visited Christmas Island on 5-6 September 1987, tell the UCIW to lift its bans or the mine would close;
(c) the UCIW lift its bans subsequent to Mr Brown's visit and prior to his press release; and
(d) Mr Brown's release ignore this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Yes; the media release was drafted in the Christmas Island Section.
(b) Yes.

(c) While industrial bans and limitations concerning a number of issues were lifted on 11 September 1987, the UCIW instituted legal challenges to the operation of large mobile plant between 11-21 September 1987 which resulted in the plant not being operational during this period.
(d) See (c) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the minute of 17 March 1989 from the Director of the Christmas Island Services Corporation to the Christmas Island Consultative Committee, which said he had a clear obligation to recover back rents if they were not paid voluntarily
(a) did an officer from the Christmas Island Administration deliver this minute to the Union of Christmas Island Workers (UCIW) office; if so, why;
(b) was the Department aware that this minute was to be delivered and what was the nature of any discussions the Department had about its delivery with officials on Christmas Island;
(c) why was the minute dated one day after the Federal Court's judgment in which the UCIW failed in its bid to have the selection of a successor phosphate operation reviewed;

(d) is the Department aware that the Administration officer who delivered this minute is purported to have said that, now the UCIW had lost its court case, the Services Corporation was going to sue Islanders for back debts; if so, is this true;
(e) did the Department inform the Minister for Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) that this minute was to be delivered; and
(f) had the Minister given any instructions to the Department as to whether or not such a message should be transmitted to Islanders; if so, what.

(2) Did material supplied by the Department of Administrative Services and Homes West on island housing recommend more than one rental structure for Christmas Islanders; if so, how many options were put to the Christmas Island Consultative Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. It is not uncommon for material affecting members of the Union of Christmas Island Workers to be hand delivered to their office as there is no postal delivery service on the Island.
(b) No.
(c) The two dates in question are coincidental.
(d) No.
(e) No.

(f) The Minister wrote to the Director of the Christmas Island Services Corporation, Mr McCutcheon, on 15 December 1988 following advice from Mr McCutcheon that he intended instituting legal action to recover debts. The Minister's advice to Mr McCutcheon was that prior to instigating such action he should discuss the matter with the Christmas Island Consultative Group and seek the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor on how legal proceedings should take place.

(2) The Australian Construction Services/Homeswest housing report discussed three rent structure options but only one rental structure was recommended. The Department wrote to the Community Consultative Group on 16 March 1989 enclosing a copy of the report and seeking their comments prior to the report being finalised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to the assessment of mining proposals for Christmas Island, is it not a fact that the Booth proposal was operationally similar to the Elders proposal.

(2) By recommending Elders' fly-in fly-out proposal, how could Mr Yeomans (the liquidator of the Phosphate Mining Corporation) have been acting in accord with Mr Punch's request for him to give attention to the policy of the West Australian Trades and Labour Council that preference in employment be given to Christmas Islanders where they could demonstrate they had the appropriate skills.
(3) Did a departmental officer ever advise Elders Resources that only a fly-in fly-out mining operation would be approved for Christmas Island.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the liquidator that there were similarities and divergences.

(2) Mr Yeomans recommended that negotiations about future mining be commenced with Elders, he did not recommend that their proposal be accepted as a final position. Had any conditions the Government placed on the recommencement of mining not been agreed, then negotiations would not have been satisfactorily concluded. The WA Trades and Labour Council policy on employment formed part of the negotiations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Department prove it told Mr Punch that the Attorney-General's Department had advised orally that the liquidator should be concerned only with winding-up PMCI and not with other matters such as the commercial viability of mining proposals before Mr Punch announced Mr Yeomans' appointment on 12 May 1988 and prior to his having available the Attorney-General's written advice.
(2) What is the reason for the change of date on the bottom of the minute to Mr Punch of 11 May 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. There is no file record of the telephone conversation during which this advice was passed to the Minister's office.
(2) No reason for the change of date is recorded.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the press release issued by the then acting Minister (Senator Richardson), at the time of the sacking of the Christmas Island Assembly, specifically the part which said, `Despite appeals from the Department over many months, and Mr Brown's recent personal intervention, the Assembly has shown itself unwilling or unable to take decisions to place its affairs on a satisfactory basis' and that `the Assembly has been unable to balance the budget of its municipal authority, the Christmas Island Services Corporation', did either the Minister's Departmental Head or First Assistant Secretary for External Territories have a role in drafting or approving this release; if so, what role.
(2) With reference to the media kit prepared at the time the Government closed phosphate mining on Christmas Island,
(a) did the Minister's Departmental Head and First Assistant Secretary for External Territories read and approve this media kit;

(b) did this kit say that `the Assembly did not seek assistance from the Department in over-coming this problem . . . The Department nevertheless decided to assist . . . (and) . . . arranged for a consultancy to be undertaken into the Services Corporation's financial base, management practices and structure'.

(3) With reference to a minute from the Assistant Secretary for External Territories to the Minister of December 1988, which noted a projected deficit for CISC of $7.245 million for 1988-89, how is it that the Assistant Secretary could contradict Senator Richardson's remarks at the time of the Assembly sacking, by saying that it would be `unfair to blame the Assembly entirely for CISC's financial malaise and indeed they instigated a round of redundancies with UCIW support in 1987'.

(4) Why did this minute of December 1988 say the Assembly `asked the Department for support and we provided them with accounting support and management/local government consultancies', thereby totally contradicting the statement in the media kit of November 1987 about the Assembly not seeking assistance.

(5) Would it be fair to assume that the Assembly's management of CISC's budget was misrepresented in both Senator Richardson's release and the media kit, in order to justify the sacking of the Assembly.
(6) Was CISC's financial position evaluated monthly and a balanced budget produced.
(7) Did Senator Richardson's release at the time of the Assembly sacking say that, under Assembly control, the Services Corporation was `on the verge of going broke', if so:
(a) what was its projected deficit then;
(b) what was it in December 1988; and
(c) what is it now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the acting First Assistant Secretary External Territories drafted the media release.
(2) (a) Yes.
(b) The media kit stated:

``The Assembly did not seek assistance from the Department in overcoming this problem because of the position those members of the Assembly in the Union have adopted over the years. The Department nevertheless decided to assist.

``As a first step to assist both the Assembly and the Services Corporation in addressing this immediate problem, the Department arranged for a consultancy to be undertaken into the Services Corporation's financial base, management practices and structure''.
The problem referred to in this statement was described in paragraph one of Attachment D of the media kit.

(3) The Assembly's inability to properly manage the financial affairs of CISC was exacerbated by significant structural problems in CISC. The Minute of December 1988 to the Minister states that despite the introduction of realistic charges by the Acting Assembly, CISC was still over-staffed, less than fully productive, had an excessive wage rate and allowance structure and was involved in commercial activities more appropriate to the private sector.

(4) The media kit actually states that the Assembly did not seek assistance from the Department in overcoming the problem it had in balancing the Services Corporation budget during the second half of 1986. The Minute of December 1988 states that the Assembly asked the Department for support and it provided them with accounting support and management/local government consultancies. This refers to the assistance sought by the Assembly in April 1987 following the receipt of the Malcolm and Malcolm report which was commissioned by the Department to help CISC in addressing its financial difficulties. The assistance sought by the Assembly included financing the secondment of officers with local government, accounting and personnel management expertise and also a training officer with particular computing expertise.

(6) As a statutory authority, CISC is responsible for evaluating its own financial position and reporting to the Minister in accordance with the CISC Ordinance. Following the resignation of the Director in March 1988 and delays in appointing a new Director until July 1988, estimates of receipts and expenditure for 1987/88 were not submitted to the Minister, although CISC briefed the Department on its financial position at regular intervals as requested by Mr Brown in October 1987.

(7) The following figures should be read in the context of the Island's population and employment levels. At the time of the dissolution of the Assembly, the mine was operating with PMCI also providing housing subsidies and maintaining much of the Island's infrastructure. The Island's population was approximately 1800 with 650 employed. This resulted in CISC having a larger revenue base and greater economies of scale when compared with the situation in late 1988 when the mine had closed and CISC's revenues were diminished due to a relatively large pool of unemployed and a campaign by the UCIW which involved the majority of residents in refusing to pay appropriate charges for electricity and housing. The Island's population in December 1988 was 1228 with 267 employed. Against that background the information sought is as follows:

(a) The Director CISC advised in August 1987 of a projected deficit of $238,000. At that time there was also a possible further liability of $590,000 and debatable revenue of $291,000 which may have resulted in the deficit realising $1.12M.

(b) The Department on 2 December 1988 briefed the Minister for the Arts and Territories advising that CISC in October 1988 had a projected deficit of $7.245M and recommending a range of measures required to rationalise CISC. The projected deficit did not take into account $2.9M made available in the 1988/89 financial year to underwrite operating losses in the electricity and housing functions.

(c) The Director CISC on 28 April 1989 advised that he would balance the budget for 1988-89 making an allowance of $1.4M for bad debts and Commonwealth subvention of $3.516M. The budget estimate for bad debts resulted from the Union of Christmas Island Workers (UCIW) instructing its members to pay less than the cost recovery rate for electricity, housing, water and sanitation charges. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories met with the UCIW on Christmas Island during May 1989 and negotiated a Heads of Agreement which included UCIW members paying monies due to CISC in accordance with the Heads of Agreement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the name of the person who originated the idea that Mr Yeomans be used to assess Christmas Island mining proposals, when did he ori-ginate this idea and to whom did he subsequently communicate it.

(2) At the meeting between DAS and DASETT officers, convened to discuss options for a formal process of evaluation on 22 April 1988, did DAS or DASETT officers suggest using Mr Yeomans to assess the mining proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am advised that, at a meeting on 22 April 1988 between officers of DAS and DASETT, against the background of the concerns of some proponents that the Department not be involved in the assessment, officers of my Department impressed upon DAS officers the request from several tenderers that the assessment process not be protracted. Officers at the meeting do not recall who first raised the option of using the liquidator. I have been assured that the option arose for the first time at that meeting in the context of keeping the process as short as possible to meet the wishes of proponents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister's Departmental Head approve or help settle:
(a) Senator Richardson's answer to Senator Boswell's Question on Notice No. 871;
(b) the brief Senator Richardson relied on in the Senate on 5 May 1989;
(c) the brief Senator Richardson relied on in the Senate on 5 May 1989, particularly the parts justifying the recommendation of Elders Resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.
(b) No.
(c) The Departmental Head, other Departmental Officers and the liquidator discussed the issues with Senator Richardson before he addressed the Senate on 9 May.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 May 1989.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were 2 former PMCI employees, Mr De Guingand and Mr Hoare, employed by Elders Resources to help develop their mining proposal.
(2) In late 1988, early in the liquidation process, did 2 PMCI employees, Messrs Gardiner and Ronaldson, write to Mr Yeomans, expressing their interest in a successor mining operation.
(3) Did Mr Gardiner later send his criticisms of the Arthur Andersen report, commissioned by the UCIW to examine the feasibility of successor mining, to DASETT.
(4) Were Mr Gardiner's criticisms of the Arthur Andersen study included in Ministerial submission, along with other criticisms from a Mr Inglis and a Mr Ronaldson.

(5) Did Mr Gardiner concede during the recent Federal Court hearing that Arthur Andersen were not given much help by PMCI, even though instructed to do so, partly because of resentment towards the UCIW.
(6) Whilst employed by Mr Yeomans, did Mr Gardiner, in February or March 1988, prepare a report for the Perth United Credit Union on the Arthur Andersen study and an early Century proposal.
(7) During the recent Federal Court hearing, did Mr Gardiner admit he knew this report was critical of Century's proposal and could affect Century's application for finance.
(8) Did Mr Yeomans allow him to do this report `out of work hours'.

(9) In this report, did Mr Gardiner say `it is no secret that Elders Resources is the major Australian company for which Mr Punch opened the door', that `their proposal would be consistent with the Government's objectives for the Island' and that `Government approval to proceed with the existing (Century) Proposal is unlikely'.
(10) Was Mr Gardiner also employed by Mr Yeomans when assessing proposals and, at Mr Yeoman's request, did Mr Gardiner give him his comments on proposals both before and during the assessment.

(11) Did Mr Gardiner admit to the Federal Court that his criticisms of the Century proposal in May 1989, which would have been for Mr Yeomans' assessment were in some respects the same in this report for the Perth United Credit Union.

(12) Did Mr Gardiner also admit to the Federal Court that he would have been wary of anything the UCIW was involved in; wary of their involvement in any consortium, particularly involving Mr Bennett; and had formed strong, unfavourable and resentful views about Mr Bennett in terms of his industrial activities; and from time to time had made derogatory remarks about him.
(13) As well as from Mr Gardiner, did Mr Yeomans:
(a) seek opinions from Mr Ronaldson and Mr Inglis for the purpose of this assessment;
(b) take these views into account; and
(c) repeat these views and words in his report.
(14) What was the period and in what capacity did Mr Hoare work for
(a) Elders Resources; and
(b) Mr Yeomans.
(15) While working for Mr Yeomans, what input did Mr Hoare have into Mr Yeomans' assessment of mining proposals.
(16) Which officers in DASETT:
(a) saw Mr Gardiner's criticisms of the Arthur Anderson study, on which Century's proposal was based;
(b) knew Mr Gardiner was helping Mr Yeomans with his assessment;
(c) knew Mr Hoare was or had been employed by Elders Resources; and
(d) knew Mr Hoare was working for Mr Yeomans.
(17) Do the Minister's answers to the above cause him to doubt the objectivity of the assessment process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Neither the Minister nor the Department are privy to the arrangements employed by Elders Resources to help develop their proposal although it was known that Mr Hoare had been employed by Elders as a consultant.

(2) No. The Liquidator has advised that he did not receive an expression of interest in a successor mining operation from Mr Gardiner and Mr Ronaldson. However, he had been forwarded by the Department a copy of a facsimile sent to the Department by Mr Gardiner and Mr Ronaldson stating that they were preparing a submission. Mr Gardiner later advised the Liquidator that he would not proceed with a submission.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes.
(5) The evidence on this aspect given by Mr Gardiner during the Court case was as follows:
``And, what I am suggesting to you is that the instruction that Mr Yeomans gave was not carried into effect? (answer) Effectively it was physically impossible.

And, another reason was, I suggest to you, that there was a deal of resentment amongst the staff against the union because they felt, that is the staff felt, that in a real sense the union had cost them their jobs? (answer) There was a degree of resentment and that feeling was certainly evident in the management. However, at that time it certainly was not clear-the only thing that was clear to senior management of the PMCI was that that mine was being closed and it was not clear to us at that time that the Government were going to actively allow or seek proposals for a new operation to commence. So when the Arthur Andersen representatives arrived on the island, we thought it was actually a bit of a waste of time.
And, that is not withstanding that Mr Yeomans gave you that instruction? (answer) Yes, he asked us to provide the answer within the time constraints available.''

(6) The Liquidator has advised that in early 1988 Mr Gardiner sought his approval to prepare a report for a financial institution independently and in his own time. The Liquidator understands from the evidence that was given in the Federal Court that Mr Gardiner prepared the report. The report was never provided to the Liquidator, the Department or the Minister and only became known to the Department and the Liquidator during the Federal Court case.
(7) The evidence given by Mr Gardiner in the recent Court case was as follows:
``And you knew that it could affect the result of that application? (answer) My understanding was that it was required by United Credit to assist them in evaluation of an application by Century.
That is right. And from that you understood at the time that it could affect the result of that application? (answer) Yes.''
``And your assessment of the Century proposal was also critical? (answer) I think I produced a balanced assessment of the Century proposal.
Yes, but it was critical? (answer) In some respects, yes.''
(8) Yes.
(9) A copy of the report was not made available to the Minister, the Department or the Liquidator.

(10) The Liquidator has advised that Mr Gardiner gave him comment on the various proposals and on the Arthur Andersen Report in his capacity as one of the Liquidator's employees in the winding up of PMCI.
(11) The evidence given by Mr Gardiner in the recent Court case was as follows:
``And can we compare the two documents and see where your criticisms were, in some respects, the same? (answer) Yes, no doubt.''
(12) The evidence given by Mr Gardiner in the recent Court case was as follows:

``And as a result of your experience over those five years you had difficulty in being sympathetic to something that the union was involved in, I take it, or Mr Bennett was involved in? (answer) I would have been wary on the basis of past industrial activities.
Yes? (answer) But I do not think that I could accept that as a general statement.
Yes. But if they were to become involved in the consortium you would be somewhat wary about what they might do? (answer) In terms of industrial activities based on past experience, yes.
Yes. And by ``they'' I mean not only the union but Mr Bennett? (answer) Well, I would think probably more Mr Bennett than the union actually.
Had you formed strong views about Mr Bennett? (answer) Yes.
Whilst you were there? (answer) Yes.
And they were not favourable to him; they were unfavourable, were they not? (answer) In terms of industrial activities, yes.''

``And, generally speaking, you and other management people-particularly yourself; I am only asking you of your own knowledge-had a deal of resentment against Mr Bennett? (answer) In terms of past industrial activity that is true, yes.

And there was a tendency to denigrate him in conversation that you were involved in? (answer) Well, personally I tried to avoid discussing industrial relations or Mr Bennett whilst on Christmas Island because it was a very small community and out of work it was more pleasurable to avoid talking about such things.
Yes, but you did talk about such things? (answer) Occasionally, yes.
Yes. And in the course of talking things were said by you and by others that would be regarded as derogatory of Mr Bennett? (answer) From time to time.''

(13) (a), (b) & (c) The Liquidator has advised that Mr Ronaldson commented on the Arthur Andersen Report but not on the proposals, while Mr Inglis commented on the report and the proposals. In assessing the proposals the Liquidator has advised that he took into account the proposals themselves, supplementary material provided by the three groups, and the advice he had sought in relation to the matter. The Liquidator also took into account the matters the Minister had drawn to his attention prior to undertaking the assessment. The Liquidator also advised that the views expressed in his report are his own, having taken into account the matters and advice referred to.
(14) (a) The Department is not privy to any arrangements entered into between Elders Resources and Mr Hoare.

(b) The Liquidator has advised that Mr Hoare was employed by him as a consultant following the cyclone damage on Christmas Island in March 1988 to advise on the storm damage, attend to repair arrangements and advise on the insurance recovery arrangements. Mr Hoare has continued to be employed by the Liquidator on a part-time basis to attend to those matters and to the care and maintenance program for the Liquidator's assets on the Island.
(15) The Liquidator has advised that Mr Hoare had no input into his assessment of the proposals to recommence mining operations.
(16) (a) The Assistant Secretary, Indian Ocean Territories Branch and officers of the Christmas Island Section.
(b) None; the Department has no involvement with the Liquidator, proponents or individuals from proponent companies during the Liquidator's assessment period.

(c) Elders submission of 4 May provided to the Minister (Mr Punch), included a list of key personnel. The submission indicated Mr Hoare is a consultant to Elders Resources. The Assistant Secretary, Indian Ocean Territories Branch and officers of the Christmas Island Section had access to this report.
(d) Departmental officers concerned with damage on Christmas Island caused by the storm of 27 March 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 25 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Serpentine Leather Pty Ltd of Townsville, Queensland, received a Federally-funded grant relating in any way to the development of a crocodile skin tannery? If so, under what scheme was the grant made, and for how much.
(2) Has any other Queensland company received a Federally-funded grant relating in any way to the development of a crocodile skin tannery; if so, what type of grant and for how much.
(3) What criteria are used in determining whether to award grants of this nature to projects involving utilisation of wildlife resources and how did Serpentine Leather Pty Ltd meet these criteria.
