(4) Was the grant in any way related to enhancing or furthering the company's capacity to develop an export market for crocodile skin; if so, how.
(5) Is there currently a proposal for a management program for Queensland crocodiles under consideration for approval under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.

(6) If the answer to question (4) is `yes' and (5) is `no', why was Federal Government money provided towards furthering this export trade, given that legal exports of crocodile skin from Queensland cannot currently take place, and there is no management program (which would allow for legal exports) currently under consideration by the Federal Government.

(7) According to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 March 1989, Serpentine Leather also processes about 10,000 sea snake skins per year. There is no approved management program under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 for sea snakes. What steps do you intend to take to ensure that crocodile and snake skin leather products produced by Serpentine Leather are not illegally exported from Australia, by tourists or otherwise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Relying in part on information supplied by Austrade, the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program (IAMP), an initiative of the Hon John Kerin, MP, Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and administered by the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE) provided a grant of $126,794 to Serpentine Leather Pty Ltd of Townsville for production and marketing of Australian marine and reptile leathers (including fish and crocodiles) for export to Europe.
(2) I am advised that AUSTRADE has no knowledge of any other grant.

(3) The IAMP requires all applicants to meet the criteria of innovation, agricultural base, developed marketing plan, export or import replacement orientation and private sector involvement. Serpentine Leather's application met all these criteria. The provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 disallow disclosing how the applicant met these criteria.
In the course of assessment of the application the project activity must be within the law. This was seen to be so in Serpentine Leather's application.

(4) The grant was provided to produce leathers of marine and reptile animals, including fish and crocodiles, for export. Up to now there has been minimal production of crocodile leather in Australia. The majority of crocodile skins produced are exported in salted form for tanning overseas.

(6) AUSTRADE has informed the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service that the applicant, Serpentine Leathers Pty Ltd, advise they intend to draw their supplies of crocodile skins for tanning from:
Edward River Crocodile Farm in Queensland
Northern Territory crocodile farms

Edward River Crocodile Farm Crocodile skins may be exported from Queensland under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 as they are derived from animals bred in captivity in a breeding operation recognised by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

Crocodile skins derived from Northern Territory crocodile farms may be exported after tanning in Queensland because the Northern Territory has a management program for crocodiles approved under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.

(7) The export of items derived from crocodiles and sea snakes requires a permit by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Serpentine Leather does not need a permit for domestic trade in snake skins. Therefore I do not hold records of its domestic processing of snake skins. Serpentine Leather does not hold a permit to export sea snake skins. No export permits will be issued for sea snake leather or crocodile skins derived from animals taken from the wild unless an approved management program is in place. The Act provides penalties of up to $100,000 or 5 years imprisonment for individuals who attempt to illegally export wildlife. The Australian Customs Service is the agency primarily responsible for enforcing the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act, including inspection of goods and permits.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, upon notice, on 29 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What investigations have been carried out to determine the extent of naturally-occurring dioxins in the inland and off-shore waters of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It appears that there is no systematic research being carried out on the extent of naturally-occurring dioxins in either inland or off-shore waters.

There are 75 possible isomers of dioxin. The isomer of most concern is 2, 3, 7, 8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD). Many of the other isomers may well be very toxic, but toxicological tests have not been carried out. The concentration of TCDD is very difficult to measure accurately because of the complexity of mixtures in which it occurs and its extremely low abundance (in the order of a few milligrams in a million tonnes).

We are not aware of any company operating a pulp mill that has carried out a baseline study of dioxins in natural waters, but most would have had some analyses of dioxin levels in their effluent carried out by overseas companies. These typically cost about $1200-$1300 per sample. One of the major overseas laboratories being used is the Chemistry Division of DSIR in New Zealand, but there are other specialist laboratories in the US, UK and Sweden.
There are currently 2 government agencies gearing up to monitor dioxins. They are the State Water Centre Laboratories, Adelaide and the State Government Laboratories, Perth.

The State Water Centre has purchased a gas chromatography mass spectrometer. The equipment is more accurate than the model currently being used by the United States Environment Protection Agency to monitor pulp and paper mill effluent. The equipment was commissioned. The Centre is currently evaluating the EPA analytical method and standards and quantitative software. With the expertise built up at the Centre in the past few years in analysing the by-products of disinfection (chlorination compounds in water)-these are just as difficult to analyse as dioxins and it should be able to tackle this problem. The Centre should have the facility operational by now. I understand that its forthcoming work includes analyses for APM and APPM in Tasmania, and for the Latrobe Water Sewage Board in Victoria.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 6 June 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated annual cost of each of the following elements of ATSIC administration: (a) salaries, allowances, travel, and other related costs for the 19 Commissioners; (b) allowances, travel, etc, costs for meetings of Zone Councils; (c) allowances, travel, etc, costs for Regional Council meetings; (d) allowances, travel, etc, costs for Regional Council Executive Committee meetings; (e) 60 Regional Councils elections, including appeals procedures, and by-elections; (f) the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Council; and (g) region boundary review Committee meetings, hearings and costs of persons constituting the committees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The estimated annual cost of the full board of 20 Commissioners meeting 10 times per year is $800,000.
(b) Nil, as Zone Councils are not being established.
(c) The estimated annual cost of 60 Regional Councils, meeting four times a year, is $2,100,000.
(d) The estimated cost of 60 Regional Council Executive Committees, meeting 5 times a year, is $525,000.
(e) The estimated cost of 60 Regional Council elections is $2.140 million. It is not practicable to estimate at this stage what the cost of appeals might be to the Government.

Because it is proposed that casual vacancies will be filled on the basis of an order of priority determined from the results of the regional council election, there will not be by-elections required (except where the Court of Disputed Elections orders a new election).
(f) The estimated cost of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, based on 4 meetings per year, is $63,000.

(g) The cost of Review Panels convened under clause 138 are not able to be easily estimated as costs will largely depend on the membership of the Panel, and the particular matters raised (which would affect the necessity for travel etc.). It is considered that the costs of the Panel would not exceed $30,000 in any one year, but could be expected to be substantially less.

26 places in the Interim List of the Register
1273 places in the Register
44 places removed from the Interim List or Register or rejected by the Commission
6 places destroyed before being assessed

90 places not assessed as yet by the Commission
13 places in the Interim List of the Register
152 places in the Register
